summary:
- Paul Merson and Andros Townsend had a public disagreement, which started when Merson criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England squad.
- Townsend proved Merson wrong by scoring a goal for England against Italy, and Merson admitted his mistake.
- Despite the apparent reconciliation, Merson made another comment about Townsend after Tottenham's draw with Burnley, where Townsend only played for 7 minutes.
- The core issue was Merson's opinion on Townsend's football skills and his place in the England squad, which Townsend refuted with his performance.

Chelsea have made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto. Muto would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if he moves to west London. A £4million deal for the youngster has been suggested. Muto has not yet decided to join the club, but said it is an honor to receive an offer from such a great club.

A study published in Pediatrics found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers, particularly boys. Researchers found that one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese by age two. Repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being overweight. While the study didn't prove that antibiotics cause weight gain, it's theorized that they may kill off gut bugs that would normally consume some of the food eaten, or that killing certain gut bugs may increase appetite. The researchers caution against the overuse of antibiotics in infancy and highlight the importance of judicious use.

During the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, a Queen's Guard slipped on a manhole cover and fell while taking his position. The incident, which was captured on video by a tourist, shows the guard losing his footing, dropping his rifle, and quickly scrambling back to his feet. Despite his embarrassment, the guard's colleagues continued the ceremony as if nothing had happened. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E Networks is creating a remake of the miniseries "Roots," which will air in 2016. The original 1977 miniseries was about an African American slave and his descendants. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake. The new version will be based on Alex Haley's novel, "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." The producers will consult scholars in African and African American history for added authenticity.

- Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman at Clarence House in 1978, alleged that palace aides attempted to force him into an orgy.
- He reported being pinned to a chair and groped by a staff member on his first day, leading him to quit.
- Lawler's initial complaint in 1978 was allegedly dismissed by Clarence House.
- He contacted palace officials again in 2022 after news of investigations into historical child sex abuse cases.
- After months of delays, his complaint was passed to Scotland Yard.
- A retired royal aide was questioned but denied involvement, claiming he was working elsewhere at the time.
- The Palace has pledged full cooperation with the police investigation.
- The police are currently investigating the claims.

Jesse and Melissa Meek, an Oregon couple, announced their pregnancy in a rap video parody of the "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" theme song. The video went viral, receiving over 1.7 million views on YouTube. In the video, Melissa raps about how they initially told family and friends they weren't ready for kids yet, but after a couple of months of trying, they conceived. The video concludes with the couple sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. The Meeks made the video to share the news with loved ones who live far away and were surprised by its popularity. They are considering making another video to reveal the baby's gender. The Oregonian reported that Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. It was part of a collection of items from the film amassed by James Tumblin, who acquired the dress for $20 in the 1960s when it was going to be discarded. Other notable items sold were a hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000), and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland ($30,000). Gone With the Wind, based on the 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary last year. Actress Hattie McDaniel made history as the first African-American to be nominated for and win an Academy Award for her role in the film.

A two-year-old boy fell into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the railing. He fell 10-12 feet and was rescued by his parents. The boy suffered minor injuries and is in stable condition. Zoo officials plan to press child endangerment charges against the parents.

A non-functioning speed camera, previously used to enforce a 30 mph speed limit, has been mysteriously repositioned to face a house in Handsworth, Birmingham.  The camera, one of many deactivated in 2013 due to obsolete technology, will be assessed by a Birmingham City Council engineer and may be removed. Although there are plans to implement new digital speed cameras at select locations, this particular camera will not be included in the pilot program.

Usain Bolt will be part of the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt says he is fit, healthy, and ready to run, and that he always does his best for his country. Garth Gayle, JAAA General Secretary, stated that they were pleased Bolt was available and that they expect some sprint magic on the track. The rest of the Jamaican team will be announced soon.

Neymar and teammate Dani Alves attended a Barcelona basketball game against Real Madrid. Barcelona won 85-80, though Real Madrid still leads the Euro League. Neymar recently led Brazil to a 1-0 victory against Chile, in which he endured several hard tackles. Barcelona will play Celta Vigo next in La Liga. Neymar was accompanied by his sister Rafaella at the basketball game.

Between Friday and Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued off the coast of Italy. Save the Children reported that a boat carrying 550 migrants capsized in the Mediterranean Sea, but the Italian Coast Guard has not confirmed the incident. Over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with most coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died this year while making the crossing, often due to poor weather and overcrowded boats.

Alexis Sanchez had many options for clubs when he left Barcelona, ultimately choosing Arsenal over Liverpool.  Liverpool may have used their interest in Sanchez as leverage in negotiations with Barcelona for Luis Suarez. Sanchez has adjusted quickly to the Premier League, scoring 19 goals and revitalizing Arsenal.  Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased with Sanchez's performance and has downplayed rumors of a summer transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling. Wenger also praised Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for the team's performance, especially given the loss of Suarez and injury to Daniel Sturridge.

Four-time Olympic champion Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record at the Lee Valley VeloPark on June 7. Wiggins will aim to beat the current record of 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February, in front of a 6,000 capacity crowd with the event broadcast live on Sky Sports. Tickets go on sale April 19.

Serena Williams had to fight back from a set down to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup. Williams stated that the match was an "eye-opener", showing her that she was not ready for the clay court season. The US team lost to Italy 3-2 and were relegated to World Group II.

Radamel Falcao left River Plate in 2009 after playing with them for eight years. River Plate would like to have Falcao return. Falcao currently plays for Manchester United on loan from Monaco, but has only scored four goals for them this season. Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for River Plate when he played for them previously.

Ella Henderson, a finalist on the X Factor and pop star, is the new face of dry shampoo brand Batiste. The 19-year-old singer's partnership with the company was announced as part of Batiste's 2015 "Ready For It" campaign, which will be Henderson's first brand collaboration. The campaign includes a TV ad featuring Henderson's single "Mirror Man" and launched internationally. In the campaign images, Henderson is seen with a variety of hairstyles against a blurred city background. She is pictured wearing a black fringed leather jacket, a black animal-print maxi dress, and a black lacy dress in the photos. Henderson said she's excited to be working with Batiste and that it's a product she uses frequently.

- Aaron Siler, a man wanted for violating parole, was shot and killed by Kenosha police officer Pablo Torres on March 14, following a vehicle and foot pursuit.
- A billboard featuring Officer Torres and thanking the Kenosha community for their support was erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association.
- Siler's family and friends found the billboard disrespectful and called for its removal, while the police association said it was simply a gesture of gratitude for community support.
- The incident occurred 10 days after Officer Torres shot and wounded a suicidal man armed with knives, an action later deemed justified by the District Attorney.
- The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing, while the investigation into the previous shooting has concluded.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed and three militants were killed in fighting on Monday near the Iranian-Pakistani border. The Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian militant group, claimed responsibility for the attack. Iranian officials say the militants crossed into the country from Pakistan and have asked Pakistan to apprehend the surviving assailants. Pakistan has condemned the attack and said if the militants entered Pakistan after the attack they would be apprehended.

- Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani recently stated that the country's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object.
- The statement was made in response to a question from lawmaker Antonio Inoki.
- Inoki, a former wrestler, has a history of making headlines, including fighting Muhammad Ali in 1976 and attempting to replicate Dennis Rodman's "basketball diplomacy" by staging a wrestling tournament in North Korea.
- This isn't the first time Japanese politicians have discussed the implications of visitors from another planet. In 2007 then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba pondered the legal ramifications of a defense against an invasion from outer space.

A man, Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized after he squatted on a toilet in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China. The toilet broke, causing deep cuts on his leg and buttocks which required dozens of stitches. He initially told his friends he was squatting but later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid paying for the damages. Authorities believe the incident was accidental and reminded people that toilets are for sitting.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old Pennsylvania man, was arrested and charged with multiple offenses, including aggravated indecent assault and sexual abuse of children. A 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom, which contained videos of her and others, some showing genitalia. Rebbie admitted to filming the victims, including the 15-year-old girl, over a period of three to four years. He is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama created a photo series of fathers jumping in the air next to their daughters. The daughters maintain a neutral expression while the fathers strike a dramatic pose.  The photos are part of a book called "Daughter and Salaryman." The photos depict the fathers, who are typically serious due to their jobs, expressing a fun, energetic side. Each photo features the daughter in casual clothing and the father in a suit, posed in front of various Japanese landmarks. The photos are gaining popularity online due to their unique and curious nature.

Kevin Pietersen is rejoining Surrey in an attempt to rejoin the England national team after being dismissed in 2014. Pietersen's return comes after England's managing director, Paul Downton, was recently sacked. Pietersen last played for England during the disastrous 2014 Ashes tour in Australia, where England suffered a whitewash defeat. Surrey will begin their season at Glamorgan on April 19.

Ze Maria, former Brazilian football player and coach of Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, was fired twice in one week by club owner Angelo Massone. After initially being fired for a poor run, he was reinstated only to be fired again following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani which left the club 6 points adrift of safety. He had been appointed in January, the club's third coach this season, and was replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's teammate from Monaco, Nabil Dirar, believes that Falcao regrets his move to Manchester United. Falcao moved to Manchester United on loan, but has not performed well and they are not expected to sign him permanently. Dirar suggests that Falcao was unhappy at Monaco, but that he would have been better off staying there, as he would have played more and participated in the Champions League.

Christchurch police are searching for a tall man who robbed a dairy on Saturday. The man was wearing a bright orange sweatshirt and a cartoon mask. He stole the cash register and around $1500. Police are asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old Texas math teacher, has been arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with 15-year-old students. The first arrest was in March for kissing a student and letting him touch her breasts. The second arrest was in April after another 15-year-old student accused Granado of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. Granado has been suspended from teaching and put on administrative leave.

In Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, a crocodile snatched a bike shop owner's dog and swam through a marina with the dog in its mouth. The incident was captured on video and has been viewed over 500,000 times. Witnesses described the scene as shocking, with the crocodile holding the dog for hours. Crocodiles are common in the area, as the resort is built near mangrove habitats. The American Crocodiles in Mexico can grow up to 6 meters long and are increasingly living closer to humans due to urbanization. The video has sparked horrified reactions on social media, with some expressing their newfound hatred for crocodiles.

Hull City lost 2-0 at Southampton on Saturday. They are now just two points clear of the relegation zone with six games remaining. Manager Steve Bruce remains confident Hull can avoid relegation, even though they face difficult fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. He believes they can get the points needed to stay up, but admits this season has been their most difficult yet. Southampton's win moved them up to fifth in the table. Manager Ronald Koeman had to intervene when Sadio Mane tried to take a penalty ahead of designated penalty taker James Ward-Prowse. Koeman said he will remind his players that team rules must be followed.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, was found to have violated exam rules by allowing and making changes to students' SATs exam papers after the exam session had ended. Consequently, the Department for Education voided the entire school's SATs results for the year. Guffick admitted to the misconduct and was banned from teaching for a minimum of two years. While expressing remorse, the panel deemed his actions deliberate and impactful, warranting the prohibition order. Guffick has the option to appeal the decision within 28 days.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United's third-choice goalkeeper, is married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri. The couple wed in 2014 and have a son together. Lindegaard has struggled to make an impact on the pitch since joining Manchester United in 2010, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons. He was linked with a move to FC Midtjylland in January 2015, but the two clubs could not agree on a price. Despite his struggles on the pitch, Lindegaard is happy off the pitch with his wife.

Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson's attempt to auction off the 13 letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium proved unsuccessful. Despite an estimated value between $300,000 and $600,000, the letters, purchased by Jackson in 2008, failed to attract any bids at the Sotheby's auction. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe were pictured recently using legal and illegal substances. Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers spoke with the two players and reminded them of their responsibilities as professional athletes. Rodgers will not punish the players and wants to move forward. The manager believes that the team is ready to win after coming close in the Capital One Cup and the Premier League.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's midfielder, is back in London after playing in Germany's Euro 2016 qualifier win against Georgia. Ozil, who missed Arsenal's last game due to illness, posted a picture of himself at home with his dog. He is expected to start in the upcoming game against Liverpool. Ozil has been performing well since recovering from injury, contributing four assists and three goals since January. He says he is adapting to English football.

- Barcelona are pleased with manager Luis Enrique and do not intend to replace him.
- Enrique's contract is valid until 2016.
- The club is content with his performance, particularly as they are in contention to win three trophies this season.
- After the Champions League match against PSG, Enrique dedicated himself to preparing for the game against Valencia.
- Barcelona defeated Valencia with goals from Suarez and Messi.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new contract with the club that will last until 2020. Henderson's new deal is worth roughly £100,000 per week. Henderson's improved play under manager Brendan Rodgers has resulted in 13 assists and 7 goals this season. When current captain Steven Gerrard departs for the LA Galaxy this summer, Henderson may be named the new captain.

Filipe Luis, despite interest from Atletico Madrid, has stated his desire to remain at Chelsea for the duration of his three-year contract. He acknowledges the challenges faced in securing a starting position but remains committed.  Luis's focus is currently on Chelsea's Premier League title pursuit, echoing manager Jose Mourinho's emphasis on maintaining concentration and winning every remaining game.  The defender recognizes the difficulty of the upcoming nine matches but believes the team is prepared for the challenge.

Nathan Hughes had his 3 match ban overturned after his appeal was upheld. There was no intent found in his actions when his knee hit George North's head. North was knocked unconscious and advised to take a month off. Many people, including Wasps captain James Haskell, spoke in Hughes' defense. Hughes is free to play again but is not in the squad for Wasps' next match. The appeal panel concluded that the incident was accidental and no foul play occurred.

Seattle resident Tim Durkan captured vibrant sunsets over Washington, caused by wildfires in Siberia. The fires, started by farmers on April 14th, spread rapidly due to strong winds, causing significant damage. Smoke from the fires was carried across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, resulting in intense red sunsets due to the filtering of shorter wavelength colors by smoke particles. As the smoke clears, air quality will improve, and the sunsets will return to normal.

Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen and later found by police, thanks to a tip from Mick Sexton. When returned, the car had been altered with red spray paint on the rims and sides, as well as orange accents on the steering wheel. Schoenig has decided to get the car professionally cleaned due to the smell of cigarettes and marijuana. In a show of gratitude, she is also creating a smoothie named "Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, in honor of the man who helped locate her car.

Manchester City players will lose £500,000 in bonuses if they don't qualify for the Champions League. Players are on incentive-based contracts to adhere to Financial Fair Play rules. Currently, City is in fourth place, which means they would need to win a qualifying round to participate in the Champions League. As a whole, the team has roughly £12 million riding on reaching the Champions League. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted that the team has not performed well, especially in the last three months. They are now fighting to sign top players, like Paul Pogba, who is also sought after by Manchester United.

Manchester United's Under 18 team beat Manchester City's Under 18 team 1-0. Callum Gribbin scored the only goal of the match on a free kick. The match was played at Altrincham's stadium in front of a crowd of 1,000. Manchester United's win leaves them two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough.

After England's 1-1 draw with Italy, England goalkeeper Joe Hart, who earned his 50th cap in the match, praised Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon, who earned his 147th cap, as a "legend of the game." The 37-year-old Buffon, who is 10 years older than Hart, inspired Hart, who said that he still has a lot to learn. Hart also expressed his pride in reaching the milestone of 50 caps and his desire to continue playing for his club and country.

Chipotle has partnered with the Postmates app to offer food delivery in 67 cities. Customers using the app will have to pay a 9% service charge in addition to the Postmates delivery fee, which starts at $5. Chipotle joins other franchises such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King in capitalizing on the growing food delivery market. Also, Chipotle has recently seen visits from two presidential candidates, Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton.

The parents of Martin Richard, an 8-year-old boy killed in the Boston Marathon bombings, are publicly requesting that the death penalty be removed as a sentencing option for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was found guilty of the crime. They argue that while they understand the severity of his crimes, removing the death penalty would prevent prolonged suffering for their family caused by years of appeals. They believe this will allow them, and the city of Boston, to heal and move forward.

A mystery billionaire has spent an estimated £400 million to have a Boeing 747 customized into a luxury home over a three year period. The plane, which can normally hold up to 600 passengers, now contains a dining room, kitchen, lounge, 'state room', bedrooms, and an 'aeroloft' that sleeps eight.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket with an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station. The rocket successfully launched, but it landed too hard on a drone ship and tipped over. The Dragon will deliver supplies to the ISS, and after 5 weeks, it will return to Earth with experiments and trash. This is SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS, and the company was the first private contractor to dock with the station.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas at the Westgate Hotel on April 23, 2015. The wedding is part of a contest by NBC's Today show where an Elvis-obsessed couple will win an all-expenses-paid wedding, including a reception, hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets. Priscilla Presley was involved in the design of the chapel, which is the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside of Elvis's Memphis home. To enter the contest, couples must submit a video or photos explaining why they deserve to win. The chapel is located in the same hotel where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows.

Liverpool are only 4 points behind Manchester City in the race for the Champions League.  Liverpool beat Newcastle 2-0 on Monday night. Raheem Sterling scored the first goal in the 9th minute and Joe Allen scored his first Anfield goal in the 70th minute.  Liverpool had previously had disappointing results against Manchester United and Arsenal. The win against Newcastle was a much needed win for Liverpool.

Roma defeated Napoli 1-0 at home, ending a four-month winless streak at their stadium. Miralem Pjanic scored the lone goal in the 25th minute, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis had several key saves in the second half to secure the victory for Roma. The win moved Roma into second place, four points ahead of Lazio. Napoli remained in fifth place after extending their winless streak to five matches. Security was tight for the match, which was Napoli's first visit to Roma since a fan of the southern club died following a shooting before last season's Italian Cup final. There were no reports of problems, however. Roma was without injured captain Francesco Totti and fellow forward Gervinho.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played to a 0-0 draw in a League One match at the Keepmoat Stadium. The match was not exciting, and the Doncaster media team had a difficult time creating match highlights. The highlights video is only 27 seconds long, with 14 seconds of match action, including the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Ben Stokes is a fiery character in the England cricket team, who has had his share of ups and downs. He is a talented player but needs to be managed carefully so that his aggression does not get out of control. England want Stokes in the team as much as possible to help him reach his full potential. They believe he can be a valuable asset if he can control his aggression and channel it in the right way.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium at Cardiff City Stadium on June 12th has sold out of its 33,000 tickets.  Following Wales' 3-0 win against Israel, there has been increased hope that the team will qualify for the 2016 finals in France. Although there was speculation that the match would be held at the Millennium Stadium to accommodate more attendees, UEFA rules prevent changing the venue less than 120 days before the game. Additionally, the Welsh team prefers playing at Cardiff City Stadium.

England's U17 soccer team, coached by John Peacock, will be competing in the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The team, which won the tournament last year, will play its first match on May 7th against Italy. The team includes players from various Premier League clubs, including Chelsea, Arsenal, and Liverpool.  Notable additions to the team are Chris Willock who will be playing for the first time and Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold who are returning to the team after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers. England will also play Holland on May 10th and Ireland on May 13th.

Manchester City are interested in signing Evangelos Patoulidis, a 14-year-old Anderlecht player. The young midfielder is considered a top talent and has garnered interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. City have talked with Anderlecht's chairman in hopes of reaching a deal.  Previously, Patoulidis turned down Barcelona because his family prioritized his education.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico, was found dead in her Fulham flat at the end of March.  A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but was released on bail.  Police are asking anyone who may have had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward.

Dawn, a woman who had suffered seven miscarriages, was saving money for a gravestone for one of her babies. Her friend Jamie and his girlfriend Carol were living with Dawn and her partner (also named Jamie). Dawn accused Jamie of stealing £207 she had saved for the gravestone. After a lie detector test on the Jeremy Kyle show proved Jamie was lying, he confessed to stealing the money but blamed his girlfriend. Dawn was devastated by the betrayal.

More than 200 Yazidis, mainly women, children, and elderly, were released by ISIS after being held captive since the previous summer when ISIS attacked their towns in northern Iraq. Kurdish officials say Arab tribal leaders coordinated the release, but the exact reason for it is unclear. This is not the first time ISIS has released Yazidi captives; they have previously let go of scores of children and elderly people. The Yazidis are a minority group with an ancient religion that has faced long-standing persecution. Their capture and mistreatment by ISIS led to a humanitarian crisis, with many fleeing to the mountains or neighboring Syria and facing dire conditions. Some were killed, and there were reports of women being enslaved and raped. International efforts, including airstrikes and aid drops, have been made to combat ISIS and assist the Yazidis.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham player nominated for PFA Player and Young Player of the Season, is featured in a new animation showcasing his best goals and celebrations of the season. The video, produced by Copa90, uses still photographs to create an animated effect, including goals against Chelsea and Arsenal, and his England debut goal. The video is titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?' and was released before the awards ceremony where he is competing against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Despite a trophyless season and a likely finish outside the top four, Jamie Carragher believes that Brendan Rodgers is still the right person to manage Liverpool. Carragher feels that it is too soon to judge the new players and that the team needs to improve in the next season by winning a trophy and finishing in the top four. Carragher also received the Beacon Award for his community work with the 23 Foundation which provides coaching to underprivileged children in Merseyside.

Four-year-old James Hayward's toy Nerf gun was confiscated at East Midlands Airport because it was deemed a security risk.  His father, Phil Hayward, said the security check was "ludicrous" and "overzealous." East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience and stated that they offered to send the toy back to the family's home. They defended their actions by explaining that "no items may be permitted through security that resemble a prohibited item." The Department of Transport's prohibited list includes "replica or model guns."

A 31-year-old single man who lives in Humpty Doo in the Northern Territory posted an advertisement on Gumtree in search of a girlfriend or wife.  He describes himself as a white male, 175cm tall, athletic build with brown hair and brown eyes who is heavily tattooed, does not drink, smoke or do drugs. He owns property, makes great money, is successful, loves cars, bikes, the outdoors, sports, fishing, camping, and traveling. He is looking for a non-smoker and non-drinker who is fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, good with their hands, a good cook, and great in bed.  He is offering a free gym membership, phone, and possible company car, phone, and laptop. He states that all reasonable offers will be considered, but former partners need not apply.

FA chairman Greg Dyke's proposal to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from 8 to 12 and change the "home-grown" player requirements is facing opposition from the Premier League.  Five former England managers; Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson and Steve McClaren, support Dyke's proposal and warn that if it's blocked, it will be harder for England to win the World Cup. They highlight the shrinking pool of English talent playing at the top level as a disadvantage for England managers, despite the emergence of some promising young players like Barkley, Sterling, and Kane, who aren't given enough opportunity to play.

In the latest episode of Poldark, Demelza gives birth to her and Ross’s daughter, just one episode after announcing her pregnancy.  Ross, who married Demelza out of duty, now professes his love for her.  Fans noted the unrealistic timeline of the pregnancy, which progressed from announcement to eight months along, then to birth within a single episode, similar to Elizabeth’s pregnancy in a previous episode.

Leicester City, currently in last place, are only three points away from escaping relegation after two consecutive wins. Manager Nigel Pearson urges his team to concentrate on their upcoming match against Swansea and to disregard the performance of their relegation rivals. Pearson believes Leicester's destiny is in their own hands and that if they continue to play well, they will have a chance to avoid relegation on the final day of the season. Despite a recent improvement in form, Pearson cautions against excessive optimism and emphasizes the need for the team to maintain focus.

A gray whale named Varvara swam close to 14,000 miles from Russia to Mexico, setting a new record for the longest mammal migration. This journey may indicate that she is actually an eastern gray whale, not a western gray whale as previously thought. This could have implications for the estimated population of western gray whales, which is critically low.

On the eastern coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island, 1,000ft of seabed rose to the surface overnight near the town of Rausu. Geologists believe the cause is a nearby landslide, in which melting ice and snow caused a land section to drop, forcing the underwater area up. The new land mass measures 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, rising 30 to 50ft above sea level. Local residents reported no tremors or sounds overnight. Authorities do not expect the land mass to expand further and believe the incident is unrelated to earthquakes.

Gregory van der Wiel, despite a recent disagreement with Paris Saint-Germain manager Laurent Blanc, has stated that he is happy at the club and has no plans to leave. He expressed his love for the club, city, and teammates, and his desire to sign a new contract. While PSG is reportedly interested in signing Dani Alves, Van der Wiel maintains that he is ready to play whenever called upon.

Carlos Tevez, who is currently under contract with Juventus until the end of next season, has expressed his desire to leave the club this summer to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Boca Juniors have confirmed they are in the process of completing a deal with the 31-year-old, but he must first terminate his current contract with Juventus. Although Juventus is reluctant to lose their top scorer, who has netted 17 times this season, they have accepted that he wants to leave and have started to search for potential replacements. Tevez’s international manager, Tata Martino, has stated that a potential move would not affect the player’s future with the Argentinan national team.

During Bayern Munich's 6-1 Champions League quarter-final win over FC Porto, Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola ripped his trousers in excitement. The win secured Bayern Munich a place in the Champions League semi-finals.

On Wednesday afternoon, a three-car collision occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale, west of Brisbane, involving 10 people, including four children. Two adults and two children were airlifted to the Princess Alexandra Hospital with chest, shoulder, arm, and abdominal injuries. Six others, including three children, were transported to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. One person was trapped in their vehicle and had to be freed by emergency crews. The highway was temporarily closed with diversions in place.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil showed off his new Apple Watch on social media, comparing it to a gadget from the TV show Knight Rider. Ozil is expected to start in the crucial match against league leaders Chelsea. Meanwhile, Arsenal legend Ray Parlour believes that Jack Wilshere's fitness is the only thing holding him back from reaching his full potential. Wilshere recently returned from a five-month injury layoff.

Mark Clattenburg will referee the Manchester derby on Sunday despite having sent off three players from the two teams this season. City captain Vincent Kompany was sent off in an international match and is suspended for the match against Wales in June.  Clattenburg has only sent off two players in the Premier League this season, both from Manchester United. The Manchester derby could determine which team finishes second in the Premier League.

Bob Katter, a federal MP, accused the Queensland government of treating Billy Gordon, an independent MP, like a "black puppet." He believes that the government assumed Mr. Gordon would resign after accusations of domestic violence and a criminal past were made public because of his race. These accusations sparked criticism, but Mr. Katter defended his statement, citing his own experiences with racism. He used the term "black puppet" to highlight what he perceives as racial bias from the government, referencing other MPs who became puppets for the government after becoming independent but stating that Mr. Gordon would not follow the same path.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old with cerebral palsy, is challenging the way people with disabilities are viewed. Through her inspirational dance videos, she aims to counteract stereotypes and demonstrate that she is just like everyone else. Dayna's videos highlight her ability to dance, drive, and attend college, defying the limitations often associated with cerebral palsy. She hopes to inspire others and encourage people to look beyond her disability.

Orlando City is the latest club to express interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez. Hernandez has also garnered interest from eight other European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United has offered a revised contract to Andreas Pereira, who has also received interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

At a South Los Angeles gas station, a driver got into a dispute with a group of at least three people. The suspects then doused the driver's car with gasoline and set it on fire while two passengers were still inside. Although no one was hurt, the car was significantly damaged. Authorities are investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects are still at large. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is utilizing surveillance footage to aid in their investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor in Iowa, surrendered his license after admitting to exchanging services for sex with patients and performing exorcisms.  In addition to these practices, he also advised patients to stop taking prescribed medications. Despite these actions, Manuel received positive patient satisfaction reviews online. He cannot reapply for his license for at least 10 years and must prove the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker over the Baltic Sea. The U.S. deemed the Russian pilot's actions unsafe due to aggressive maneuvers and close proximity. Russia stated the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder off, a claim the U.S. denies. The U.S. will file a complaint with Russia through diplomatic channels. Similar incidents between U.S. and Russian aircraft have occurred in the past.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of a Salt Lake City hotel where he was staying. The rifle was in a locked case that was secured to the vehicle. Police believe the thief broke the car window and used a rope and another vehicle to rip the rifle case from its secured location. The theft occurred just days before President Obama visited the city, and the Secret Service was notified. The rifle has not been recovered.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in Canberra in July 2012. A forensic psychiatrist, Professor Paul Mullen, testified that Costa was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse, leading to a confused mental state at the time of the murder. Evidence, such as Costa's fluctuating mood during the incident and a trail of feces, supports this claim. Costa's mental state is critical to the case, as it could lead to a not guilty verdict if proven unstable at the time of the attack.

In Everton’s 1-0 win against Burnley, Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley’s missed penalty kick. Barkley took the penalty instead of Leighton Baines, who usually takes penalty kicks for Everton and has a near-perfect record. Martinez insisted that it was Barkley’s right to take the penalty and that Baines was fine with it. Although Barkley missed, Everton went on to win the game after a goal by Kevin Mirallas.

Two passengers were found dead on a Holland America Line cruise ship, ms Ryndam, in Puerto Rico. The cruise line believes the deaths to be a murder-suicide. The FBI is investigating the deaths after being notified by the cruise line. The ship left Tampa, Florida on March 29th and was in San Juan, Puerto Rico at the time of the deaths. The passengers were found by cleaning staff.

Curacao, coached by Patrick Kluivert, has advanced to the second round of CONCACAF qualifying for the 2018 World Cup. Curacao drew 2-2 with Montserrat in the second leg to win 4-3 on aggregate. They will face Cuba in the next round.

Esteban Cambiasso, who has had an illustrious career winning many European competitions, says that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be like winning another trophy. Leicester City is currently in last place and has not won a game since January. Cambiasso believes that Leicester City still has a chance to stay in the Premier League, and he is happy playing for Leicester City.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two, has relinquished the care of her children to her own mother, Debbie. Debbie has threatened to prevent Gemma from seeing her children due to Gemma's partying, drug use, and theft. Debbie asserts that Gemma is an unfit mother who prioritizes her social life over her children's needs. As a result, Debbie has raised the children, who now refer to her as "mum."

Chelsea defeated Manchester United 1-0 after Eden Hazard scored a goal following a strong challenge by John Terry on Radamel Falcao, which the Sky Sports punditry team, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, agreed should have been called a foul. The challenge involved Terry coming in from behind and potentially striking Falcao in the back of the head with his elbow, causing him to fall and lose the ball. Despite acknowledging that Falcao could have been stronger, the pundits felt that Terry's actions warranted a foul.

Hillary Scott, a singer in the band Lady Antebellum, was on a tour bus that caught fire after a tire blew out on a Texas freeway. Everyone on board was able to safely evacuate, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver. The fire destroyed everything in the back lounge of the bus except for Scott's Bible. The other two band members were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is still scheduled to perform at the Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, of Dundee University, is working on a project that would use lasers in space to convert sunlight into energy that can be beamed to Earth. The process involves satellites orbiting Earth, covered in mirrors to collect sunlight and convert it into laser light, which is then converted into energy using semiconductors and sent back to Earth. This technology could potentially make solar power viable in areas with less sunlight and could be used to provide power to disaster-stricken areas. While the lasers would not be powerful enough to be used as weapons, concerns have been raised about who would control the satellites. The project has seen initial success in Scotland and may move to Portugal for further trials.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted pedophile, escaped from a psychiatric facility near Hook, Hampshire. He was last seen leaving the hospital at 6:15 pm on Tuesday. Police describe him as 5'8" tall, heavyset, with dark hair, and may have shaved his beard. Munden was committed to the facility after being convicted of sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He also has a history of possessing indecent images of children. Police are urging anyone with information about his whereabouts to come forward.

V. Stiviano was sued by Rochelle Sterling for receiving expensive gifts, including cars and a duplex, from Rochelle's husband, Donald Sterling. Donald Sterling's wife won the lawsuit and Stiviano was ordered by a judge to return over $2.6 million in gifts. The lawsuit stemmed from the controversy surrounding Donald Sterling's racist remarks that were caught on an audio recording, ultimately leading to his ban from the NBA and the forced sale of his team, the Los Angeles Clippers.

Thierry Henry believes Arsenal need to purchase four top players (a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder and striker) in order to win the Barclays Premier League title. He feels that Olivier Giroud is not a top, top quality striker and that Arsenal need a player of that caliber to win the league. He cites Chelsea's purchases of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa as an example of how key purchases can change a team's ability to win the league.

Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. One of his victims spoke to the court about how his abuse had impacted her life. She did not understand it was wrong when she was abused and did not speak up until she learned he had been caught. She has since attempted suicide and is scared for her future relationships. The victim also suffers from depression and has been hospitalized for self-harm. Van Ryn is in custody and the hearing continues.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is nearing a return after a year out due to a serious knee injury. He last played for Arsenal's first team in March 2014 but recently played two full 90-minute matches with the Arsenal Under 21s. Gnabry says he is feeling better and is looking forward to playing again.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling from a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales. After a night out with friends, he and his friends took a taxi but didn't have enough money for the fare. They planned to trick the driver, and Mr. Phillips ran away into the darkness. He accidentally fell off the cliff, which was located at the end of the disused Northern Promenade. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death.

Thousands of travelers affected by significant passport delays in the summer of 2014 did not receive compensation, despite the passport agency generating a £42 million profit and awarding bonuses to managers.  The agency received 2,191 compensation applications, approving a total payout of £203,066, averaging £92.68 per claim. Ministers rejected a blanket refund for affected travelers, citing the creation of a precedent.  Many individuals, like Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham, lost substantial sums of money on trips due to delayed passports, despite applying well in advance and paying for expedited services. The passport office's surplus and manager bonuses during this period fueled further criticism.

A three-bedroom semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, untouched since the 1930s, is going up for auction with an estimated price of £200,000-£250,000. The house features many original details, including stained-glass windows, the original mint green and black bathroom, a 1930s kitchen, and even vintage food tins. While some modern upgrades like double glazing have been added, the extensive renovations needed might deter developers. The auction will take place on April 30th at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his career as a backup quarterback, but became the starter for the 49ers in 2012 after the starting quarterback was injured. He led the team to the Super Bowl that season, where they lost to the Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

- Anne Rice was born in New Orleans.
- Route 495 is a freeway in New Jersey that connects a highway to a New York route that provides access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo, pronounced teleˈmundo, is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal's NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in East London and Essex, formed the band Blur with Graham Coxon. Blur released their debut album *Leisure* in 1991.  Albarn's debut solo album *Everyday Robots* was released in 2014. It was co-produced by Richard Russell and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It houses many of Somalia's important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by Nine Inch Nails from their debut EP, *Broken*, which was released in 1992. The song falls into the industrial rock genre.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter nominated for a BAFTA award. He was born on August 14, 1964.

**Film (2007)**

* **Main character:** Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran played by Mark Wahlberg.
* **Plot:** Swagger is framed for murder by a secret military company.

**TV series**

* **Main character:** Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman played by Ryan Phillippe.
* **Plot:** Swagger is living in exile and returns to action to stop a plot against the president. 

**In essence:** Both the film and TV series feature the character Bob Lee Swagger, a skilled marksman who gets caught up in conspiracies. The film focuses on a framed murder, while the TV series revolves around an assassination plot against the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including Sharon Tate, carried out by members of his group. He was also convicted of the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea.  After he was charged, recordings of his music were commercially released.

Sean Penn is an American actor and filmmaker who began his career with a television appearance in 1974. Following diverse roles throughout the 1980s, Penn received critical acclaim for his roles in the crime dramas At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito's Way. His prominence as a leading actor was solidified with Dead Man Walking (earning him his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival). Penn later received two more Oscar nominations before winning Best Actor awards in 2003 and 2008 for his roles in Mystic River and Milk, respectively.

Sir Donald George Bradman, also known as "The Don", was an Australian cricketer considered the greatest batsman of all time.  After retiring, he continued to heavily influence the game as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid worked as the chairman and CEO of Epic Records, which is owned by Sony Music Entertainment. He was also the president and CEO of Arista Records, in addition to being the chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer, best known for playing in the bands Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. He started his career in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, he has also played in the band Prophets of Rage. Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984.

*   **Show Title:** The Millers
*   **Format:** Multi-camera series
*   **Air Dates:** October 3, 2013 - July 18, 2015
*   **Number of Episodes:** 34 (2 seasons)
*   **Network:** CBS
*   **Cancellation Announcement:** November 14, 2014 (during season 2)

Ann Richards was the 45th Governor of Texas, serving from 1991-1995.  She was the second female governor of the state. In 1994, she lost her re-election bid to George W. Bush.  Richards was well-known for her outspoken feminism and memorable quotes.  There was also a jazz singer with the same name, who was married to the pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell independently released an EP called *A Reminder* in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who was born on July 6, 1927, and died on October 3, 2004. She wrote four books, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar was a Venezuelan military and political leader who was instrumental in the establishment of six sovereign nations that were formerly under Spanish rule.  These six nations are: Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama. He is known as "El Libertador".

The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil's Triangle, is located in the western North Atlantic Ocean. It's said that a number of aircraft and ships have disappeared there under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick started out as a backup quarterback for the 49ers, but became the starter midway through the 2012 season after the starting quarterback was injured. He led the team to the Super Bowl that season, and the NFC Championship the following season.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a type of marketing that uses sponsored, non-personal messages to promote products, services, or ideas. Unlike personal selling, advertising is not directed at a specific person. It uses mass media channels like newspapers, TV, and websites to reach a broad audience.
*Private Lives*, originally a 1930 comedy of manners play in three acts by Noël Coward, was later adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Harold Macmillan was a British Conservative politician who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from January 10, 1957 to October 19, 1963.

Aristotle was a Greek philosopher and scientist who lived from 384 to 322 BC. He studied at Plato's Academy in Athens from age 17/18 to 37. After Plato's death, he left Athens and tutored Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Packouz is a former arms dealer who transitioned to becoming a musician, inventor, and entrepreneur.  He is known for inventing the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is the CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons.  In his rookie season, he won a championship and was named the NBA Finals Most Valuable Player.  He won four more championships with the Lakers in the 1980s and retired in 1992 after contracting HIV, but returned in 1996 to play 32 more games before retiring for good.  Johnson was named by Ebony magazine as one of America's most influential black businessmen in 2009 and was a part-owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D, a comedy rock duo from Los Angeles, was formed in 1994 by Jack Black and Kyle Gass. The band has released 3 albums and gained popularity through their television series in 1997, after which they began opening for larger bands.

James VI of Scotland and James I of England reigned over Scotland and England during his lifetime. Though both were ruled by James, the kingdoms remained separate states with their own parliaments and laws. James advocated for a single parliament but faced difficulties in England, including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 and conflicts with Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley, is the 18th season of the British reality television show Big Brother. Marcus Bentley is a British actor and voice-over artist best known for narrating the UK's Big Brother since it began in 2000. He is one of Britain's most recognizable voices due to his voice-over work and Geordie accent.

Saxony is a German state that borders Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It's the tenth largest state by area and the sixth most populous. Located in a formerly all German-speaking part of Europe, Saxony has a history spanning over 1,000 years. It is also a quality wine region in Germany, and one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe. It's one of only two wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park was a major league baseball park in Cincinnati, Ohio. "In the End" is a song by Linkin Park, an American rock band.
Mel B launched her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra, a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah, was the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year. Raveena Tandon replaced Divya Bharti, who died during filming. The film's soundtrack was highly successful.
"Hourglass" is a song by British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is also the title of the fourteenth studio album by singer-songwriter James Taylor.
Shane Black is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor best known for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and directing the 2005 film Kiss Kiss Bang Bang.
A View to a Kill, a 1985 film, is the 14th movie in the James Bond series and the last to feature Roger Moore as James Bond. It is also the 7th Bond film starring Moore.

Papua, the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, is located on the western side of New Guinea. It was previously referred to as Irian Jaya and, before that, West Irian or Irian Barat, encompassing all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though rumors circulated that his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez debuted in the music industry in 1999 and simultaneously released her second album, J.Lo, and her film, The Wedding Planner, in 2001, making her the first woman to have a number one album and film in the same week. After her second divorce and a high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck, she rebounded with the box office success Shall We Dance? before giving birth to twins in 2008. Following a relatively unsuccessful period, she returned to prominence in 2011 as a judge on American Idol and with her most commercially successful single to date, "On the Floor".

Working animals are typically domesticated and trained by humans to perform specific tasks.  These tasks can range from close companionship, such as guide dogs, to providing physical labor like draft horses. In rare cases, wild animals can be trained, but they are mainly used for entertainment due to their unpredictable nature, unlike domesticated animals that are known for their reliability and gentle temperament.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. Billboard magazine publishes the Top Latin Albums chart, which ranks Spanish-language albums in the US. Billboard also publishes a weekly chart called Regional Mexican Albums which ranks albums in the Regional Mexican music genre.

Vedam, a 2010 Telugu-language Indian drama film, was written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi. The film stars Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.
Men in Black II (MIIB), a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film, stars Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character in the novel Don Quixote by Miguel de Cervantes. He is Don Quixote's squire and is known for his "sanchismos".  Sanchismos are a combination of humor, Spanish proverbs, and wit.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash, a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film, stars Eddie Murphy in a dual role and is directed by Ron Underwood.
The world premiere of Hedda Gabler, written by Ibsen, took place on January 31, 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Ibsen in attendance.
Brazzers is a pornography production company located in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A. (commonly called Juve) is a professional Italian association football club in Turin. Founded in 1897, it is the second oldest active Italian football club. Its home matches are played in the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium, and the team traditionally wears a black and white striped uniform.

Viola Davis had several supporting and minor roles in film and television in the late 1990s and early 2000s. Some of her work includes roles in the films Kate & Leopold and Far From Heaven, and the television series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson, born in 1974, is an American entrepreneur and former pornographic film actress known as the world's most famous adult entertainer.  She began her career in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamour model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a team in the NBA's Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was a professional wrestling event held annually by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW) from 1983-2000 originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually pay-per-view. It was tradition for JCP to hold major wrestling events on Thanksgiving and Christmas. Starrcade (1985) was the third annual event, Starrcade (1987) was the fifth annual event, and Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual event.
Jack Ryan Falahee is an American actor known for his roles as Connor Walsh in the ABC legal drama *How to Get Away with Murder* and Benjamin Stringfellow in the PBS historical drama *Mercy Street*.

Seohyun, a South Korean singer and actress, debuted as a solo artist with her mini album *Don't Say No* on January 17, 2017, making her the third member of the girl group Girls' Generation to do so. She is also known for her roles in musicals such as *Moon Embracing the Sun*, *Gone with the Wind*, and *Mamma Mia*.

The Apple II, designed by Steve Wozniak, was one of the first successful mass-produced microcomputers.  Jobs oversaw the case design and Holt developed the power supply. It was introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer.

A&E, formerly Arts & Entertainment Network, is an American cable and satellite television channel owned by A&E Networks. A&E Networks is a joint venture equally owned by Hearst Corporation and Disney-ABC Television Group, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company.

L.A. Reid was the chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group. He also founded and served as CEO of Hitco Music Publishing and co-founded LaFace Records.

Veeram is the title of two Indian films: a 2014 Tamil action film, and a 2016 historical drama. Both films were Indian productions. The 2014 film was directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, while the 2016 film was written and directed by Jayaraj.

Home for the Holidays is the name of two American films. One is a 1972 made-for-television horror film, and the other is a 1995 film. The 1972 film was directed by John Llewellyn Moxey and stars Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan. The 1995 film stars Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Killam is an American actor, comedian, and writer born on April 1, 1982.
The Sex Factor, produced by xHamster, is an online reality TV series where 8 men and 8 women compete to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan, born on July 15, 1973, is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer.
Island Records is a British-American record label that is part of Universal Music Group.
Sikkim is a state in northeast India.
Christa McAuliffe became a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.
Ron Weasley is a fictional character in the Harry Potter book series written by J.K. Rowling.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder and produced by Jack Binder. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures and released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick, born November 3, 1987, is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent.

**Sheryl Lee**

* Starred in *Café Society* (2016).
* Reprised her role as Laura Palmer in the *Twin Peaks* revival (2017).

**Sheryl Lee Ralph**

* Played Madame Morrible in the Broadway production of *Wicked* (2016).
Matteo Renzi was the Prime Minister of Italy from February 2014 until December 2016. He was born on January 11, 1975.
"The Road to El Dorado" is an animated movie featuring the voices of Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

"Same Old Love", a song by Selena Gomez, was released in 2015 as part of her second studio album, Revival. This album was a success, debuting at the top of the Billboard 200 chart. The album's first three singles, including "Same Old Love", reached the top of the US Mainstream Top 40 chart.
Weekly Idol is a South Korean variety show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal, or metal, is a genre of rock music that originated in the late 1960s and early 1970s in the UK and US.  During the late 1970s, new wave British heavy metal bands such as Iron Maiden and Saxon continued the genre's evolution.
Ashton Kutcher starred in several romantic comedies after his initial success, including Guess Who, A Lot Like Love, What Happens in Vegas, and No Strings Attached.
Topman is a men's clothing store chain owned by Arcadia Group with locations throughout the UK and Ireland.

During the Industrial Revolution, Wales's economy transitioned from agriculture to industry due to growth in mining and metallurgy. This shift, particularly the South Wales Coalfield's development, led to a population boom.
Tool is a band that has won three Grammy awards, had several albums top the charts in multiple countries, and performed worldwide tours.
YouTube is an American video-sharing website headquartered in San Bruno, California, and is ranked as the second most popular website globally, according to Alexa Internet.
Sidse Babett Knudsen, born on November 22, 1968, is a Danish actress who performs in theater, television, and film.

Conrad Dunn's first significant film role was as Francis "Psycho" Soyer in the 1981 movie *Stripes*. This movie also launched the careers of several other actors, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, and Judge Reinhold.
Raees is a film starring Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
Asylum Records is a US-based record label that was started in 1971 by David Geffen and Elliot Roberts.
Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series on Netflix created by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

The Armenian Genocide was the systematic killing of 1.5 million Armenians by the Ottoman government within the Ottoman Empire and the Republic of Turkey. Other groups, including Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks, were also killed by the Ottoman government in what some historians consider part of the same genocidal policy.
Marcus Morgan Bentley is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist born on October 4, 1967.
Bill Clinton, born on August 19, 1946, was the 42nd President of the United States, serving from 1993-2001.  His first inauguration was held in Washington D.C. on January 20, 1993.
Danny Boyle is a film director, producer, screenwriter, and theater director. One of his films, The Beach, was released in 2000. It is an adventure drama based on a novel of the same name.
The dress went viral online, sparking debate about its true colors, illustrated by the use of hashtags like #whiteandgold and #blackandblue.
Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand MC and bar (22 January 1917–11 June 2006) was a British Army officer.
Advertising is a sponsored, non-personal message that uses audio or visual media to promote or sell a product, service, or idea.

"The Others" (2001), an English-language film, won eight Goya Awards, including Best Film and Best Director. It was the first English-language film to win Best Film at the Goyas, despite having no Spanish dialogue. Additionally, it received six Saturn Award nominations, winning three for Best Horror Film, Best Actress (Nicole Kidman), and Best Supporting Actress (Fionnula Flanagan).
Ralph Fults was an outlaw and escape artist during the Depression era. He was associated with outlaws Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow.

The 14th Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, was born in Tibet in 1935 and formally recognized as the Dalai Lama in 1939. Following the 1959 Tibetan uprising, he fled to India and currently lives there as a refugee.

During World War II, four members of the 92nd Infantry Division, known as Buffalo Soldiers, find shelter in a Tuscan village after seeking refuge. The film, which is set in German-occupied Italy, portrays the connection they establish with the villagers. Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who has also written weekly columns for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who has also done voice work including: narrating commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the Valencian Community in Spain and is the third most populous city proper in Spain, with a population of roughly 800,000. The Valencian Community is also the third largest metropolitan area in Spain, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers is a fictional character who was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the Buffy the Vampire Slayer movie and Sarah Michelle Gellar in the Buffy the Vampire Slayer television series.
The TV series "Make It or Break It" ended after its third season, with the series finale airing on May 14, 2012. The announcement of the show's ending was made on April 26, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR), an interdisciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics, uses methodologies and technologies to recognize and translate spoken language into text by computers, incorporating knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.  Applications include voice user interfaces like voice dialing, call routing, appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft direct voice input. Industry adoption of deep learning methods in designing and deploying speech recognition systems has led to major advances, with companies like Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC publicizing the use of deep learning as core technology in their systems.
Richard Alf, an American businessman, co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International, formerly known as the Golden State Comic Book Convention, and served as its chairman starting in 1970.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film, Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par. McIlroy shot a 67 and is one stroke behind the leaders at 15 under par, tied with Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy is looking for his first win since May and believes he can shoot a low round. After a slow start, McIlroy eagled the 13th hole and is in contention for the win. This is McIlroy's first tournament win since returning from an ankle injury in July. He is also looking to win his third Race to Dubai title in four years. England's Chris Wood and Richard Bland are currently in fifth and seventh place, respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of al-Wefaq, believes that dialogue is crucial for Bahrain's future but the government must offer concrete solutions.  Many young protestors have lost faith in the main opposition parties, but Sheikh Salman believes working with reformists within the royal family, like the Crown Prince, is the way forward.  He recalled a seven-point plan agreed upon with the Crown Prince in 2011 that was abandoned when GCC troops entered Bahrain.  Sheikh Salman hopes the new US Secretary of State, John Kerry, will take a stronger stance on human rights and democratic practices in Bahrain.  He urged the UK government to publicly pressure Bahrain for reform, stating that private conversations have been ineffective.  Sheikh Salman confirmed al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations and demanded the release of 13 imprisoned opposition leaders and activists, whose inclusion he deems vital for successful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a period of illness.  Hogwood's legacy includes founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading them for 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, notably the complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments.  His 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah remains a landmark achievement.  Hogwood's influence extended through his work with leading orchestras globally, and his academic roles at prestigious universities like Cambridge, Harvard, and Cornell.  His colleagues remember him for his generosity, his significant contribution to historically informed music, and his lasting impact on the AAM and the broader musical landscape.

In 2015-16, Scotland had 57 homicide victims, the lowest in 40 years, with only one case unresolved. Sharp instruments, mostly knives, were the most common murder weapons.  Although most accused had unknown alcohol/drug status, 31% were under the influence. While the Justice Secretary highlighted the positive trend, he stressed the need for continued efforts in education and enforcement to tackle violence. The Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman urged caution, noting previous revisions to homicide figures and a rise in other violent crimes like sexual offenses and attempted murders.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, who had previously not won a game in the Premier League this season. Bournemouth's goal was their first in three games, but despite creating many chances in the match, they were unable to score more than once and lost the game. Their manager, Eddie Howe, believes a lack of confidence is not the issue, highlighting the number of chances created by the team.

-Australia's policy is to detain migrants who arrive by boat and send them to offshore processing camps where they await resettlement elsewhere.
-The New York Times criticized Australia's immigration policy, deeming it inhumane and potentially illegal, contrasting it with Australia's historical acceptance of refugees.
-The newspaper cautioned European leaders against replicating Australia's approach.
-In response to the migrant crisis, Mr. Abbott maintained that the only way to prevent deaths at sea is to stop the boats, highlighting Australia's success in doing so.
-Mr. Abbott's comparison of IS to the Nazis, stating that IS boasts about its evil unlike the Nazis, drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups who emphasized the distinction between terrorism and state-sponsored genocide.
-Despite the criticism, Mr. Abbott stood by his comments but clarified that he wasn't trying to rank evil.

The US has ceased bilateral talks with Russia aimed at sustaining a ceasefire in Syria, citing Russia's failure to uphold its commitments and its continued bombing of Aleppo alongside Syrian government forces. Russia expressed regret over the US decision, accusing the US of shifting blame and not fulfilling its own obligations regarding the humanitarian situation in Aleppo. Despite halting bilateral talks on the ceasefire, the US and Russia will continue discussions concerning counter-terrorism operations in Syria.

Policy Exchange, a think tank, suggests selling high-value social housing to fund new social housing construction, potentially creating the largest program since the 1970s. They argue that this could raise £4.5 billion annually, enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 new homes, and reduce the social housing waiting list. While Downing Street supports the idea, Labour opposes it, arguing that it would displace low-wage families and create segregated communities. They propose alternative solutions like a bank bonus tax to fund affordable housing and boost the construction industry. The debate highlights the tension between utilizing existing resources efficiently and ensuring fair access to housing for all, particularly in expensive areas.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, of Swansea, died and measles was confirmed after his death, though it has not been confirmed as the cause.  An inquest will be opened to investigate further. He had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash shortly after. His mother stated he saw a GP about the rash and was found dead the next morning. The family is unsure how he contracted measles.
Vincent Hudson, 54, from Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offense against a boy under 16 that allegedly occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear in court.

Gateshead and Guiseley tied 1-1. Guiseley scored first, with Jake Lawlor scoring in the first half. Gateshead tied in the second half with a goal by Wes York. The game ended with substitutions for both teams.

Bristol Sport Ltd, owner of Bristol City Football Club, plans to increase stadium capacity by replacing two stands. This plan will proceed if a judicial review requested in response to the city council's November approval is not granted by March. Construction would begin in May. The club previously proposed building a new stadium but was delayed due to an application for a town green.

Cuadrilla, a company conducting shale gas drilling (fracking) in Lancashire, has suspended operations after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The tremor was similar in location and mechanism to one in April, according to the British Geological Survey (BGS). Cuadrilla will analyze data and consult with experts before resuming operations. Fracking involves injecting pressurized water into rocks to release gas, which can cause earthquakes. The BGS is monitoring the situation and noted that the April tremor occurred 2km from the drilling site. They confirmed that the recent tremor likely shared the same location and mechanism as the one in April.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud when he played his bagpipes in April 2015 with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner draped on them, which made it appear that the money he collected was for the charity. He was cleared of two other counts.
