Though the chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign had given Carpenter permission to display the banner, he had not given him permission to use it to collect funds. Carpenter claimed that the banner was a tribute to the victims and that he was simply busking as usual. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town secured a 3-0 victory over Queens Park Rangers. Goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence sealed the win for Ipswich. QPR struggled offensively, with their best chance being a header from Sandro that hit the post. The win moved Ipswich up to 14th in the Championship standings, while QPR dropped to 15th. 

Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance, highlighting the contributions of Luke Varney and Jonathan Douglas. QPR boss Ian Holloway expressed disappointment with his team's mental toughness and defensive errors, particularly goalkeeper Alex Smithies' role in the second goal.

Luke Wells had a successful T20 Blast season, scoring 373 runs at a strike rate of 138.66. Wells is excited about the direction of the club, citing the coaches' creation of a high-performance environment.

The Red Ruggers, currently ranked 5th in National Two South, defeated the 3rd ranked Chinnor team.  Their coach, Churcher, credits the win to the strong defensive play of the front row, specifically Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams.  The Reds have a favorable schedule ahead and Churcher believes the team can continue to improve on their recent success.

Nazrul, a 28-year-old Bangladeshi man, was arrested in Kolkata for the alleged rape of a 74-year-old nun. This is the sixth arrest in the case, which sparked outrage and protests across India. Police have identified eight suspects, with two still at large. Nazrul was identified by the five previously arrested suspects as the rapist. He had fled to Bangladesh but was apprehended upon his return to Kolkata based on a tip-off. The attack involved a group of eight who ransacked the convent, stole money, and raped a nun.

The interactive video discusses the reasons behind changes in consumer purchasing habits in the UK. Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, highlights the impact of new technologies (like freezers), products (like washing powder), and cheaper imports on consumer choices. The video also explores shifts in brand ownership and popularity, specifically examining the growing influence of Chinese ownership and the annual ranking of top UK consumer brands.

Two incidents of fraud occurred in the Dumfries and Galloway region. In both cases, scammers contacted women claiming to be BT employees and offering to fix internet issues. They gained remote access to the victims' computers and stole substantial sums of money. Police warn against granting remote access or sharing banking details over the phone, emphasizing that legitimate organizations never solicit such information.

John Duffy, 37, has left Swinton Lions to become head coach of Featherstone Rovers. He replaces outgoing coach Jon Sharp, who left the club in August, and has signed a one-year contract with the Championship side. Duffy will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday before the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. His former assistant Stuart Littler will replace him at Swinton.

At 12:50 GMT on Sunday, a Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded to an incident at Sker Beach where a horseback rider was found unconscious with head injuries. The rider was treated at the scene and flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to allocate radio frequencies for a global flight tracking system, enabling real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide via satellite. This decision was made in response to the disappearance of MH370, which highlighted the inadequacy of the existing ground-based radar system that leaves about 70% of global airspace uncovered. The new system will utilize automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) technology, with the UN's aviation arm, ICAO, setting a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft transmitting their position at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez went missing at age 5 when his father, Bobby Hernandez, took him from preschool in 2002 and fled.  He was found 13 years later at age 18 living with his father in Cleveland, Ohio after the FBI received an anonymous tip. Bobby Hernandez was arrested and is being held on $250,000 bail.  His mother has been notified.

A large fire occurred at a waste site in Duncan Street on March 2nd, causing travel disruptions. Following this, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended the site's operator, Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, from receiving waste and revoked their environmental permit, effective August 7th.  While the fire service found the site to be generally compliant with fire safety laws, they had expressed concerns to the EA in February about the potential impact of a fire on the surrounding area. The EA and fire service conducted joint visits, leading to the EA's decision. The company must remove all waste from the site. The cause of the fire is still unknown.

Due to the ongoing crisis in Ukraine, which has heightened pro-Russian and separatist sentiments in the Crimean region, Russia's Duma is reviewing two bills proposed by the pro-Kremlin party, A Just Russia. These bills aim to simplify the process by which Russia can annex a territory and expedite the issuance of Russian passports, particularly to Ukrainians. The proposed annexation law would remove the requirement for a treaty with a neighboring state if that state is in turmoil, while the proposed passport law would waive fees, residency requirements, and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship for applicants. These measures are seen as a way for Russia to exert influence and potentially incorporate territories with strong pro-Russian leanings, like Crimea, into the Russian Federation.

McLaren, a once-dominant Formula 1 team with a rich history of championships, has been in a slump since 2013. Despite having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Jenson Button, and a strong chassis, their Honda engine has been underperforming. This partnership with Honda, which brought them great success in the past, is now a source of difficulty. McLaren's history has been cyclical, with periods of dominance followed by decline. The team is currently hoping to arrest the slide and return to its winning ways, with Ron Dennis back at the helm and Alonso's return to the team. They believe a competitive car and an improved Honda engine will bring them success in the near future, but for now, belief is all they have to rely on.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was shot in the head and chest outside Phoenix Gym at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27th. He later died in hospital. Police have arrested three men in connection with the crime and are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene. Detectives believe the suspects waited outside the gym for about an hour before the shooting and are asking anyone with information to come forward.

This article explores five ways people are using the internet to engage with Christianity during the Christmas season. These include: 

1.  **Online church services:** Everyday Church Online offers virtual services and a chat room for a global congregation.
2.  **Faith-based video games:** Guardians of Ancora is a free game for children that teaches Bible stories through quests.
3.  **Viral nativity videos:** Companies like Viral.de and the Churches Advertising Network have created modern interpretations of the nativity story using social media and video platforms.
4.  **Manga Bible stories:** Next Manga has released digital versions of its Manga Bible adaptations, including the nativity story, and distributed them to refugees.
5.  **Social media engagement:** Christian groups utilize platforms like Facebook and Twitter to share spiritual messages and connect with their communities.

The article highlights how technology is being used to make religious content more accessible and engaging for a wider audience, particularly during the Christmas season. It also touches upon the debate surrounding the appropriateness of religious advertising in mainstream media.

The proposed plan to build a racetrack in Ebbw Vale has been met with scrutiny regarding its impact on the environment. The developers have offered more land in exchange for building on the common land, but experts disagree on whether the replacement land is of equal value. The developers claim there would be a net gain in biodiversity, while the Gwent wildlife trust disagrees. The final decision on the plan rests with the Welsh government ministers.

Following a report in the Novaya Gazeta that over 100 suspected homosexuals had been detained in Chechnya, with at least three killed, Chechen Muslim clerics responded by calling for retribution against those who insult their faith and the dignity of Chechen men. The paper urged Russian authorities to prevent actions inciting hatred and enmity towards journalists. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, with his spokesman stating there are no gay people in Chechnya. However, the LGBT Network confirmed the report and stated that detainees were tortured. The paper's editor, Dmitry Muratov, stated that they did not intend to insult the Chechen people and would continue investigating human rights abuses. The LGBT Network is assisting people in fleeing persecution and may file a case with the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute those responsible.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, are both owned by the same person and operate out of the same building. Fresh Start Housing refers homeless clients to Investing Solutions, who house them in properties and charge the government housing benefits per person, rather than per property. This practice, while legal, has been called a "new low" by a homeless advocacy group. Investing Solutions says most of the housing benefit money goes to the landlords, but in one example, the agency made an annual profit of £11,568 from a single property. One former tenant described the properties he was placed in as "wholly unsuitable." Fresh Start Housing says it has housed hundreds of homeless people, but would not disclose how many were housed through Investing Solutions. Wandsworth Council, which has paid Investing Solutions over £2.1 million in housing benefits, says it has a team to ensure housing is safe and affordable. The Department for Communities and Local Government says local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayer money.

Great Britain lost their final warm-up game 78-72 against the Netherlands despite leading for the majority of the first three quarters. GB's top scorers were Andrew Lawrence (14 points) and Ben Gordon (13 points). Coach Joe Prunty believes the team needs to play hard for the entire game if they want to be successful in the upcoming Eurobasket qualifiers which begin midweek in Hungary. The Netherlands were led by Worthy De Jong who scored 18 points.

Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather have both requested to use 8 ounce gloves instead of the regulation 10 ounce gloves for their upcoming fight. The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) will publicly debate the matter on August 16th and announce their decision before the fight which is scheduled for August 26th.  Typically, 10 ounce gloves are required for fights above 135 pounds, however if both fighters agree, and the commission approves, 8 ounce gloves may be used in fights between 135-147 pounds. The fight between Mayweather and McGregor is scheduled to take place at 154 pounds, which is 7 pounds above the weight limit for 8 ounce gloves. The NAC’s executive director, Bob Bennett, stated that their primary concern is the safety of the fighters, and that the commission will need to determine if deviating from the regulations for a 7 pound weight difference is acceptable.  McGregor’s camp has requested to use 8 ounce gloves because he believes it will give him a better chance at knocking Mayweather out, as they offer less cushioning than 10 ounce gloves. Mayweather has agreed to the request, and has stated that he will also be using

Fleet Street, once the hub of British journalism, is now losing its last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith of the Sunday Post. The street was once home to nearly every national paper, with journalists working and socializing in its many pubs and bars. The decline of Fleet Street began in the 1980s when Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to a new complex in east London, leading to other newspapers following suit and adopting new printing technology. The buildings were repurposed, and now Fleet Street's era as the center of British journalism has come to an end.

Following criticism for her political views regarding the Scottish independence referendum, J.K. Rowling stated that she has been called a traitor and received numerous abusive comments on Twitter, primarily from supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). Despite this, she defends her right to speak out against bullies and notes that many SNP supporters have also been kind and share similar political views.

The Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime found that children from impoverished backgrounds in Scotland were more prone to encounter police action, violence, and involvement in the juvenile justice system.  Poverty, even after considering other factors, increased the likelihood of young people committing offenses and becoming both victims and perpetrators of crime. This cycle was found to be exacerbated by contact with the justice system, inadvertently fostering conditions conducive to violence.  The study also revealed that boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, with poverty further increasing the likelihood of violence among girls. Despite an overall decrease in crime rates in Scotland, the study indicated that crime remained concentrated in deprived communities with high levels of chronic health problems and unemployment, raising concerns about the effectiveness of government efforts to address inequality. The Scottish government defended its record, citing lower crime rates and investments aimed at mitigating the impact of welfare cuts.

Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in Kilkee, Ireland. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm in relation to the incident. Two other men were arrested but released without charge. Police allege Walsh was one of three people who entered the Marian Estate and a fight ensued, during which Haugh was stabbed in the back. Haugh was brought to the hospital and pronounced dead at 06:00 local time. A judge remanded Walsh in custody until August 14th.

In May 2014, Phil Flanagan, an MLA, tweeted that Tom Elliott, a UDR member, harassed and shot people. Elliott, who has a clean MoD record, sued Flanagan for libel. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and apologized, admitting the tweet was false.  The court has yet to determine the compensation amount, and Flanagan's insurance firm refused to cover the costs, leading to a separate court case. Elliott stated he felt vindicated by Flanagan's admission.

Hawick Knitwear, a company established in 1874 and acquired by Benny Hartop in November of the previous year, has boosted its sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 per week. This increase is due to higher demand for both their private label and newly launched Hawick Knitwear-branded items in markets including Europe, the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. The company's managing director anticipates continued success due to this growth.

72-year-old Sylvia Blackburn, a lollipop lady for 20 years, was hit by a car driven by 55-year-old Brian Wright in Kempston last December.  Mr. Wright says he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light or Mrs. Blackburn.  He says he is sorry for the injuries he caused.  The trial is ongoing.

NATO is conducting anti-submarine warfare exercises in response to increased Russian submarine activity. Russia has been investing heavily in its submarine fleet, which is considered the most advanced in the world. The exercises highlight a gap in Britain's defenses, as they no longer have maritime patrol aircraft and must rely on allies for assistance. This vulnerability is concerning because it allows Russian submarines to operate near the UK undetected and potentially track the country's nuclear deterrent. The exercise demonstrates the importance of NATO cooperation in anti-submarine warfare and the need for Britain to address its defense gaps.

Due to ongoing violence in South Sudan, 340,000 South Sudanese refugees have fled to Uganda in 2016, more than any other country. Civilians are being targeted and killed based on ethnicity, with Dinka soldiers attacking Equatorians and Nuers. Refugees report killings, rape, and theft by soldiers. Uganda is struggling to support the massive influx of refugees, despite providing land and aid. The international community needs to intervene and pressure South Sudanese leaders to end the violence.

Leon McKenzie, a 38-year-old professional boxer, will be fighting Jahmaine Smyle on November 12th for the English super-middleweight championship. McKenzie, who was previously a professional footballer, has had 9 fights with a record of 8 wins and 1 draw. He comes from a family of champion boxers, with his father and uncle both being former champions.

Bridgwater Community Hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and will be replaced by a new facility with 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, an X-ray unit, and space for mobile scanners. The new hospital is part of a £330m investment in new NHS facilities and will cost a total of £33m, with funding coming from the coalition government, NHS Somerset, and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The aim is to complete the new hospital at Bowers Lane by autumn 2014, pending planning permission. The current matron and a local GP highlight the positive impact the new facility will have on patient well-being and healthcare services in Somerset.

A man was fatally shot in the chest while near his car on Daniel Hill Terrace in Sheffield. The victim was taken to the hospital but died from his injuries. The police are investigating the incident. There have been a number of other shootings in Sheffield recently, but all of the previous shootings have been in the north of the city, not near the Upperthorpe area where this shooting occurred.

## Concise Summary of the Passage:

This passage discusses the role of various hacker groups in the Ukrainian conflict.  

**Pro-Ukrainian Groups:**

*   **Ukrainian Cyber Troops:** Led by Yevhen Dokukin, they employ DDoS attacks to disrupt rebel websites and funding, hack CCTV systems for surveillance, and spread pro-Ukrainian messages. They claim to have shared data from hacked Russian servers with Ukrainian security services.
*   **Inform Napalm:** This volunteer group analyzes leaked data, such as the Russian military's involvement in Ukraine.

**Pro-Russian Groups:**

*   **Cyber Berkut:** This anti-Western group disrupts Ukrainian government websites, claims to expose Ukrainian military plans and US involvement, and spreads pro-Russian propaganda through hacked billboards. They also allege to have evidence of Ukrainian forces downing MH17.
*   **Anonymous International:** This Russian group leaks sensitive information, potentially from Kremlin insiders. While primarily focused on Russian domestic affairs, they have released information about the conflict in Ukraine, including a letter challenging local support for separatists and alleged emails from a key rebel commander.


The passage highlights the significant role of cyber warfare in the conflict, with both sides utilizing hacking and information dissemination to

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick and veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil were emotional as they bid farewell to the parliament. Former first minister Alex Salmond, who served between 2007 and 2014, used his final address to express his belief that Scotland was “not divided, but diverse.” He also stated that the Scotland Bill did not fulfill the pledges made by unionist politicians. Salmond concluded by saying that there is “no greater honor in public life than to be a member of this parliament.” Marwick thanked Salmond for his service as an MSP and first minister. McNeil, who served in the parliament since it was established in 1999, warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster with regard to the committee system. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie joked that she would miss her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

- The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is launching a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales.
- The review will gather evidence from older people and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies.
- The commissioner aims to highlight both good and poor care and address variations in quality across Wales.
- The review will consider factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment.
- Care providers, social care staff, and public bodies will also be consulted.
- The commissioner's recommendations will aim to ensure that those responsible for care services understand the realities of residential care and take action to improve the quality of life for older people.
- Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but expresses disappointment at the lack of a provider expert on the advisory panel.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based company, saw an increase in pre-tax profit to £3.5m despite a £1m decrease in turnover. International sales grew and the company remains confident in the face of Brexit. The company supplies animal feed and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland.

A man in his 70s was found dead in his home in Nettleden Road on Saturday. Police are treating the death as a murder and are looking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin.  A man in his 80s was also taken to the hospital. The police are asking anyone with information to contact them.

- The IMF's latest assessment reveals a weakening global economy, particularly impacting China.
- Weaker-than-anticipated trade data from China, including a significant drop in exports, contributes to this decline.
- In light of this, the IMF is likely to revise its global growth forecast downward in the coming months.
- These developments have implications for businesses and industries reliant on China's growth.

The new Cowes Floating Bridge has had a problematic start, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspensions, causing disruptions and frustration for local businesses. The council has initiated a project review and is offering free ferry crossings until July 2nd to gather feedback. Compensation for affected businesses is being considered, and the council is addressing the technical issues and training deficiencies that have arisen.

At approximately 7:30 GMT on Thursday, a fatal multi-vehicle accident occurred on the southbound lane of the A3 near the Hindhead tunnel in Bramshott. A 32-year-old male was pronounced dead at the scene, and a 33-year-old male from Waterlooville was arrested for suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until the evening while police investigated.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency, faced criticism for its discriminatory job ads requesting a personal assistant with specific physical attributes and a "sexy female driver." The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) deemed the ads unlawful and discriminatory, while women's equality campaigners found them outdated. Matching Models defended its practices, stating the importance of looks for its clients. Employment lawyer James Lynas confirmed the illegality of such ads under the 2010 Equality Act. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, cited client preferences to justify the requirements. Despite the controversy, Matching Models boasts high-profile clients like MTV and Louis Vuitton.

Mahesh, an office assistant at Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, shot two students on Tuesday. One student, Gautami, was killed, while the other, Sirisha, was severely injured but is expected to survive. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday and will be held until April 12. Though rare in India, this is not the first incident of gun violence in schools, as a similar incident occurred in Delhi in 2007.

In a study of television series airing or confirmed between June 2016 and May 2017, Glaad found 278 LGBT characters, including an increase in transgender characters from 7 to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off. The report also showed a record number of black characters, primarily due to shows like Empire and Luke Cage. While progress is being made, representation numbers are only part of the story, according to Glaad's president.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, will not seek re-election following criticism over a loan made to Northampton Town Football Club while he was leader of the borough council.  An investigation is underway regarding the disappearance of £10.25m of public money loaned for the stadium project.  Mackintosh, who denies wrongdoing, was expected to be deselected by his local party.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old policeman, was charged with murder after shooting into a car full of teenagers leaving a party, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. Initially, police claimed the car reversed towards Oliver, but footage showed it driving away. Oliver was fired and faces 5 to 99 years in prison. He was also charged with aggravated assault for the other teenagers in the car. While an indictment is appropriate, a lawyer for the Edwards family notes it's been over 40 years since a police officer was convicted of murder in the county.

Melania Trump will not be moving into the White House immediately, instead choosing to stay in New York until her son, Barron, finishes school. This decision has caused some controversy, as she will be only the third First Lady in history to not live in the White House. However, her decision is not unprecedented, as many other First Families have also prioritized their children's education and well-being. While the role of the First Lady is largely ceremonial, it is still seen as an important part of the presidency, and it remains to be seen how Melania Trump will choose to fulfill her duties. There is speculation that her step-daughter, Ivanka Trump, may take on some of the responsibilities traditionally associated with the First Lady. In the past, other First Ladies have also adapted the role to fit their family's needs and priorities, and the White House has often been a place where children have grown up and made memories.

A 72-year-old man called the police from a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on October 27th of this year and was later found dead. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) has been instructed to investigate the police response to the call.  Police Scotland awaits the findings of the investigation and is cooperating fully.  The commissioner’s findings will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS).

Strong winds, with gusts up to 75 mph, are expected in parts of Wales, particularly in western areas near the mountains, with possible travel disruption. The affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A fallen tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey has already caused road closures.

The Giants and Panthers tied 2-2 after the first period, with goals from Walser (Giants) and Dimmen (Panthers). The Giants pulled ahead in the second period with goals from Forney and Radja, and Desmarais extended the lead to 4-2. Ling scored one back for Nottingham before the end of the second period, making it 4-3. The teams will play again on Saturday, with Nottingham currently leading the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield (27) and Belfast (25).

Lewis Hamilton had a difficult race, starting from the back due to a grid penalty. He suffered front wing damage on the first lap, necessitating multiple pit stops. He finished in seventh place. Sebastian Vettel and Kimi Raikkonen, both driving for Ferrari, collided on the first lap but recovered to finish second and fifth, respectively. Nico Rosberg won the race, extending his lead in the championship standings. The race was also notable for an incident between Kvyat and Vettel, with the latter accusing the former of dangerous driving. Ricciardo led initially but suffered a puncture and finished fourth.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German national team football player, publicly announced he is gay after retiring from professional football. This is a historic event as he is the most prominent player to come out in a country where homophobia in football has been a significant issue. Hitzlsperger’s announcement has garnered widespread support from former teammates, football administrators, politicians, and even Bayern Munich, his former club. While some, like Philipp Lahm, previously advised against coming out due to fear of repercussions, Hitzlsperger’s brave decision is hoped to break down the taboo surrounding homosexuality in football and pave the way for greater openness and acceptance in the sport.

- Steve Sidwell, 34, has played in 32 Championship games this season, helping Brighton get promoted to the Premier League.
- His contract ends this year, but he hopes to sign a new one to play in the Premier League next season.
- He believes Brighton can remain in the Premier League and that he has earned a new deal through his performances this season.
- Sidwell joined Brighton on loan in the 2015-2016 season and signed a one-year deal in June 2016.
- He has Premier League experience with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke.

The match ended in a 1-1 draw between Blackpool and Colchester United. Blackpool scored first with a goal by Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized with a goal by Kurtis Guthrie. Despite chances for both teams, neither could secure a winning goal. The game ended with Colchester down a man after Sean Murray received a red card for a foul on Jim McAlister. Notably, Sam Slocombe made several key saves for Blackpool, while both teams had players receive yellow cards.

Colchester United have signed midfielder Alex Reid. The 29-year-old could make his first appearance for the club on Wednesday against Aston Villa. Last season, Reid played 37 games for Coventry as they were relegated from League One.

Following the murder of PC Keith Palmer, a memorial is planned at the National Memorial Arboretum to honor police officers and staff who have died in the line of duty. The UK Police Memorial Trust is raising funds for the memorial, which will feature the names of over 1,400 officers and staff and include a brass screen with leaf shapes for families of the fallen officers. The memorial is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United beat Sunderland 1-0 to go 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League table. Manager Alex Ferguson says that the team is focused on the next game and not on the points gap, but that they are going into the derby against Manchester City with a 15-point head start. Manchester United have won 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games and have eight matches remaining to better Chelsea's record 95-point haul in 2005. Ferguson will make changes for Monday's FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea after seeing Rafael and Anderson suffer injuries at Sunderland, while goalkeeper David De Gea also suffered a knock after a heavy collision with team-mate Nemanja Vidic.

Google's chairman, Eric Schmidt, stated that Google complies with tax laws wherever it operates. They believe that it is the government's responsibility to change tax laws if they want corporations to pay more in taxes. They are willing to pay more or less depending on the tax laws. A member of Parliament has proposed a committee that would examine the tax arrangements of large corporations. Google's chairman believes that corporate taxes should be levied in the country where a company conducts business and takes risks, not where products are consumed. He supports international tax reform.

To reduce the NHS’s reliance on agency staff, a cap was introduced on the amount hospitals can pay agency workers, which has saved the NHS £600m.  The NHS is still short of its goal to reduce agency spending by £1bn.  In the future, the NHS plans to publish data on agency spending to increase transparency and identify excessive agency costs.

Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland's economic boom, now reflects the country's economic struggles. Though local businesses have seen improvement, the opposition party Fianna Fáil criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, suggesting that funds should be directed towards broadband rather than water meters. While the government defends its efforts, highlighting the potential Center Parcs development, local traders believe that further action, such as eliminating parking charges, is needed to stimulate the local economy. Despite some signs of recovery, the midlands requires continued support to fully rebound.

The competition, which includes eight teams, runs until May 29th. The top four teams in the league will advance to the playoffs. Warner leads in runs scored and sixes, while De Kock has the highest score in a single inning, and McClenaghan has the most wickets. Four English players will be participating in the tournament, including Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The competition's schedule includes matches nearly every day, culminating in the final on May 29th.

Plastic bag use has increased by 200 million since 2013, ending up in landfills and waterways, causing environmental damage. To combat this, England will introduce a 5p charge for plastic bags in October, similar to Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where charges have successfully reduced bag consumption. This initiative aims to encourage bag reuse and reduce environmental pollution.

High winds across Wales on Friday, December 23, 2022, caused a school roof to be ripped off, hundreds of homes to lose power, train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and ferry cancellations. The highest wind gusts were recorded on Anglesey. Some locations, including the National Trust, closed due to the high winds. The winds eased into Friday evening, with bridge restrictions lifted. Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed until Tuesday, December 27, 2022, due to continued blustery weather forecasts.

Michael B. Jordan will star in the movie Black Panther, which will be released in February 2018, directed by Ryan Coogler. He is excited to work with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman.  Jordan previously worked with Coogler on the movie Creed.  He also played the Human Torch in the Fantastic Four reboot.  Nyong'o played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens.  Boseman plays Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War.

Alexandra Palace's theatre and BBC studios are planned to undergo renovations as part of a larger east wing restoration project. The theatre, which has been unused for decades, will be refurbished and potentially used for various performances and events. The project has received funding from the Heritage Lottery Fund and Haringey Council, with the remaining funds to be raised by the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust. The goal is to reopen the theatre in 2018 and transform Alexandra Palace into a cultural destination.

James Milner, who played for England's national team from 2009, retired from international duty after earning 61 caps. He was part of the England squad in two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played three minutes in Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps and scored one international goal.

The Smith family’s house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, caught fire and was destroyed. The fire was started by rubbish burning in the wood stove. While the family escaped, their pets died in the fire, and they lost all of their possessions.  David Smith, the son, was awake and saw the flames, waking up his mother and sister. The fire spread extremely quickly, engulfing the kitchen in seconds. The community has been very supportive, donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for David.  Mrs. Smith credits her son with saving her and her daughter’s lives.

- Energy drinks giant considers a £200m offer for West Ham.
- Sullivan and Gold bought West Ham for £105m in 2010 and currently own over 85%.
- West Ham linked to Qatari and Chinese groups.
- Sullivan said minority shareholding could be sold, but ownership will pass to his children.

The MTV Movie Awards, held in Los Angeles, celebrated fan favorites like best kiss and best shirtless performance. “The Fault in Our Stars” won best movie, with Shailene Woodley taking home best female performance, Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance, Channing Tatum won best comedic performance, and Meryl Streep won best villain. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, Rose Byrne, and Kevin Hart, who received the comedic genius award. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, presented by his fellow Avengers co-stars. The ceremony also showcased upcoming films like “Pitch Perfect 2”, “Trainwreck”, and Marvel’s “Ultron”.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old forward, has joined St. Mirren on loan from Aberdeen. Smith previously played for Dundee United, where he scored 5 goals this season. St. Mirren manager Jack Ross is excited about the acquisition, believing Smith will provide another attacking option for his team.
Northumberland County Council will be fixing potholes over the next four months. They hope to fix 145 potholes per day. They will also be repairing drainage systems and clearing debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework. The exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). EnQuest and Wood Group conducted investigations and implemented additional safety measures. The workers involved, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, expressed concerns about potential long-term health effects and criticized EnQuest's handling of the incident.  Unite union called for greater transparency in such incidents to improve offshore safety. HSE was informed but did not conduct an investigation as the incident was not reportable under existing regulations.

The Asian Civilisations Museum (ACM) in Singapore has agreed to return a stolen 11th Century bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India after it was confirmed the item was purchased from a dealer of stolen Indian antiquities. The museum bought the sculpture for $650,000 in 2007 from Art of the Past, whose manager later admitted to selling stolen artifacts. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a temple in Tamil Nadu. The museum will take legal action to recoup the money lost in the purchase.

On November 25, 2013, a 4.8 magnitude earthquake hit 35km north of Lucca, Italy. The quake, which had an epicenter in Garfagnana, had aftershocks that were felt in Milan and Florence. No injuries or damage were reported, though schools near the epicenter were evacuated as a precaution. Italy is prone to earthquakes, including one in L'Aquila in 2009 that killed almost 300 people and another in May 2013 that killed over 20 people. In October 2012, members of the National Commission for the Forecast and Prevention of Serious Risks were convicted of manslaughter for providing inaccurate information about the likelihood of the 2009 earthquake.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, has successfully grown a pineapple plant outdoors in South Yorkshire, despite initial doubts about the climate's suitability. The fruit is not yet ripe.

The release of Grand Theft Auto V for PC has been delayed from January 27th to March 24th to allow for extra testing and polishing. Online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. The PC version will support resolutions up to 4K and up to triple monitor configurations. Minimum PC specs have been released. The original release generated $1 Billion in revenue in 3 days.

- Ansel Krut, a judge, said Squint (19) was an extraordinary painting.
- Squint (19) was painted by 76-year-old artist, Simpson.
- Simpson said the painting was inspired by medieval leper squints.
- Simpson will use the £25,000 prize money to buy art supplies.
- The John Moores Painting Prize was established in 1957.
- Previous winners include David Hockney and Peter Doig.

In Istanbul, Turkey, the offices of two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked at night. Masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building and started a fire that was quickly extinguished. At Yeni Akit, windows were shattered by gunfire. No casualties were reported at either location. Police are investigating the attacks. So far, no group has claimed responsibility.

The 24-year-old football player, who was previously under contract with the Stags, will be joining the Mariners on January 1st after a free transfer was agreed upon. He spent the first part of the season playing for Crawley, where he scored 3 goals in 23 appearances. This will be the manager's first signing for the Mariners.

Gareth Southgate is the interim manager for the English National team after Sam Allardyce's departure. Southgate has two more games to prove he should have the job permanently. Wenger believes Southgate has the experience and qualifications for the job. Wenger also mentioned that Arsenal defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a contract extension. Bellerin's current contract has three years left, but Wenger wants to keep him at Arsenal long-term. Lastly, Wenger stated that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will be out for one or two more games with a hamstring injury.

A man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker and died on Thursday at 13:45 GMT.  Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are investigating the incident, and the company is cooperating fully.

- Freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay have been operated by Seatruck, which is contracted by Serco Northlink.
- The RMT union claimed that some workers on the freight boats were being paid less than £4 an hour.
- Seatruck argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents.
- Serco Northlink said they offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined.
- A new charter arrangement will see contracted out services return to operator Serco Northlink from next month, and all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage.

Ken Dickie died after an altercation with Jamie Mitchell at Rockley Park on May 14th. Mitchell intervened in an argument between Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell. Jamie and Samantha initially lied to the police about what happened but Jamie later admitted that he pushed Dickie, causing his death. He pleaded guilty to common assault. Both Jamie and Samantha Mitchell pleaded guilty to attempting to pervert the course of justice. Sentencing will be on February 6th.

Rod Temperton, a renowned British songwriter known as "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, passed away in London at 66 after battling cancer. His funeral was private. Temperton's career began with the disco group Heatwave, where he wrote hits like "Boogie Nights." He then gained recognition for writing songs for Michael Jackson's albums, including "Off The Wall" and "Thriller," contributing to the latter's status as the best-selling album in the US. His songwriting talent extended to various artists like Anita Baker, Donna Summer, and Aretha Franklin, earning him a Grammy Award and two Oscar nominations. He was known for prioritizing his love for music in his songwriting process. His legacy is celebrated by numerous artists and industry figures who recognize his significant contribution to the music world.

A team of researchers, including Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, discovered 2,000-year-old earthworks in the western Brazilian Amazon. These "geoglyphs" were likely used as ritual gathering places, though their exact purpose remains unclear. Analysis of soil samples suggests they were built within the forest, unlike other ritual sites like the Maya pyramids. The research also indicates that humans have influenced the Amazonian forests for over 6,000 years, potentially through a form of "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. This challenges the assumption that the Amazonian forests were pristine before European arrival.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, beat Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in the first round of the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios said he was bored and tired during the match, which followed his win at the Japan Open and a lot of travel. Last year's Shanghai Masters saw Kyrgios fined for bad language.

HPV is a sexually transmitted virus that can cause head and neck cancers. The number of cases are increasing, especially in younger men. Currently, only girls aged 12 and 13 in Wales receive the HPV vaccine to protect them against cervical cancer. Charities and organizations are urging the Welsh government to vaccinate boys as well. They believe this will reduce the number of HPV-related cancers and show that the government takes public health seriously. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old with a rare form of blood cancer, passed away.  Diagnosed in August, Jak documented his treatment and life on social media via “Jak’s Journey”.  He was able to attend his prom, which was held in his honor, for a short time.  Despite his illness, Jak remained positive and spent his time doing activities he enjoyed.  After learning his cancer had spread and was no longer treatable, Jak and his family urged people to donate to a Leukemia & Lymphoma Research fundraiser.  A football match fundraiser was planned in his honor as well.

Egypt won the match against Uganda 1-0. The only goal was scored by Abdallah El Said in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside in the 52nd minute. With this win, Egypt will play Ghana to determine the top spot in Group D. Uganda is out of the tournament, their first time since 1978.

Lancashire County Council has chosen the location of a former sports college and college campus for a new Skelmersdale railway station. The site was selected after a study by Network Rail and deemed preferable due to its size, highway access, and connectivity to the town. The council will now begin acquiring the land. The station would allow for two direct trains to Liverpool per hour.
During a police search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, an elaborate grow house containing a number of plants was discovered, leading to the arrest of a man in his late 40s.

A 28-year-old German woman of Kurdish origin was found seriously injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Germany, after being dragged through the streets by her neck. Her 38-year-old ex-partner, also a German citizen of Kurdish origin, turned himself in and is now in custody. The motive is still unclear and police are investigating.

Research using Australian workplace data from 2013-14, found that men and women are equally as likely to ask for a raise, but men are 25% more likely to receive one. This debunks the theory that women are less likely to ask for a raise, and potentially indicates the presence of discrimination. Younger women and men (under 40) were found to have equal success in asking for and receiving raises, which may indicate a shift in workplace gender dynamics.

Oxford City Council has been searching for land for a new burial site for many years, but has been unable to find a suitable location. The two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. After that, only the reopening of family plots, the use of a few reserved plots, and the interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place July 19-22 in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, will feature acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean.  A new app will allow visitors to access online information, videos, and band interviews. The app also offers people around the world a chance to experience the festival.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old racehorse, died after winning the Cotswold Chase.  The horse had a history of post-race ataxia, or overheating, but had no other underlying health issues. After examination, it was determined he died from a rare pulmonary hemorrhage.

Davina Ayrton, 34, was found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in 2004. Ayrton, who was 15 at the time and identified as male, met the victim at a Portsmouth garage. The victim stated she was raped by Ayrton while two others slept in the garage. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, will be sentenced on March 4th and was remanded to a male prison. During the trial, Ayrton stated she had not made any physical changes or enhancements to her body or taken any medication, but had changed her name in 2012.

Novak Djokovic and Nenad Zimonjic (Serbia) lost in the men's doubles to Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares (Brazil). The day before, Djokovic was defeated by Juan Martin del Potro (Argentina) in the singles competition. Earlier in the year, Djokovic lost to Sam Querrey in the third round at Wimbledon but bounced back to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto.

- More than 20 competitors will participate in the chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge on Saturday.
- Carvers are from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US.
- Only chainsaws can be used to carve logs into shapes of animals and people.
- Last year's winner Pete Bowsher will return to defend his title.

Webb, who has been out with a foot injury since September, is nearing a return to rugby. He is currently in a pre-season phase and hopes to be back playing at the beginning of February. His goal is to be fit in time for the Six Nations which begins February 7th. In addition to his return to rugby, Webb has renewed his contract with Ospreys and the WRU, turning down offers from other teams. He cited his enjoyment of the club and desire to play for his country as reasons for staying.

On Tuesday morning, border patrol agents apprehended two men carrying backpacks near Sumas, Washington, interrupting a smuggling operation of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One suspect, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested on the spot, while the other, Nathan Hall, fled after firing at the agents. Hall was later apprehended by Canadian police. The backpacks contained 58lb of ecstasy and a fake driver's license. Two more individuals, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were arrested for their alleged roles in planning to transport the drugs to San Francisco. All those in custody face charges related to drug possession, distribution, and conspiracy. The area where the incident occurred is known for smuggling activities, leading to frequent prosecutions.

Childline's report shows a concerning increase in cyberbullying cases among children aged 7 and above, impacting their mental health and well-being. The charity urges adults and schools to intervene and provide support, emphasizing that bullying escalates if left unaddressed. One victim's testimony highlights the emotional distress caused by online harassment and the need for understanding and effective solutions.  The report's release coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, aiming to raise awareness and combat bullying through collaborative efforts.

Following a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements as illegal, Israel postponed a vote on authorizing new settlement homes in East Jerusalem. The postponement, at the request of Prime Minister Netanyahu's office, aims to avoid further conflict with the US before Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Israel was angered by the UN resolution, especially the condemnation of building in East Jerusalem, which it claims as part of its capital while Palestinians want it as their future capital. The resolution, which the US did not veto, calls for an end to settlement construction and states that settlements violate international law and hinder a two-state solution. In response to the resolution, Israel summoned ambassadors, recalled its own ambassadors, cut aid, and canceled a visit by Ukraine's prime minister.  Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution, hoping it will pave the way for a peace conference in France.

In a BBC interview, Prince William praised the Queen's exemplary service as a monarch, citing her as a guiding example. The Queen's 90th birthday celebrations included the release of commemorative stamps featuring four generations of the Royal Family, a visit to the Royal Mail delivery office, and the opening of a new bandstand in Windsor. The Queen's actual birthday on April 21st was marked with a walkabout in Windsor and the unveiling of a plaque for The Queen's Walkway. In the evening, she lit a beacon, initiating a chain of over 900 beacons across the UK and globally. The official birthday celebrations will continue in June. Prince William also addressed criticisms regarding his commitment to royal duties, stating that he takes his responsibilities seriously but is finding his own way at the right time. He emphasized his priority of maintaining a normal life for his family and himself. The BBC's extensive coverage of the Queen's birthday drew criticism from the republican pressure group Republic, which argued for a more balanced and proportionate reporting approach.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0. Sakho and Ayew scored first-half goals to secure the win for West Ham. Cheltenham had a few chances but were unable to score. Notably, Pell's volley and Forster's header were close, and Holman couldn't connect with Pell's low volley. Adrian, West Ham's goalkeeper, wasn't seriously tested. West Ham could have increased their lead, but Storer cleared Ogbonna's header and Flatt saved Sakho's attempt from Ayew's cross. Cheltenham's loss means that no League Two teams remain in the EFL Cup. The match concluded with a score of Cheltenham Town 0, West Ham United 2.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a motorcycle accident caused by Andreas Werner, who failed to see him while making a right turn. Werner admitted guilt to causing death by careless driving. He received a £1,000 fine and a two-year UK driving ban. Although the victim's family acknowledged it was an accident, they saw no value in Werner's imprisonment. Werner expressed remorse but couldn't explain the crash's cause.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British citizen, traveled to Syria to join Rayat al Tawheed, an Islamic State affiliate, where he engaged in combat and produced propaganda. Upon his return to the UK, he was arrested and charged with terrorism-related offenses. Khawaja's cousin, Tahir Bhatti, assisted in his return and was also charged.  Khawaja is considered a dangerous individual by authorities due to his involvement in terrorist activities and attempts to conceal his return to the UK. He has pleaded guilty to four offenses, while the more serious charge of soliciting to murder will lie on file.

- Kayden Jackson, who is 22 years of age, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season.
- Wrexham finished in eighth place.
- Jackson is Barnsley's third signing for next season.
- Barnsley will play in the League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday.
- Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham.

Numerous sealed bottles of Vanish detergent have washed up on the Cornish coast, likely from a container that fell overboard during rough seas.  Although it's suspected that the container originated from the MV Blue Ocean, which lost a container of Vanish in May near Land's End, there is no definitive proof.  The National Trust, along with other organizations, are cleaning up the bottles due to potential harm to wildlife, and Cornwall Council advises the public to avoid contact with them.

At approximately 2 PM, a crash transpired on the A9 road, situated north of Berriedale in Caithness. The incident resulted in one fatality and minor injuries for several individuals. Authorities shut down the road and implemented detours through the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. An ongoing investigation into the incident is being conducted by Police Scotland.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French center-back, has signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers following their promotion to the Championship. Dervite made 14 appearances last season, helping the team finish second in League One. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has played in a total of 83 games for the club. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contributions to the team's successful season. Dervite joins David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in extending their contracts with Bolton.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour are experiencing conflict in the House of Lords concerning Brexit-related amendments. Although the two parties initially collaborated to defeat the government on issues like EU citizens' rights, their cooperation dissolved when MPs rejected these amendments. The Liberal Democrats are determined to persist with these amendments, while Labour is prepared to yield to the House of Commons. Each party accuses the other of political maneuvering, with the Liberal Democrats criticizing Labour for aligning with the Conservatives on a hard Brexit and Labour accusing the Liberal Democrats of offering false hope to EU citizens. Despite this tension, the Liberal Democrats remain optimistic about future collaborations on other issues, while Labour anticipates lingering strain in their relationship.

This article discusses the UK’s defense policies and the challenges it faces in maintaining its military capabilities.

**Key takeaways:**

*   Defense is not a top priority for most political parties in the current election, despite a more dangerous and unstable global environment.
*   The UK has been making significant cuts to its armed forces, including reducing the size of the army and navy, and has capability gaps, such as a lack of Maritime Patrol Aircraft.
*   The UK's defense spending is projected to fall below the NATO target of 2% of GDP, potentially impacting its credibility with allies, particularly the US.
*   Further defense cuts are likely, with the MoD being a potential target for savings.
*   The future of the UK's nuclear deterrent, Trident, is uncertain, with some parties proposing alternatives or even scrapping it altogether.
*   The UK's new aircraft carriers may face challenges in terms of crew and aircraft, potentially undermining their effectiveness.

In conclusion, the UK's defense faces significant challenges in terms of funding, capabilities, and political priorities, raising questions about its ability to maintain its global influence and meet future security threats.

Barcelona football club paid £48.6m for Neymar in the summer of 2013.  There are allegations that the actual cost was far greater, which prompted an investigation into the transfer.  Barcelona denies any wrongdoing but paid £10.6m as a "complimentary tax declaration" to cover any possible divergent interpretation of the tax amount.  The investigation is ongoing.  Neymar has scored 7 goals in 18 league appearances this season.

Michael Luciw died as a passenger in a van that was hit by a wrong-way driver, who also died. Luciw's family suggests that older drivers should have regular driving tests, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of driving for older people's independence. The family remembers Luciw as a kind and generous person whose life was tragically cut short. They believe the accident could have been avoided with stricter regulations for older drivers, such as tests in a car with an instructor. The van driver, who survived with injuries, supports the idea of medical examinations for retired drivers. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK self-assess their driving ability every three years without a formal test. The DVLA has no plans to change the rules based on age, stating that older drivers are not statistically more likely to cause serious accidents. They emphasize that drivers must report medical conditions and can have their licenses revoked if they don't meet medical standards. Age UK highlights the importance of driving for older people's independence and advocates for supporting safe driving practices among them.

An independent review of transvaginal mesh implants concluded that the procedure should not be routinely offered to women with pelvic organ prolapse. The review also recommended that patients be offered a range of treatments and be given the information necessary to make informed choices, and that reporting of adverse events should be mandatory. The chairwoman of the review apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the review's controversial final report, which was met with criticism from some women who had suffered complications as a result of the procedure. Two patients and a consultant quit the review group over concerns about the final report. Over the past 20 years, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants, and some have suffered painful and debilitating complications. There are more than 400 women currently taking legal action against Scottish health boards and manufacturers as a result of mesh implant surgery.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish runner, broke Liz McColgan’s 25-year-old British 5K record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan raised concerns about the legitimacy of the race as Muir was the only runner to complete the 5K, but British Athletics confirmed Muir’s time was expected to be classified as official. McColgan believes Muir can achieve even faster times and win world medals with improved race tactics.

Michael Jung won the gold medal in the equestrian eventing competition in Rio. He was riding Sam, a horse who replaced the original horse after it became ill. Astier Nicolas of France and Phillip Dutton of the USA won silver and bronze respectively. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished in 12th place, despite leading after the dressage phase. He incurred time penalties in the cross-country phase which took him out of medal contention. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished in 9th place.

Andy Murray, the 30-year-old British tennis player, defeated Fabio Fognini in a four-set match at Wimbledon. The final score was 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5, with the match concluding at 20:57 BST. Despite a late surge by Fognini, Murray secured victory in the fourth set, winning five consecutive games after trailing 2-5. Murray will face Benoit Paire in the fourth round. The match was marked by tension and fluctuating momentum, with Fognini's temper and a potential delay due to fading light adding to the drama. Murray acknowledged the challenging conditions but expressed satisfaction with his performance, particularly his ability to overcome the deficit in the fourth set.

On October 6, 2014, police discovered Joe's Bar in Dungiven was serving alcohol outside of licensing hours, as late as 04:49 BST.  The establishment's license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and employee, James Thomas, were charged with permitting the consumption of alcohol after hours. O'Neill was fined £3,000 and Thomas £1,000. The judge ordered a 3-month closure of Joe's Bar.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party (UUP), launched the party's manifesto, 'Real Partnership'.  Nesbitt's comments on partnership rather than domination and his suggestion that voters consider transferring votes to SDLP candidates have caused controversy.  Despite criticism, Nesbitt stands by his remarks and believes that voters are more concerned with issues like the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle and the DUP and Sinn Fein's handling of Stormont. The UUP manifesto focuses on issues such as tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, and standing up for the LGBT community.  Nesbitt hopes that the election will be a referendum on the current government's incompetence and alleged corruption.

- Northern Ireland's Justice Minister will put forward a motion for a pardon for men convicted of abolished sexual offenses.
- The pardon will be similar to one planned for England and Wales, which would provide both posthumous and living pardons.
- The aim is to provide equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland, similar to their counterparts in England and Wales.
- The Justice Minister will ask the assembly to pass the motion, which will bring the changes into effect sooner than if a new bill was introduced.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish runner, achieved a new Scottish record in the 1500m race, finishing second to Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4:19.12. This accomplishment also placed her second on the British all-time list. Muir expressed her delight with the new record and is now focused on securing a spot in the British Olympics team during the upcoming trials in Birmingham.
Scotland has 26 beaches that are ranked as having the "most excellent" water quality.

Alexander Litvinenko was murdered in 2006 after drinking tea laced with polonium-210. UK officials suspect Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, who deny involvement. Evidence suggests Russian state involvement, potentially motivated by Litvinenko's defection and criticism of Putin. The suspects remain in Russia, extradition attempts failed, and the risk to the public from polonium contamination is unknown.

Following Michael Clarke's retirement after Australia's Ashes defeat, Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed Australia's Test cricket captain.  He has previously captained the team in three Test matches and currently leads the one-day side.  David Warner, 28, was named vice-captain of the team.  Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron, the newly elected leader of the Liberal Democrats, states that defending and extending equal marriage will be at the top of his agenda. He plans to extend marital rights to transgender people and ensure their equal access to marriage. Although passionate about LGBT-plus rights, he refused to answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin. He voted against the 2007 Equality Bill due to concerns about protecting individual liberties but maintains that he supports equality for all, regardless of sexuality.

Sanofi's drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, which closed in 2015 and resulted in the loss of 450 jobs, will be reopened by Accord Healthcare. Accord's investment in the plant will not only have a positive impact on the area, but it is also expected to bring back many of the jobs previously lost. The investment will also boost the local economy and strengthen Newcastle's reputation as a hub for science and healthcare.

Three senior members of Aberdeen City Council, Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland, are leaving their positions. Richard Ellis's contract ended, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland chose voluntary redundancy and early retirement. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition, believes this shows the council's struggle to retain senior staff and expects more departures soon. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their service.

Guy Martin has quit Honda road racing for the remainder of the year after mechanical issues with the Fireblade and a crash at this year's TT. He clarified that he has not quit road racing entirely, but will not race Hondas for the rest of the year. He cited a disastrous TT and the bike's lack of competitiveness as reasons for the decision. He was withdrawn from the Ulster Grand Prix by the team and plans to race classics and other unique events in the future.

In Nigeria's elections, the APC won 19 governorships, while the PDP won 8, marking a significant shift in power. The APC's triumph includes key states in the north, but they failed to secure any of the oil-producing regions. This could pose challenges for the incoming president, as it may hinder efforts to control oil production and revenue. The elections, while not without violence, were deemed more peaceful than previous ones, suggesting a maturing democracy. The PDP, once dominant, is now relegated to a regional party and faces the need for introspection and rebuilding. Their loss can be attributed to factors like defections, corruption allegations, and the inability to quell the insurgency in the north-east.

Mighty, a US environmental lobby group, has accused Olam, a Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may be contributing to the haze problem in Southeast Asia. Olam denies the allegations, stating that it has a strict "no burn" policy and that it is working to ensure its suppliers meet its sustainability standards. Temasek, a Singapore state-owned investment company, has also denied the allegations, stating that it does not direct the business operations of its portfolio companies. Mighty also accuses Olam of deforestation in Gabon, Africa, where it is establishing palm oil plantations. Olam defends its practices in Gabon, stating that it is working with the government to develop sustainable palm oil plantations. The palm oil industry globally faces criticism for unsustainable practices, including deforestation and the burning of plantations. Environmental groups and palm oil executives often disagree on the extent of the problem and how to address it.
After a new law was introduced in August of 2016 allowing dogs to eat at restaurants, a restaurant began serving puppy platters outdoors.
Fernando Forestieri (knee) and David Nugent (groin) are injury doubts for Derby County. Jacob Butterfield is hoping to be recalled after scoring as a substitute against Huddersfield.

Pakistan's YouTube ban was lifted because Google launched a Pakistan-specific version that allows the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to request the removal of content deemed offensive, though YouTube will not automatically grant all requests and maintains it will remove content violating its community guidelines. The ban was originally imposed in 2012 after the film "Innocence of Muslims" was uploaded, sparking protests. Google's local YouTube versions for Pakistan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka were launched last week.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, the same nationality as one of the presidential candidates.  In the past, Scala excused himself from FIFA elections for this reason, but has refused to do so this time, as there is no rule requiring it.  Musa Bility, head of the Liberian FA, says he will take the issue to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down.  The election will take place on February 26th.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday. The men were working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday. The Health and Safety Executive is investigating the incident.

Tunisia and Morocco will be allowed to compete in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia had been facing expulsion for complaints made against the Confederation of African Football (CAF), but the issue has been resolved. Morocco had been banned following its refusal to host the 2015 tournament, but the ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

After a 95th-minute brawl during the Chelsea-Manchester City game, City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho received bans. Aguero was banned for four matches, and Fernandinho was banned for three. Both clubs have until December 8th to respond to the charges.

Concise Summary:

Wales has some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world.
A pilot scheme in Cynon Valley & Neath Port Talbot allows GPs to refer patients they suspect of having cancer, but who don't show clear symptoms, to a diagnostic center within 7 days.
The hope is to diagnose patients sooner & improve survival rates, as currently many patients begin treatment when their cancer is advanced.
The pilot is modeled after a similar system in Denmark, which saw improved outcomes.
If successful, the scheme will be rolled out to other health boards in Wales.
The scheme aims to address the issue of patients without clear symptoms facing delays in diagnosis due to not fitting easily into treatment pathways. 
A similar clinic will be set up in Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of a trial by Swansea Bay University Health Board.

England decisively won the second Test against Pakistan by an innings and 120 runs at Old Trafford, leveling the series 1-1. Joe Root was named man of the match for his exceptional performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and 71 not out in the second. England's dominant batting display, coupled with Pakistan's struggles, has positioned them as strong contenders for the remainder of the series, despite concerns about Pakistan's potential comeback.

Warren Gatland, head coach of the British and Irish Lions, has appointed Rob Howley as interim coach. With Gatland away, Wales forwards coach Robin McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales during the summer tour. The WRU will announce assistant coaches next week.  WRU chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches with the Lions tour will benefit the national team in the future.

Hull City defeated Southampton 2-1. Charlie Austin scored a penalty kick for Southampton in the 6th minute of the game. Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson each scored a goal for Hull City to secure the win.  Hull City had lost their previous six games. The win moved Hull City out of last place in the league.  Southampton had more shots on goal and more corner kicks than Hull City, but were unable to score more goals.

A motorcyclist was killed in a crash with a tractor on the B1191 in Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at approximately 2:15 pm BST. The tractor driver was unharmed. Police are seeking witnesses to the incident. The B1191 was temporarily closed in both directions between the B1192 and A158 junctions.

Macedonia's President Ivanov canceled an investigation into recordings that revealed potential abuse of power by government ministers. Ivanov's reason was to end turmoil before elections in June, but his decision was condemned by the EU and Macedonia's opposition. The recordings, released by opposition leader Zaev, allegedly exposed government corruption, including vote-rigging and cover-ups. The government denies these accusations. As a result, protests have erupted, and Macedonia's EU membership is now at risk.

Following Bob Bradley's dismissal, Curtis and Paul Williams will temporarily lead Swansea against Bournemouth. The club aims to swiftly appoint a new manager, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the top candidate. Curtis believes Swansea have deviated from their established style of play since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 due to frequent managerial changes. He emphasizes the importance of remaining in the Premier League, citing the difficulty of bouncing back from relegation, as evidenced by the struggles of other relegated clubs. Despite acknowledging the squad's potential for survival, Curtis highlights the significance of the club's history and the need for players to understand the importance of avoiding relegation.

Dagenham & Redbridge have been relegated to the National League after a 3 - 2 loss to Leyton Orient. Dagenham had reached the Football League for the first time in their history in 2007, reaching League One in 2010. Manager John Still, who returned for his third spell at the club in December, said he is committed to helping the Daggers gain promotion from the National League next season. The win keeps Leyton Orient's playoff hopes alive, as they sit two points adrift of the playoff spots. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler took over after player-manager Kevin Nolan was removed from his role four days prior.

Steven Gerrard, former Liverpool and England captain, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February. Gerrard, who retired from playing in November, has stated his desire to manage in the future and this is his first step towards that goal.  Gerrard played for Liverpool for 17 years before leaving in 2015. He has also been working towards his Uefa A coaching license.

Morton won the game against Alloa with a final score of 4-1. Morton's McManus scored two goals, one at the start and one at the end of the match. Forbes scored Morton's second goal, while Johnstone scored their fourth and final goal. Alloa's only goal was scored by McAusland.

Ofsted investigations uncovered evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three unregistered schools in Birmingham, which have now been closed.  

- Unregistered schools operating for over 20 hours a week are illegal.

- Ofsted, along with the help of the local council, closed three unregistered schools in Birmingham, and the owners are under investigation.

- Sir Michael Wilshaw believes that the government was slow to take decisive action in closing the schools.

- The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools.

- The Education Secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools.

Lilliard Gin, the first distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837, is about to open at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh. It is a small-batch operation that sources local ingredients. The gin is named after a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

Gary Green, who had consumed over two times the legal limit of alcohol, reversed a vehicle into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm in August 2013, resulting in Harry's death.  Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others under health and safety legislation, as the incident occurred on private land.
