The service at Westminster Abbey concluded with the national anthems of Australia and New Zealand. The Gallipoli campaign, a significant event in the war, is remembered for the sacrifices made by Australian and New Zealand troops.

David Clarkson, who rejoined Premiership Well for his second spell in July, could make his debut for St Mirren against Alloa on Saturday. Clarkson has been playing with the U20s to keep his match fitness up and says he is ready to play. He has two caps for Scotland and has made almost 400 senior appearances at the club level. St Mirren are currently eighth in the Championship.

Bernard Matthews, the turkey firm, was sold to Ranjit Boparan.  There were concerns that the new owners would not honor the pension scheme agreements in place, but after discussions with the union, it was confirmed that the pension scheme agreements will be honored.  The new owners plan to invest in the business, implement cost savings, and utilize spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkey, with the goal of restoring the firm to a highly profitable business.

The new Cowes Floating Bridge has had a problematic start with breakdowns, groundings, and suspensions, causing disruptions and frustration for local businesses. The council has initiated a project review and offered free ferry crossings until July 2nd to gather feedback. Compensation for local businesses impacted by the ferry's issues is being considered, while the council has addressed some technical problems and is working to resolve the remaining issues.

Following Brexit, the UK fishing industry, which currently makes up a small percentage of the UK’s GDP, has the opportunity to become a leading fish exporter. However, this depends on the UK government prioritizing the industry during Brexit negotiations to maintain tariff-free access to the EU market, which may come at the price of allowing EU boats access to UK waters. The UK fishing industry also needs to ensure that fishing quotas are based on scientific advice and that there is a unified fisheries management approach across England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. Despite the challenges, the industry remains optimistic about the future of UK fishing post-Brexit.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, admitted to taking and possessing indecent images of children over a 10-year period. He was sentenced to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and has now been removed from the teaching register by the General Teaching Council Scotland. The GTC panel deemed his actions incompatible with the teaching profession and found a high likelihood of recurrence due to the volume of images, duration of the offense, and lack of remedial action. Geaney is prohibited from reapplying for registration for two years.

A large fire occurred at a waste recycling facility in Duncan Street on March 2nd, causing travel disruptions. Following the incident, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended the facility's operator, Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, from receiving further waste. While the fire service found the operator generally compliant with fire safety laws, the EA decided to revoke the site's environmental permit due to concerns about potential risks to the surrounding area. The operator has until August 7th to appeal the revocation, after which they must cease operations and remove all waste from the site. The cause of the fire is still unknown.

Syria, despite delays, maintains its commitment to eliminating its chemical weapons stockpile, citing attacks by terrorist groups as a hindrance.  They deny accusations of using barrel bombs against civilians in Aleppo, framing it as defense against terrorists.  Furthermore, the Syrian government refutes claims of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, stating it remains under government control, despite reports from organizations like the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Aleppo Media Centre suggesting otherwise.  The US expresses concern over delays in the chemical weapons removal process, originally slated for completion by June.  Russia, a Syrian ally, has set a new deadline of March 1st for the transfer of weapons to the coast for removal.  The OPCW acknowledges security concerns have hampered the process, but Syria insists it will fulfill its obligations.

England decisively won the second Test against Pakistan by an innings and 120 runs to level the series 1-1. Joe Root's exceptional performance, scoring 254 in the first innings, earned him the man of the match award. Pakistan's batting struggles continued, highlighting a lack of confidence and poor shot selection, while England's strong performance suggests they are well-placed to win the series, despite predictions it will be closely contested.

- The Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of residential care of older people in Wales.
- The review aims to gather evidence from older people and their families to understand their experiences (both positive and negative) with residential care.
- The goal is to develop recommendations for improving the quality of life and care for older people in residential homes.
- The review will investigate various factors impacting quality of life, including physical and mental health, social interactions, and the care environment.
- While supporting the review's aims, Care Forum Wales expresses concern about the lack of care provider representation on the advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, former Dons midfielder and Arbroath's player-manager, will be Aberdeen's new manager after Neil Cooper. Aberdeen's chief executive said that despite wanting to keep Sheerin at Arbroath, the chairman understood his desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin played for several Scottish clubs, Östersunds in Sweden, and was capped for the Scotland Under-21 team. He also led Arbroath to win their first national trophy and a promotion in 2011.

Following Bob Bradley's dismissal, Curtis and Paul Williams will temporarily lead Swansea against Bournemouth. The club aims to swiftly appoint a new manager, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the top candidate. Curtis believes Swansea have deviated from their successful approach since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 due to frequent managerial changes. He emphasizes the importance of remaining in the Premier League, acknowledging the difficulty of immediate promotion if relegated, citing Norwich, Burnley, and Newcastle as examples. Despite believing the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation, Curtis highlights the significance of the club's history and the need for players to understand its value.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his work on the human genome project and the creation of synthetic life. His contributions to genomics significantly sped up the process of decoding the human genome, despite criticism from some in the scientific community. After the human genome project, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, Synthia, which was a decade-long endeavor. His career also includes work at the NIH, where he developed innovative gene decoding methods, and founding Celera Genomics, a company focused on cracking the human genetic code. Beyond genomics, Dr. Venter has explored marine life and collected genetic data through his project, Sorcerer II. His work has been controversial at times, but he remains a significant figure in genomics and synthetic biology, with his creations potentially leading to a new industrial revolution.

England's apprenticeship system is failing young people with a majority of apprenticeships being low quality and too short. In comparison to other European countries like Germany, who have a strong vocational education system, England has too many qualifications and too few employers offering apprenticeships. The report suggests that England needs to create more apprenticeships that are at least 3 years in length and at a level 3 standing. The report also suggests that no more than 10% of apprenticeships should be 2-year courses at level 2. The goal of increasing the number of quality apprenticeships is to boost the economy, improve youngsters' job prospects, and provide a path to good skilled jobs that rivals that of a university degree.

Sarah Storey, a British Paralympian, won the UCI Para-cycling Road World Cup time trial in Switzerland. With this win, Storey is now on track to possibly win her 17th title at the UCI Para-cycling Road World Cup. In addition to her cycling achievements, Storey was previously a swimmer and has won a total of 22 Paralympic medals across both sports. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference because the club failed to provide assurances that they could resolve their financial issues, despite being given several extensions. As a result, Chester has been reinstated, and Hayes & Yeading will remain in Conference South. The club's financial woes stem from debts owed to football creditors, including former players and staff. Hereford United had been given multiple deadlines to pay their debts but ultimately failed to do so, leading to their expulsion. Their expulsion follows a dramatic end to the previous season where a last-minute goal kept them in the Conference Premier, but those efforts are now void. The club's financial troubles have been ongoing since their relegation from the Football League in 2012, worsened by declining attendance. An offer from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club and resolve the debts was not accepted, and despite talks with other potential buyers, a resolution was not reached before the final deadline.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England since his 2009 debut. Although he was part of the England squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, his only playing time in those tournaments was a brief three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46, and scored his sole international goal during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers against Moldova.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a period of illness.  He was the founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), where he served as director for three decades, leading them across six continents and producing over 200 CDs.  Hogwood's legacy includes his work with leading orchestras globally, his significant contributions to historically informed music, and his role in nurturing the talents of numerous musicians who now hold prominent positions in orchestras worldwide.  His colleagues and peers remember him for his generosity, intellect, and ability to bring music to life through historically accurate performances.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream school in June because he was not coping. His family requested a place for him at a special school, but all the schools were full. The boy's mother is worried that other families will face the same situation as the special needs school system is at capacity. The Education Authority said they are reviewing the need for special school places and are trying to ensure that places are available close to where children live.

The Welsh Rugby Union has put in a bid to take over the Newport Gwent Dragons and stated that they view Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. Newport County has a lease with Rodney Parade until 2023 and expects the contract to be honored. The WRU's takeover will be put to a vote on May 9th, 2017. In 2013, Newport County agreed to a 10-year lease after gaining promotion to the Football League. The WRU had been made aware of the fact that Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. The WRU wants to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County can clinch survival this weekend if they win and their rivals Hartlepool lose. Relegation to the National League would be devastating for fans and the city of Newport.

Mohamed Sillah, a former Sierra Leonean rebel during the civil war, found solace and purpose through the Lifeline Nehemiah project after escaping the horrors of war and imprisonment. During the 2014 Ebola crisis, Mohamed and his team played a crucial role in educating communities, providing support, and establishing treatment centers, ultimately saving numerous lives. Now reformed, Mohamed focuses on investing in young people, believing they hold the key to a brighter future for Sierra Leone and the world. The Ebola outbreak in West Africa resulted in over 11,000 deaths, with Sierra Leone being one of the most severely affected countries.

The Wedgwood Museum's collection of 80,000 works will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire after a public fundraising campaign raised enough money to save it from being auctioned off. The collection will be gifted to the V&A Museum and loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The fundraising campaign was successful due to the goodwill and determination of those involved in the negotiations. The collection is important for Staffordshire and charts a significant part of Britain's cultural development.

Mark Wright is in talks to purchase 20% of Billericay Town Football Club. Currently, the club is owned by Glenn Tamplin.  Billericay is three points out of a playoff position.  Wright previously played in a series of non-league football clubs. In early March, the club signed Paul Konchesky, a former England International.

Blackpool and Colchester United tied 1-1. Blackpool's Jamille Matt scored the first goal of the match, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester tied the game with a goal by Kurtis Guthrie.  Colchester's Sean Murray was given a red card for a foul on Jim McAlister. The match ended with a score of 1-1.

The Fawley Power Station chimney, decommissioned in 2013 after over 40 years of operation, will become the focal point of a £1bn "merchant city" development.  The project will include a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry connections to Southampton and Portsmouth, with construction potentially starting in 2018. The chimney, standing at 198 meters, will be the tallest structure south of London's Shard. It was built in 1971 and supplied power to one million homes. The 300-acre site was acquired by Fawley Waterside developers in 2016, who plan to transform the chimney into a petal-shaped glass structure as the centerpiece of the development.

At the Hong Kong World Championships, Great Britain's Mark Latham secured a bronze medal in the men's scratch race, while the men's team pursuit squad finished fourth. In the women's team pursuit, the British quartet, featuring Olympic gold medalist Elinor Barker, placed fifth. Katy Marchant, an Olympic bronze medalist, was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint.

After a 10-year absence, Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell in the spring of 2016. He will reunite with his brother, Phil, to see their mother Peggy, who is being killed off after her cancer returned. Peggy's sons will be reunited with her one last time before her death. The Mitchell brothers, two of EastEnders' most memorable characters, will be played by Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden.

Tottenham Hotspur lost to Liverpool after a poor performance, especially in the first half, that manager Mauricio Pochettino said showed a lack of desire to win. As a result, they are now at risk of falling further behind in the Premier League title race, with Chelsea having the chance to go 12 points clear at the top. Spurs have struggled away from home against their fellow top-six sides, with only one win in their past 17 such matches. Their defensive record, which was among the best last season, has also suffered in these games. Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy criticized Tottenham's performance, noting their lack of pace and different mindset when playing away from home.

In Nigeria's elections, the APC won 19 governorships, dealing a major blow to the PDP, which only secured 8. This marks the PDP's first loss in key northern states and a shift in power dynamics. Though marred by some violence, the elections were deemed relatively peaceful. The APC's victory signifies a potential change in governance, but challenges remain, particularly in oil-producing regions where the PDP still holds influence. The PDP, once dominant, will need to introspect and rebuild under new leadership.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place July 19-22 in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, will feature acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean.  A new app will allow attendees to access online information, videos, and band interviews via augmented reality technology.  The app also allows people worldwide to experience the festival virtually.

Ofsted has rated Park View and Nansen Primary schools as inadequate and will terminate their funding agreements. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were also warned about potential funding loss. An anonymous head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools revealed that parents undermined her authority and disrupted an Ofsted inspection. The report highlighted concerns about Park View's management, failure to promote pupils' development, and inadequate safety measures, including allowing a guest with extremist views to speak at assemblies. Birmingham City Council will work with Saltley School to install a temporary governing board. Park View School plans to challenge the Ofsted report legally. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were given a list of actions to address, including ending discriminatory practices and ensuring a balanced curriculum. Ofsted's report mentioned a culture of fear and intimidation in Birmingham schools and an organized campaign to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology. Parents have criticized the Ofsted reports and accused inspectors of bias.

In Ipswich Crown Court, Honey Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter after the death of five-month-old Vincent Barker.  The prosecution alleges that Ms. Rose failed to detect swollen optic discs and refer the patient for further testing. The prosecution believes that had Ms. Rose identified the condition, it would have prevented the build-up of fluid in his brain that caused his death. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he found through an adult website and filming them. He also sent a sexually explicit clip of the encounter to the victim's sister. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and his case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing. The judge, Lady Wolffe, stated that she had to impose a sentence that reflected society's abhorrence at such conduct.

Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson hitting 56 runs in the first T20 against Afghanistan.  Afghanistan won with 171-4 with Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) leading the way. The two teams will meet again on Friday for the second T20.  Ireland captain William Porterfield said the team was aiming for 180 and came up short, which hurt them in the end.  Additionally, Ireland lost paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem.

Barcelona football club paid £48.6m for Neymar in the summer of 2013.  Allegations arose that the actual cost was much higher, leading to a judge in Spain investigating the transfer.  Barcelona FC insists they did not commit any offense but paid an additional  €13,550,830.56 to cover any possible divergent interpretations of the tax amount owed.  It is not yet confirmed if the case will be dropped.

The bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Thailand. Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun have been arrested and charged with the murders. The UK police traveled to Thailand to review the investigation and will be returning to the UK to compile a report for the families. Post-mortem examinations showed that Mr. Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Ms. Witheridge died from head wounds.

Scotland's women's football team, unbeaten in Euro 2017 qualifiers, can almost guarantee their place in the finals if they beat Iceland at home. Ranked 21st in the world, they aim to avoid past disappointments of play-off losses. Iceland, ranked 20th, also pose a challenge, with the two matches between them likely deciding the group winner. Many Scottish players, including Bayern Munich's Lisa Evans, now compete in top leagues abroad, benefiting the national team. Evans highlights the quality of the German league and the experience gained from playing alongside world-class players. The team is focused on qualifying for the finals in the Netherlands, a first major tournament for Scotland.

Apple has implemented a security feature to prevent third-party software from stealing photos from iCloud. This feature requires users to enter a four-digit code, sent to a trusted device, when logging into iCloud on a new device. While this feature was previously available, it is now required when using Apple's backup service. One expert suggests that Apple should make this feature the default, rather than an opt-in choice, as two-factor authentication is more secure than passwords alone. Apple plans to encourage users to enable this feature and use stronger passwords.

In the 2014 EU elections, UKIP had the most votes (4,376,635) and spent the most money campaigning (£2,956,737), followed closely by the Tories who spent slightly more (£2,980,815) but received fewer votes. Labour came in second place and spent the least amount of money. The Green Party came in fourth and spent £534,249. In total, the six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087 campaigning, with all but Labour spending more than they did in the 2009 elections.

Myles Anderson and Ruairi Keating have joined Torquay United. Anderson, a 27-year-old center-back, previously played for Barrow. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, was recommended to Torquay by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Torquay is attempting to climb out of the relegation zone.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old racehorse, died after winning the Cotswold Chase.  He collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary hemorrhage, a rare condition with no underlying health issues, according to the British Horseracing Authority. Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia where he would overheat and wobble, but he had not shown symptoms at this race. He had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

This article discusses the farewell speeches of several departing MSPs (Members of the Scottish Parliament), including Tricia Marwick, Duncan McNeil, and Alex Salmond. 

*   **Tricia Marwick** and **Duncan McNeil** are stepping down after serving since the parliament's establishment in 1999. 
*   **Alex Salmond**, the former first minister, used his speech to emphasize that Scotland is diverse but not divided and that the parliament should assume greater responsibility for governance. 
*   **Duncan McNeil** warned that the parliament needs to improve its accountability and scrutiny, suggesting that it could learn from Westminster's committee system.
*   **Annabel Goldie** also bid farewell, humorously mentioning her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. The article highlights the contributions of these departing MSPs and their reflections on the parliament's past and future.

A live-action version of Disney's Beauty and the Beast will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017. The film will star Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston.  Also starring are  Kevin Kline as Maurice, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision regarding potential charges related to the Hillsborough disaster at a meeting with victims' families.  Last year, new inquests concluded that 96 fans were unlawfully killed in the 1989 disaster. The CPS has reviewed evidence related to 23 suspects from investigations into the causes of the disaster and police conduct afterward.  Families anticipate a range of emotions as they await the decisions, but remain determined in their pursuit of accountability.

Chelmsford Prison is facing an issue with contraband items, such as mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, being thrown over the prison walls.  A resident living nearby the prison claims to have witnessed this occurring numerous times and that the prison has reached out to residents to discuss the issue. Although drones have been reported as another way contraband is entering the prison, the Ministry of Justice has found no evidence to support this claim at Chelmsford Prison. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the problem and is exploring solutions to better equip prisons to prevent this activity.  They also remind people that smuggling contraband into prisons can result in a two-year prison sentence.

72-year-old Sylvia Blackburn, a lollipop lady for 20 years, was hit by a car driven by 55-year-old Brian Wright in Kempston last December.  Mr. Wright says he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light or Mrs. Blackburn.  He says he is sorry for the injuries that Mrs. Blackburn sustained.  The trial is ongoing.

Eilish McColgan, a 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. McColgan, who placed fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5000m at the 2017 World Athletics Championships, will return to university to finish her final year. Though disappointed to miss the Commonwealth Games, she prioritizes her degree. McColgan is considering the 2018 World Indoor Championships as a potential target and aims for two or three more Olympic appearances in the future. After achieving a new outdoor personal best in the 5000m at the World Championships, she feels positive about her future potential.

In December 2000, 22-year-old Trevor Deely went missing after a Christmas party.  A recent search of a 3-acre site in Dublin, expected to last several weeks, is underway.  Earlier this year, investigators reviewed the case and enhanced CCTV footage from the night of Deely's disappearance. The footage shows Deely speaking with a man in black outside his workplace and later being followed by the same man.  Police are requesting this man in the footage to come forward as he has yet to be identified.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th after a two-year injury absence, defeated Stan Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 in the US Open. Del Potro will face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next. Nick Kyrgios also advanced, overcoming Dustin Brown in a five-set match interrupted by rain delays. Kyrgios will play Feliciano Lopez in the third round. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also secured victories in their respective matches.

Tunisia and Morocco were both facing issues that could have impacted their participation in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. 

Tunisia had lodged complaints against the Confederation of African Football (CAF) regarding a controversial penalty decision during their 2015 quarter-final match, prompting CAF to demand an apology. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) clarified that they never accused CAF or the referee of corruption, but maintained that the referee's decisions were questionable. Following a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou, the issue was resolved, and Tunisia's participation in the 2017 tournament was secured.

Morocco had been banned from the 2017 Nations Cup after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to concerns about the Ebola virus. However, the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned the ban, allowing Morocco to participate in the qualifiers.

McLaren, a once-dominant Formula 1 team with a rich history of championships, has experienced a significant decline in performance since 2013. Initially, the team struggled with chassis design but maintained a strong engine. Currently, the team boasts a competitive car but faces challenges with their Honda power-unit, a stark contrast to their past successes with Honda. Despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, McLaren's recent results have been disappointing. The team's history has been marked by cycles of triumph and decline, with periods of dominance followed by setbacks. Ron Dennis, a key figure in McLaren's history, has returned to the team in an attempt to restore its former glory. Dennis believes that McLaren will eventually break Mercedes' dominance and secure future championships. Fernando Alonso's return to McLaren was driven by his belief in the team's potential for success with Honda. While the team acknowledges the progress made, their current hopes rest on the belief that their car and Honda's engine will deliver championships in the future. The team's future success is crucial not only for Alonso's career but also for the reputation of McLaren as a leading name in Formula 1.

On October 6, 2014, police were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST after a sudden death. Several people were at the bar and receipts showed alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered a three-month closure of the bar. License holder Colleen O'Neill was fined £3,000 and James Thomas was fined £1,000 for allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge said it was a very serious offense.

Stephen Curry set a new NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, making 8 out of 276 in a game where the Golden State Warriors defeated the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. In other NBA action, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78. Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds for the Bulls, while Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds for the Heat.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised by YouTube star Bas van Velzen, who initially posed as a competition winner. Van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, impressed the players with his abilities, showcasing his talent in front of goal. The experience was memorable for both Van Velzen and the Liverpool players, who were amazed by his free-kick expertise. In a final surprise, Van Velzen revealed a t-shirt with Balotelli's famous slogan, "Why Always Me?".

For women diagnosed with the BRCA1 gene mutation, having their ovaries removed (oophorectomy) after a breast cancer diagnosis significantly reduces the risk of death. A Canadian study indicated that an oophorectomy reduced breast cancer death risk by 62% in women with the BRCA1 mutation and reduced death from all causes by 65%. The protective effect lasted for 15 years, with the greatest benefit seen in those who had the surgery within two years of diagnosis (73% risk reduction). The study suggests that oophorectomy should be considered as part of the treatment discussion for BRCA1 mutation carriers diagnosed with early-stage breast cancer. The same benefit was not observed for carriers of the BRCA2 mutation, highlighting the need for further research.

On Easter Sunday around 10 a.m. in Durham, North Carolina, a northbound Amtrak train hit and killed a married couple lingering on the tracks. The victims, Derek and Tina Lowe, may have been homeless. None of the train's 166 passengers were injured, but the train was delayed for nearly three hours. The accident occurred on Norfolk Southern property. The train was en route from Charlotte to New York City, and Durham is about 25 miles from its next stop, Raleigh.

Carlos Toro, a former Medellín Cartel member, became a DEA informant for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. Despite his valuable contributions, including aiding in the takedown of drug lords and a dictator, the DEA has not granted him citizenship. Now retired and facing deportation to Colombia, Toro fears for his life as his past enemies could seek revenge. While his former colleagues try to help him obtain a green card or passport, he remains in legal limbo and cannot receive social security benefits.

The U.S. body ICANN, which regulates internet addresses, is investigating Vox Populi, a Canadian company that is charging exorbitant fees for '.sucks' domain names. Vox Populi has been charging companies and celebrities, like Kevin Spacey, high prices to remove their name from the '.sucks' domain. ICANN has contacted the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. An advisory panel consisting of industry groups and companies like Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay have complained about Vox Populi's actions. The panel has labeled the company's actions a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory." If Vox Populi's actions are deemed illegal by regulators, ICANN may take action against the company.

In 1988, a baby boy's body was found in a pond in Weasenham St. Peter, Norfolk.  The unidentified boy was buried in the village church.  In 2015, police exhumed the body and used DNA to identify the boy's mother. She admitted to concealing the pregnancy and placing the stillborn baby in the pond.  No charges were filed relating to the death, but the Crown Prosecution Service is considering charges related to failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied and named Peter after the church where he was laid to rest.

Kristopher Hicks, 23, suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving taxi driven by Michael Young, 56, in Bath, England in 2010.  Young, mistakenly believing Hicks wouldn't pay the fare, drove him back towards the taxi rank against his will.  Hicks jumped from the taxi traveling over 20 mph, resulting in permanent brain damage and requiring lifelong care. The High Court ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, making him liable for damages, although the final amount will be reduced by 50% due to Hicks' decision to jump from the moving vehicle. A future hearing will determine the final compensation amount.

- On Wednesday night, Kansas experienced tornado sirens and sightings, with one reported near Goddard and others in southwestern Kansas.
- A potential tornado touchdown was reported in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding.
- Large hail was also reported in Farmington, Missouri.
- More storms are expected on Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold plans to aggressively pursue victory against Lyoto Machida in their upcoming middleweight fight. Rockhold aims to pressure Machida, forcing him into a brawl, while Machida, known for his elusive style, intends to utilize his technique and strategy to secure a win and a potential title shot. Both fighters express respect for each other's abilities while remaining confident in their own paths to victory. The fight is anticipated to be a clash of styles, with Rockhold's forward pressure against Machida's calculated movement.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light aircraft landed without its landing gear deployed, skidding along the runway on its belly. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, was able to take off again and fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, landing safely. The incident, likely caused by human error, is being investigated by the FAA.

Manchester City midfielder Yaya Toure has not performed well this season, and manager Manuel Pellegrini is disappointed. Despite this, Pellegrini will support Toure until the end of the season. City is also looking to overhaul its aging squad and will listen to offers for Toure. In the meantime, City will face West Ham without captain Vincent Kompany, who is injured. Goalkeeper Joe Hart says the players need to take responsibility for their poor performances. Pellegrini says he will support Toure until the end of the season, but the players also have responsibility. Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players by moving to City. Allardyce says Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair did not play much at City. He asks if Cresswell would be willing to join another club in a permanent deal if it meant less money.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive residing in the UK for over 20 years, will not be extradited to Italy as his 1999 seven-year sentence for being a Cosa Nostra member has expired under Italian law. Although his conviction stands, the sentence is void as it has been more than double the sentence length since it was issued. Rancadore's European arrest warrant will be withdrawn, and his case will be heard by the Italian Supreme Court and Westminster Magistrates' Court for discharge approval.  The decision follows a lengthy legal battle, including concerns about Italian prison conditions and Rancadore's heart condition. The delay in proceedings, partly due to a CPS error in 2014, allowed the sentence to expire. Some legal experts have criticized the time and resources spent on the case, given the eventual outcome. Rancadore, who lived under the alias Marc Skinner, was convicted in absentia for his role in the Cosa Nostra and taking bribes. He maintains his innocence and claims he changed his name to distance himself from his father's criminal reputation.

Mr. Mole, one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, will be ridden by AP McCoy in his final Grade One race. McCoy announced his retirement after riding Mr. Mole to victory at Newbury in February. Other runners include Special Tiara, Sacre, and Somersby.

40 years after her daughter Marcia's murder, Virginia Trimble Ritter decided to view the crime scene photos. Initially advised against it, she regretted the decision and ultimately saw them last year. The photos revealed the brutality of the crime, causing Ritter to express a desire for revenge against the murderer, Jerome Barrett. The case remained unsolved for 33 years until Barrett's DNA was matched to Marcia's clothing. He was subsequently convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years.

Rory McIlroy is determined to win the Masters Tournament to complete the career grand slam. He believes it's unthinkable that he wouldn't achieve this feat. The 2011 Masters, where he had a final round collapse, was a pivotal moment in his career, teaching him valuable lessons. Despite distractions off the course, McIlroy has achieved remarkable success, including winning four major titles. He views the golf course as his sanctuary, a place to escape pressure and focus on the game. He's eager to compete at Augusta and aims to win multiple Masters titles.

This week's trending stories include: a photo of four rainbows over New York, the crackdown on exotic dancers at funerals in China, Robert Downey Jr.'s interview with Channel 4, the Kylie Jenner lip challenge, a 102-year-old woman's trip back in time, a controversial prom proposal, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast", the trailer for Johnny Depp's new movie, a pregnancy announcement referencing the Fresh Prince, and a photobomb by a military dad.

At least 272 children were hospitalized in England last year due to Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) caused by alcohol exposure in the womb.  Experts warn the actual number affected could be much higher, with the World Health Organization estimating at least 1 in 100 UK babies, or about 7,500 annually, suffer from FAS-related issues.  FAS can cause lifelong physical, learning, and behavioral problems, and while the UK government advises limiting alcohol during pregnancy, some advocate for complete abstinence.

Shaun McKerry, a 31-year-old repeat offender nicknamed "Boomerang Boy", attempted to rob a post office with an axe. The shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled him, and his wife, Sam, hit McKerry with a baseball bat, disarming him. Police arrested McKerry, and he was sentenced to six years in jail for attempted robbery. McKerry had a history of offenses dating back to age 12, including shoplifting, vehicle theft, and burglary, earning him the nickname "Boomerang Boy" for always returning home after committing crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors stationed in Nova Scotia, Canada, have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman. The alleged assault occurred at a party at the Shearwater naval base. The four men have been released on bail with specific conditions: they must surrender their passports, reside at the Stadacona naval base, remain employed by the Royal Navy, and cannot leave Nova Scotia. They are due back in court on May 27th. The investigation is ongoing, and additional charges may be filed. If convicted, they could face up to 14 years in prison.

Valerie Jackson's four-year-old son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's Syndrome, a rare genetic skin disease that causes the skin to appear red, inflamed, and scaly.  Because of his condition, RJ has been mistaken for a victim of child abuse.  Often, people make cruel taunts and comments, and once police were even called while Mrs. Jackson was caring for her son.  Netherton's Syndrome is a severe form of ichthyosis that causes the skin to lose heat, water, and protein quickly.  There is no cure for the condition, but symptoms can be managed with regular moisturizing and cleansing of the skin.  Despite the challenges, Mrs. Jackson remains positive and sees her son as a beautiful and happy child.

Protein World's "Are You Beach Body Ready?" advertisement campaign in the London Underground sparked controversy and was eventually removed after its three-week run. The ad featured a bikini-clad model, Renee Somerfield, which drew criticism from feminists and body image campaigners who felt it promoted an unhealthy body image. An online petition to remove the ads gained over 50,000 signatures, and the Advertising Standards Authority received over 200 complaints. Despite the backlash, including vandalism of the posters and negative social media comments, Protein World defended its campaign, engaging in debates on Twitter and claiming the image was unphotoshopped. The company received threats, including a bomb threat, which was reported to the police. The campaign's removal also coincided with a planned protest in Hyde Park. The incident sparked wider discussions about body image and advertising ethics, with figures like TV presenter Susanna Reid and writer Katie Hopkins weighing in on the debate.

Following the general election, UK rail firms are planning fare increases up to 87%, despite party leaders' pledges to freeze or cap prices.  First Great Western's (FGW) plan to almost double some London-Cotswolds fares drew criticism from Prime Minister Cameron, who requested an urgent review.  FGW's changes aim to align the North Cotswolds route with other services, offering cheaper advance tickets as an alternative. Other firms, like London Midlands and Virgin, also announced increases, although Virgin claims their average rise is below the industry average.  These fare hikes contradict pre-election promises and have surprised passengers, particularly those on rural routes.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, has been left permanently blind in one eye after being struck in the face with a brick outside his Oldham home. The attack occurred on April 18th around 11 pm, just three weeks after he married his wife, Elaine. 

The couple was inside writing thank you cards when they heard a brick hit their window, followed by another shattering their glass door. When John opened the door to confront the perpetrators, he was hit in the face with a brick, causing severe injury to his left eye and forehead. Despite surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight.

Police are investigating the incident but have not yet determined a motive, suggesting it may have been a random act of vandalism. The couple has since decided to move out of their Oldham home due to fear and safety concerns.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has extended his contract for another year after recovering from leg injuries sustained in a road accident that killed his father in April 2014. Poynton had surgery and missed the entire 2014 season, but he returned to play during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the 2016 season after signing a contract extension. Graeme Welch, Derbyshire's elite performance director, praised Poynton's character and work ethic.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer that affected his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. During his radiotherapy treatment, Harley wore a superhero mask, which he decorated like a Ninja Turtle, to help him feel brave. Harley's story gained attention, and he even received Ninja Turtle gifts from Nickelodeon. After undergoing intensive chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley is now cancer-free. He will continue to have regular check-ups to ensure the cancer does not return. Harley's bravery has also led him to become the face of a Cancer Research UK campaign aimed at raising funds for research into childhood cancers.

Tim Sherwood believes Jack Grealish should focus on playing well for Aston Villa and let his international career prospects develop naturally. Grealish has impressed Sherwood with his recent performances, particularly in the FA Cup semi-final against Liverpool. He is eligible to play for both England and the Republic of Ireland. Sherwood's advice echoes that of Grealish's father, who also believes his son should prioritize club football. While a decision on international representation looms, with a potential friendly offering the chance to play for both sides, the focus should remain on continuing his development at Aston Villa.

Private jet travel is a growing trend among the wealthy. Landing fees at airports can vary greatly, with the three most expensive airports being in Japan: Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Narita International Airport in Tokyo, and Kansai International Airport in Osaka. Other airports with high landing fees include Toronto Pearson International Airport, Darwin International Airport, Bristol Airport, Chubu Centrair International Airport, Dublin Airport, LaGuardia Airport, and Salzburg Airport. Popular private jet routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas and Milan to Rome. The most expensive times to fly privately are during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix.

Cooper, a Labrador from Oregon, is known for his fast eating habits, as shown in a viral video where he devours an ice cream cone in one bite. His owner, Katie Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, often takes him and his friend Daisy for ice cream, ensuring Daisy gets her share first. Despite some criticism, Gallegos defends her choice, stating that Cooper is healthy and the treat is occasional. The dogs also enjoy Starbucks "pup-uccinos" (whipped cream), which Cooper similarly consumes quickly.

Gary Locke, former Hearts boss and Kilmarnock's interim manager, has been appointed as Kilmarnock's permanent manager after signing a 3-year deal. Locke initially joined the club as assistant manager to Allan Johnston, but took over in February when Johnston quit. He has lost only one game out of seven since his takeover.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, is fighting a school's threat to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, who attends Seminole County Elementary. The school claims the essential oils (manufactured by Doterra) she applies to her son to help with his autism are a distraction to other students because of the smell. The mother says she will continue to fight the use of the oils as they have a positive impact on her son. The school district has said they will not suspend the boy.

A large fire has destroyed a 90-unit beachside condo complex in Westhampton, New York. The fire began on Wednesday afternoon around 3 pm. The cause of the fire is unknown, but is being investigated. Witnesses say the fire was very intense, melting the paint on nearby buildings. The complex is only open between May and November. Building manager Rob Taber, who lived in the complex, lost everything in the fire. Firefighters were unable to enter the building due to the intensity of the fire.

Queen Elizabeth II, nearing her 89th birthday, enjoys riding her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She has been riding since the age of four and has a lifelong love of horses, especially fell ponies, which she also breeds. The Queen eschews helmets in favor of silk scarves while riding. Although she has cut back on riding due to a knee injury, she remains an enthusiastic equestrian and is often seen at the Windsor stables. The fell pony breed, one of the oldest, has been used as pack animals and for riding. The Queen's love for horses and her continued involvement with them, despite her age and injury, are highlighted in the passage.

A Brisbane man, Phillip Pama, has been charged with manslaughter after allegedly killing his neighbor, Leon Yeaman, with a single punch. The incident occurred after Pama confronted Yeaman about noise levels coming from his property late at night. Pama, a shift worker who was trying to sleep, claims he lashed out blindly after Yeaman pushed him. Yeaman, who was known to play loud music and yell, was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama was granted bail and the case will return to court on May 18.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, is a devout man who prays daily and believes in God. However, he never prays about football and keeps his professional life separate from his personal life, which includes his wife and children. Although he has a strong, and sometimes arrogant, persona on the field, he believes he is a good person who supports his family, friends, and even strangers.

Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show on April 1st, 2015 after an eight-year hiatus. Looking healthy at 91, he hosted the first game of the show before handing it off to current host Drew Carey.

Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. after allegedly attempting to break into a house at 12:30 AM on Friday. He was charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin's arrest follows another incident involving a high-ranking supervisor accused of misconduct, prompting investigations by the Homeland Security Department's Inspector General. These incidents are the latest in a series of controversies for the agency.

Atif Saeed, a photographer from Pakistan, left his car and approached a lion in a safari park. He got within 10 feet of the lion and took some pictures. The lion heard the camera's shutter and lunged at Mr. Saeed, who barely made it back to his car. He said he would not attempt to do it again.

The NYPD released an image of a tattoo found on an unidentified woman discovered deceased in Brooklyn on March 22.  The woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend. The tattoo on her right leg appears to be a heart with a ribbon and the name "Monique."  The cause of death is still pending a medical examiner's report. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom home on the back of a flatbed truck after returning from the UK. The home is powered by solar panels and they get water from a nearby spring. The project cost them $25,000 and took a year and a half to complete. The couple now lives in Nelson, New Zealand and are almost self-sufficient.

Research suggests that young children who share iPads in the classroom score better on literacy tests than those who do not use iPads in the classroom or use them individually.  A study by Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University found that kindergarten students who shared iPads scored 30 points higher on tests than students who did not use iPads or who used them individually. Blackwell theorizes that it is the collaborative learning facilitated by the shared iPads that makes the difference, not simply collaboration itself.  She suggests that schools should reconsider how tablets are used in the classroom, especially in the earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness.  Blackwell will present her findings at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without back legs in China has become an internet sensation after a video was posted of it learning to walk on its two front legs. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," lives with its mother and siblings who were all born with four legs.  The piglet uses its snout and front trotters to balance as it moves around, looking for food and interacting with its siblings.  This is not the first time an animal in China has become famous for adapting to a disability; a rabbit at a zoo in Liuzhou learned to walk on its front paws and became a star attraction.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, tire changer Todd Phillips was injured when Francesco Dracone's car spun while exiting the pit box, hitting Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg and was released. Dracone did not finish the race. Many cars struggled with traction due to rain.

Milton Vieira Severiano, a 32-year-old man, murdered his wife, 29-year-old dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, because he was jealous of other men looking at her.  Security footage shows Severiano dragging his wife's body into their garden, smashing her head into the pavement 11 times, punching her in the face 10 times, and then shooting her in the face 5 times with a handgun. Severiano was apprehended by police after crashing a stolen car during his escape. Police discovered four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in the stolen vehicle. Severiano confessed to the murder and is facing a life sentence in jail.

Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author, openly discussed her struggles with mental illness, revealing that anxiety nearly led her to suicide.  A combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation brought her to this point. Although she faced difficulties in her younger years, she has found some peace and acceptance of her anxiety.  Ms. Wilson highlights the link between anxiety and depression and emphasizes the need to address these issues, especially given the rising rates of anxiety among Australian women. She believes that anxiety is becoming the "new depression."  Support resources like Beyond Blue and Lifeline are available for those who need help.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with assault after hitting her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. The charges were dropped because Curtin was deemed justified in using force against the ex-girlfriend who was trespassing and refused to leave her home. The ex-girlfriend was found using heroin in Curtin's bathroom. Curtin's lawyer stated the ex-girlfriend was jealous of Curtin's relationship with the boyfriend, who is the father of her child. The boyfriend had a history of heroin use and had relapsed with the ex-girlfriend. Curtin has since reconciled with the boyfriend and is now living with her parents, while the boyfriend is not involved in his new child's life.

Gemma, a pit bull living in California with two children, was recently filmed spitting out a piece of broccoli that her owner had disguised as a treat. The video shows Gemma's immediate disgust after biting into the vegetable. It is hoped that the children in Gemma's household will not mimic her behavior and will develop a liking for vegetables. When not eating, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its website mistakenly directed users to a pornographic site. This occurred because the bank's page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards was shut down in 2011, and its URL was subsequently acquired by a pornographic site. HSBC has since removed the link and stated that they have no association with the external site. They also reassured the public that their website and internet banking services remain secure.

A 13-year-old boy, Marcus, and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in a second-floor bedroom during a house fire. Marcus called 911 and calmly gave directions to firefighters while reassuring his sister. Firefighters rescued the siblings through a window, and they were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The other three family members escaped on their own and were also taken to the hospital.

**Summary:**

Blue fluorescent algae, known as Noctiluca scintillans, recently lit up Jervis Bay on Australia's east coast, creating a stunning visual effect. This phenomenon, caused by millions of plankton emitting light, also occurred in Sydney in 2014.  Iain Suthers, an expert from the University of New South Wales, explains that the algae blooms in spring and autumn and is usually due to natural causes. The glow is a defense mechanism used by the algae.

New genetic tests can determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer tumors and the risk of recurrence. This allows some patients to forgo chemotherapy, sparing them from harsh side effects. Although tests like EndoPredict are currently expensive and often only available privately, they may be cost-effective for healthcare systems in the long run by reducing chemotherapy treatments. These tests empower patients to make informed decisions about their treatment based on their individual risk factors, rather than undergoing chemotherapy as a default.

Over 25 women in the Royal Navy have been airlifted off ships due to pregnancy in the last nine years, including at least one from HMS Illustrious and five from HMS Ocean. A "no touching" rule is in place, suggesting conception occurred before deployment or during leave. Data also reveals that between 2006 and 2013, nearly 100 female soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan and 102 from Iraq due to pregnancy, as military rules prohibit expectant mothers in war zones. The true number may be higher as some may have returned on routine flights.

A drone containing a small amount of radioactive cesium was discovered on the roof of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence. The drone was also equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle.  Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga addressed the drone incident, citing concerns about the potential for future terrorism, particularly at the Olympics and G7 Summit. Although there are flight restrictions around airports, there are no flight restrictions for most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Prime Minister Abe was away in Indonesia at the time of the incident.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in China, takes his 84-year-old mother to work with him every day because she has Alzheimer's and he fears she'll get lost if left alone. His father passed away, his wife works elsewhere, and his son is still in school, leaving no one else to care for her. He ensures his mother's safety during the motorbike ride by tying a sash around both their waists. His employers have provided a room for her at his workplace. Lu feels it's his duty to care for his mother as she cared for him when he was young.

Between 2005 and 2012, heavy drinking among Americans rose by 17.2%, especially among women, due to changing social norms and increased binge drinking. Binge drinking among women increased at a rate over seven times that of men. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers, and 18% were binge drinkers, despite the overall percentage of drinkers remaining relatively stable. The study highlights the health and economic costs of excessive drinking, exceeding $220 billion annually, and attributes approximately 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010 to alcohol. Experts suggest various factors contribute to the increase, including evolving social norms, the affordability of alcohol, targeted advertising, and relaxed alcohol control policies. The study utilized data from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System, analyzing information on approximately 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older.

Caesarean sections are being performed too frequently, placing women and babies at unnecessary risk, according to UN officials and the World Health Organization (WHO). Although life-saving in certain situations, caesarean sections carry risks such as infections and death, and should ideally be limited to 10-15% of births. Currently, over 25% of births in England are caesareans, a figure that has doubled since the 1990s. This rise is partly due to an increase in elective caesareans chosen by women anxious about natural childbirth. However, the WHO emphasizes the potential complications and financial burden associated with caesareans, contradicting current NHS guidelines that offer the procedure even without medical justification.

44 year-old Michelle Filkins was arrested on April 17th and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The homeowner, Mark Conklin, discovered Filkins in his Martha's Vineyard summer home, which is estimated to be worth $800,000. Filkins had allegedly broken in, lived there for at least a week, and sold the owner's belongings in a yard sale. Police have asked anyone who may have received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

A woman named Bella Crooke lost her iPhone at a party. It was turned into the police who then accessed her Facebook profile because the phone was unlocked. The police then posted selfies and pictures of the phone around the station in an attempt to find the owner. Bella's friends saw the post and alerted her. Bella then went to the station and was reunited with her phone.  She thanked the police and has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old hippopotamus was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult hippos. The calf's mother tried to protect her baby by staying with her herd, but one of the fighting hippos grabbed the calf. The mother hippo attacked the other hippo, but it only caused the hippo to bite down harder and fling the baby into the air. The baby hippo died hours later from its injuries.

A 3-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for £575,000. The low price is due to the lease having only 3 years remaining. Extending the lease could cost £3.35-£4.5 million, but the property could then be worth £6 million. The property is described as "unmodernised" but "bright and well-proportioned."  It includes 3 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, a reception room, a utility room, a lift, parking, and a communal garden. Estate agents report strong interest despite the short lease, with potential buyers including locals, developers, and end users.

A computer outage at 8,000 Starbucks stores in the US and Canada caused registers to malfunction, leading to the company giving away free drinks. The outage, which started Friday evening, was resolved by Saturday. Starbucks did not disclose the cause but stated it was due to a failure during a daily system refresh.  The incident prompted excitement on social media, with customers sharing their experiences. However, some Starbucks locations closed early to avoid further product giveaways. This event followed Starbucks' announcement of record quarterly earnings the previous day.

Terrorist training and radicalization of Muslims have been occurring in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. An officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit revealed that individuals involved in these activities engage in seemingly normal community activities as a cover for their ulterior motives. The officer highlighted a history of Islamic extremist activity in Wales dating back to 1998, including training in the Brecon Beacons and the involvement of individuals connected to the 7/7 bombings and other planned terrorist attacks. The officer emphasized the importance of community intelligence in identifying and addressing these threats.

A whale, feared to be extinct, washed up on an Australian beach. The Omura's whale, rarely seen in Australia, was found on a remote beach after a cyclone. The species was only first described in 2003 and little is known about it. The whale's skeleton will be preserved for scientific study and may be displayed in a museum.

Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, believes women should not be president due to their hormones, citing the possibility of starting wars. However, history suggests that male hormones have been more problematic in leadership roles.  Rios's view, while not unique, reflects a broader bias against women in leadership positions.  This bias limits women's potential despite their qualifications and achievements.  Evidence of this bias is prevalent in various sectors, including corporate boards and academia.  Hillary Clinton's candidacy faces challenges due to this bias, which is detrimental to everyone, regardless of political affiliation.  Equality benefits society as a whole, from companies to families.  It's crucial to encourage young women to pursue their aspirations despite societal biases.  Rios's intention to move to Canada if Clinton is elected is ironic, as Canada elected its first female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

89 year-old actor Robert Hardy is auctioning off over 200 items from his antique collection including paintings, furniture,  swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and books dating back to the 17th century. The auction, hosted by Dominic Winter Auctioneers, will take place this Saturday in South Cerney, Gloucestershire.  Notable items include a 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of Mr. Hardy with the bow. Mr. Hardy, known for roles in All Creatures Great and Small and numerous portrayals of Winston Churchill, is a military historian and expert on medieval longbows. He is downsizing his Cotswolds home and says he is sad to part with his collection.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted in connection with the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, in Winter Garden, Florida. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the day his mother's body was found. He has a history of mental illness and violence, and was recently going through a divorce. Neighbors speculate that the divorce proceedings may have triggered the incident. Shemansky is currently on the run and considered dangerous. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

Eugene, Oregon was selected to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The IAAF Council chose Eugene to host because they felt it was a strategic opportunity to host the event in the U.S. for the first time. The city had previously bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF felt that Eugene had what it takes to host the event after a presentation. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, befriended and lured professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his flat, where her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and his accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, robbed and killed him. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to 16 years in prison, while Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum term of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked".

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has historically struggled in the latter half of the season. Despite a strong start with Chelsea, including a potential record-breaking run for assists, his form has dipped noticeably since the beginning of 2015, mirroring a trend from his time at Barcelona.  Although he is integral to Chelsea's title hopes, his fatigue and decreased productivity are a concern for the team.  However, with several games remaining against teams he's historically performed well against, there is still a chance for Fabregas to regain his form and help secure the Premier League title for Chelsea.

Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old Jamaican forward, has impressed West Ham coaches while on trial with the club.  He also has offers from clubs in Belgium. West Ham are closing in on signing the highly-rated prospect. In other news, West Ham revealed that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, the cheapest in the Barclays Premier League, in an effort to fill the 54,000-seat stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Mike Lane, a huntsman, was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters, suffering injuries including concussion and broken teeth. Despite video evidence and a dossier of information provided to Wiltshire police, including names and car registration numbers of suspects, the investigation has been dropped due to insufficient evidence. Hunt supporters are dismayed by the decision, citing the severity of the attack and the apparent lack of effort from the police. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban face coverings for hunt saboteurs to aid in identifying and prosecuting attackers. While the case is currently closed, Wiltshire police stated it will be reopened if further evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American citizen and prominent member of al Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January.  Raised in California, Gadahn converted to Islam and joined al Qaeda in Pakistan in the late 1990s, becoming its chief English-language propagandist. He appeared in numerous videos, including some with al Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahiri, urging attacks on American and Jewish interests and praising attacks like the Fort Hood shooting and the Benghazi attack. Gadahn was indicted for treason in 2006 and remained on the FBI's "most wanted terrorists" list until his death.

A 5-year-old Chinese boy, Mai Zizhuo, is captivating audiences on social media with his impressive basketball skills.  He has been playing since the age of 2 and a half.  In a viral video, Mai showcases his ability to effortlessly score baskets and dribble two basketballs simultaneously, drawing comparisons to professional players.  His talent has garnered widespread praise and astonishment from Chinese netizens, with some even questioning if the video's authenticity.  Mai's rise to fame follows in the footsteps of other young prodigies in China, where there is a cultural emphasis on cultivating exceptional talent from a young age.

Tom O’Carroll, a former key activist for PIE (Paedophile Information Exchange), attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25. Hacked Off is a media pressure group campaigning against what it sees as the ‘biased and unfair’ Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants a statutory body to regulate the press. O’Carroll’s attendance will likely be an embarrassment to the group.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained to host a fashion show for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The show, put on by the label Ten Pieces, featured a monochrome collection of ten unisex clothing pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. The show took place in the empty pool and along the break wall, with the ocean as a backdrop. Guests enjoyed food and drinks while watching the minimalist, androgynous designs. The weather was unseasonably warm, with blue skies and sunshine throughout the show.

Boxer Amir Khan visited Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, a safari and adventure park in Northern California, with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa.  During his visit, Khan fed a white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions.  Earlier that week, Khan announced his next fight would be against Chris Algieri on May 30th.

The name of Palestinian teenager Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was killed by three Israelis in July, was added and subsequently removed from Israel’s memorial wall for fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. The teen’s family and Almagor, an organization for terror victims, objected to his inclusion on the wall because they felt his death was a result of a criminal act, not an act of terrorism. Following complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel removed Abu Khdeir’s name from the memorial wall and website.

A young boy repeatedly attempts to use his cat as a pillow. The cat moves multiple times to avoid this. Eventually, the cat goes inside. Later, the boy and cat reconcile and the boy feeds the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer and government witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his coaching job at a private school after his testimony revealed his past. Kushner had previously passed a background check when hired in 2010, but his 2007 arrest and subsequent charges, which were later expunged, were not disclosed to the school. Kushner also had a 2011 arrest and a DUI in 2008. He expressed regret and stated that he had moved past that phase of his life. The defense lawyers in the corruption trial have called into question the credibility of the government's witnesses, many of whom are former drug dealers.

An explosion and fire at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China, injured six people. The cause was an oil leak at an oil storage facility, and more than 600 firefighters were needed to control the blaze. Though there were no reports of chemical leaks, the incident sparked concerns due to the plant's history and the controversial nature of PX production, which has caused protests in other Chinese cities due to pollution concerns. The plant was relocated to Zhangzhou from Xiamen in 2007 after public backlash.

Jack Grealish, Aston Villa player, is known for wearing his socks low, just above his shin guards. He says it is due to superstition and he will continue to do so. He wears children's shin guards and has not gotten a kick to his shins yet. His first league start was in a 3-3 draw against QPR. He was pleased to get his first start and hopes to get a few more before the end of the season. The coach said he deserved to start, which gave Grealish a boost.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has severe brain damage and is unresponsive, according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston, and a source familiar with her condition. Although she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she does not respond to stimuli and requires a tracheostomy. Bobby Brown's lawyer, Christopher Brown, stated that she has a long life ahead but the quality of life is uncertain as she begins rehabilitation. Bobby Brown's statement about her being awake was made while he was in an emotional state, according to his wife.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in the Fed Cup after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki in three sets and Svetlana Kuznetsova won in straight sets against Julia Goerges.  Despite 13 double faults, Pavlyuchenkova won after Lisicki had 63 unforced errors and lost a match point. Russia is one win away from reaching the Fed Cup final.

New South Wales residents are bracing for more potential floods and damage as another storm system, similar to the one that occurred last week, is predicted to hit later this week, potentially bringing heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that further storms will hinder current clean-up efforts, particularly in the Hunter region, which was severely affected by the previous storm. Meteorologists predict that the storm will be different from the last, with heavy rain likely impacting the state's northern parts and southeast Queensland. However, the Bureau of Meteorology states it's too early to determine the severity of the approaching weather system. The SES is working to complete as many outstanding jobs as possible and is urging residents to prepare for the potential storm. They have over 1000 personnel in the field, including 200 from other states, assisting with the efforts.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model, denied claims in the Italian media that she had attempted suicide.  She stated that she had been hospitalized after collapsing due to low blood pressure which resulted in injuries.  She explained that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time and that she was recovering at home. In the past, Italian media had reported a suicide attempt by Ms. Moric in 2009.  She was once married to Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son.

If the royal baby is a girl, the public favors the name Diana, followed by Alice and Charlotte. If the baby is a boy, the favored name is James, followed by Alexander. The public is hoping the baby is a girl, with Diana being the preferred name. The public also supports William's decision to take a six-week paternity leave.

A suicide bomber in Kabul, Afghanistan killed 17 people and wounded 64 others near a group protesting the provincial governor. An Afghan lawmaker was among those wounded. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack and no other organization has claimed it.

Dani Alves, a 31-year-old Brazilian right-back with a successful history with Barcelona, will be leaving the club this summer after rejecting their final contract offer. Alves' agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that the offer of a three-year contract extension was rejected because it was conditional on Alves playing in at least 60% of Barcelona's matches. Negotiations are over between Alves and Barcelona.

Pablo Osvaldo has urged Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors. Osvaldo believes that the duo, who have South American style play, would be a good fit for Boca and that the fans would love them. He played with them previously and feels that of all the great players he's played with, these two would be the best fit.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old jockey, took a spectacular fall during a race at Wincanton, which has since gone viral online. Despite the fall, which resulted in only a minor cut, Ferguson was back at work the next day and is eager to continue his racing career. He has taken the incident in stride, acknowledging the humor and attention it has brought.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, posted a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram to celebrate the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron. Haskell, who rejoined Wasps in 2012 after stints with Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders, has played over 100 games for Wasps and earned 57 caps for England.

Wide leg trousers are a big Spring/Summer 2015 trend.  They are a good alternative to skinny jeans and can be flattering if styled correctly.  They can be dressed up or down, with denim being an easy way to achieve the trend. For a more dressed up look, try a wide leg trouser in a dressier fabric.  High heels are recommended to keep the look flattering and avoid being overwhelmed by fabric, especially if you are shorter.  Pair with a simple top to keep the outfit in proportion. Some designers who have showcased wide leg trousers include Gucci, Topshop, Celine and Stella McCartney.

Following student objections and a petition with over 200 signatures, the University of Michigan canceled a screening of the film "American Sniper," citing concerns about negative portrayals of the Middle East.
