- The Education Secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools.

Lilliard Gin, the first distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837, is about to open at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh. It is a small-batch operation that sources local ingredients. The gin is named after a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

Gary Green, who had consumed over two times the legal limit of alcohol, reversed a vehicle into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm in August 2013, resulting in Harry's death.  Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others under health and safety legislation, as the incident occurred on private land.  The HSE investigation found that Green had been walking towards a worker in a closed-off area when he backed the tractor into Harry. Harry's mother stated that her family has been significantly impacted by the loss of her youngest son. The HSE described the incident as an extremely tragic case and Green's actions as reckless.

Luis Suarez's four-month ban from all football-related activities has been lifted, allowing him to train and play in friendly matches. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) upheld the ban on competitive matches, including the remaining eight games of his nine-match international ban. Suarez can now train with Barcelona and participate in friendlies with Uruguay. His competitive Barcelona debut is expected to be against Real Madrid on October 26th. The Cas ruling also permits Suarez to attend matches and engage in promotional activities. Suarez's legal team considered the appeal a success, stating that Fifa's sanctions were disproportionate. Fifpro expressed disappointment that the court didn't reduce the length of the bans.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won the British Wife Carrying Race. They competed against other couples, including a Lithuanian couple who came in second. The course was 380 meters with obstacles including haystacks, a slope, and water pistols. The winners will go on to compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

In October 2014, the UK government will replace the paper tax disc with an electronic system, allowing people to pay for car tax via monthly direct debit.  This change will likely lead to fewer jobs processing refunds and tax discs at the DVLA in Swansea. However, the government has committed to retraining and redeploying staff to other areas rather than making redundancies. While some job opportunities will be lost, the new system offers advantages to drivers.

Hungary's Foreign Minister has stated that Hungary will not alter its stance on the new laws concerning asylum seekers, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and higher education, despite pressure from the EU. Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary, which would require a unanimous vote to pass. The EU is concerned about these new laws, particularly the higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University. Thousands of Hungarians have protested against these laws. The Hungarian government maintains that these issues are within Hungary's national jurisdiction and the EU should not interfere.

Disney's live action "Beauty and the Beast" film will star Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston.  Also starring are  Kevin Kline as Maurice, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts. The film will be released in the US on March 17, 2017, and filming begins in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a prominent journalist known for his wit and fearless writing, has died at the age of 62 after a battle with cancer. Gill, who wrote for the Sunday Times for over two decades, was praised by colleagues and fellow writers for his unique style and impactful contributions to journalism. His final column, reflecting on his illness, will be published in the upcoming Sunday Times. While admired for his talent, Gill's career was also marked by controversy, with some of his articles sparking outrage and criticism for their provocative nature. Despite the controversies, Gill's legacy as a gifted and influential writer remains.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper who performs in the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked by a Russian diplomat while performing in Ulan Bator. The diplomat was reportedly offended by Sukhbaatar's use of the swastika, which, while a Nazi symbol, is a traditional Mongolian symbol. Sukhbaatar's father said his son was in a coma for 10 days after the attack. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but said reports in the press were distorted. The suspect has not been arrested because the injuries were not deemed serious by police.

On Monday, Plane Stupid activists protested Heathrow Airport's expansion plans. They are charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. The activists will appear in court on August 19th. The protest was on the northern runway at 3:30 BST, prompting a security review by the Metropolitan Police.

Nick Selman scored a century (101 runs off 144 balls) to help Glamorgan reach a total of 220 runs after struggling against Gloucestershire's bowlers, especially Matt Taylor and Craig Miles, who took wickets regularly. Gloucestershire also found batting difficult and ended the day with a score that was evenly balanced with Glamorgan's. The match was notable for being Michael Hogan's first as Glamorgan captain due to Jacques Rudolph's injury. Selman was happy with his performance after a string of low scores, while Taylor was pleased with his bowling and the team's overall performance.

Craig Hughes from Flint was arrested in August after online chats with a Tennessee crisis center, where he made threats to ambush and shoot police officers responding to a false report. Hughes admitted to the charges and will be sentenced next week.  Hughes’s legal team stated he had no intent to harm himself or carry out the threat.

In a Royal London One-Day Cup semi-final match, Surrey defeated Yorkshire by 39 runs to advance to the final. Despite early setbacks, Davies (117) and Foakes (90) helped Surrey reach a score of 255-7. Yorkshire's chase faltered after a three-wicket burst from Meaker, and despite Bresnan's 68, they were bowled out for 236.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, began taking on water. The crew radioed coastguards for assistance, and the RNLI lifeboat crew responded by placing a pump on board and towing the trawler to Holyhead.

Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. The 24-year-old will be focusing on finishing her final year at university. Although disappointed to miss the Games, Muir is looking forward to future competitions, including potentially the World Indoor Championships in March and the next two to three Olympics. She is pleased with her recent performance at the World Athletics Championships, where she achieved a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m.

## Liverpool FC: A Season of Disappointment

Liverpool's performance this season has been a significant decline compared to their title-challenging form last year.  

**Reasons for Decline:**

*   **Loss of key players:** The departure of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's injury have severely impacted Liverpool's goal-scoring ability.
*   **Poor transfer decisions:** The replacement strikers haven't been effective and lack the work rate of Suarez and Sturridge.
*   **Lack of intensity:** The team is not pressing high or starting games with the same intensity as last season, resulting in fewer goals.
*   **Defensive weaknesses:** Despite significant investment, the defense remains a problem area, lacking leadership and a commanding goalkeeper.
*   **Set-piece struggles:** Liverpool's effectiveness from set-pieces has diminished considerably.

**Chelsea Match Preview:**

*   Liverpool are significant underdogs against a dominant Chelsea side.
*   Rodgers faces selection dilemmas, particularly in defense.
*   Liverpool need a solid midfield and attacking full-backs to compete.
*   Even with improvements, a Liverpool win is unlikely.

**Steven Gerrard's Future:**

*   Gerrard

A new £45m educational facility housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center will be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock. The East Ayrshire Council will seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after the renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock.

A sea mine, thought to be British and from the 1940s or 1950s, was found in a river near a swimming pool in Gourock. As a precaution, an area of the town was evacuated, with residents advised to stay indoors. The mine was moved to a safer location due to its deteriorated state, making it difficult to assess the amount of explosive material it contained. Ferry services were disrupted, and an exclusion zone was in place. The evacuation was precautionary, with no immediate danger to the community.

Following the Rio 2016 Olympic and Paralympic games, UK Sport has announced funding cuts to certain sports in preparation for the Tokyo 2020 games.  Overall funding was decreased by £2 million, with sports such as cycling, badminton, archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby receiving cuts. The goal of UK Sport is to prioritize funding to sports that demonstrate high potential for medal wins in the future. This decision has been met with criticism, particularly from sports such as badminton and basketball, who argue that cuts hinder the development of their athletes and overall competitiveness. While some sports face cuts, new additions to the Tokyo 2020 games, such as baseball and karate, may receive funding based on their medal potential.  The overall aim for Team GB is to secure between 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth’s East Cliff conservation area are slated for demolition to make way for new buildings.  The new construction will include a 90-room hotel and two assisted-living apartment buildings that will house 122 units. While the demolition was opposed by English Heritage and some residents, the Bournemouth council approved the project citing a need to support tourism and housing for the elderly.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier, was killed in an attack by Jake Vallely while off-duty in Brecon. Vallely was found guilty, while his friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter. The attack happened after a night of drinking, during which Vallely was heard boasting about being the "hardest man in Brecon". CCTV footage showed Vallely punching and beating Pte Boyd until he was unresponsive. Pte Boyd's family paid tribute to him, describing him as a loving and caring person with a promising career ahead of him. They also highlighted the support they received from the Brecon community.

Andrew Travers, Barnet's chief executive, left his position after polling stations in the borough turned away voters on election day due to missing names from the electoral register. An independent investigation will be conducted by the council to determine the cause of the problems and review the preparations for the EU Referendum in June. In the interim, deputy chief executive John Hooton will assume Travers' role.

Gateshead won the match against Wrexham with a final score of 2-1. Gateshead had a slow start in the first half but managed to tie the game before halftime with a goal by Sean Newton. In the second half, Gateshead played better and ultimately won with a final goal by Ryan Bowman, assisted by Jamie Chandler. Wrexham's manager noted that the team did not play as well in the second half as they did in the first, missing several opportunities to score.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014, which ranks the social and economic well-being of older people in 96 nations, has named Norway as the best country to live in and Afghanistan as the worst, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb, in collaboration with Airbus, is constructing a network of over 600 satellites to provide global broadband internet access, particularly to schools. This project necessitates a shift in satellite manufacturing towards high-volume, low-cost production using assembly line methods. Airbus, initially skeptical, has embraced this approach and established assembly lines in Toulouse and Florida. The project faces challenges such as securing funding, mitigating space debris, and obtaining regulatory approval. OneWeb aims to set new standards in debris mitigation by de-orbiting old satellites within two years and using a chase vehicle to remove defunct ones. The success of this venture and its impact on the satellite industry remain to be seen, as some specialized satellites will still require traditional manufacturing methods.

Scotland's budget will be cut by the UK government, despite the Scottish government's efforts to protect key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service. The UK government says that Scotland will have more spending available to it next year, but the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. The Scottish government also says that it could have reduced debt and the deficit without this scale of cuts. The UK government says that Scotland should focus on gearing up for its new powers and getting the best for Scotland, rather than grievance.

Individuals with profound disabilities and their caregivers frequently encounter difficulties due to the scarcity of Changing Places toilets, which are restrooms designed with extra features and space to accommodate their needs. While standard accessible toilets may suffice for some wheelchair users, they often lack essential amenities such as hoists and changing benches, forcing families to resort to undignified and unhygienic alternatives. Campaigners are advocating for mandatory inclusion of Changing Places toilets in new constructions of large buildings like shopping centers and stadiums, citing the significant impact these facilities have on the well-being and social inclusion of disabled individuals and their families. Although recommendations for Changing Places toilets exist, they are not compulsory, leading to inconsistent implementation. Architects and campaigners emphasize that making these guidelines mandatory would provide clarity and ensure that the needs of all individuals are considered in building design. Some organizations, like Arsenal Football Club, have taken the initiative to install Changing Places toilets and have witnessed positive feedback from both disabled and non-disabled users, highlighting the benefits of inclusive design for all.

Italian consumer groups have filed a complaint with the European Commission, alleging that McDonald's forces its franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees, thereby restricting competition and harming consumers. McDonald's denies the allegations, stating that its franchise model, based on shared risks and rewards, has been successful. The complaint is supported by the SEIU and European unions, who urge a full investigation. The European Commission will review the complaint and may launch an investigation if it deems the allegations credible. The consumer groups claim that McDonald's' long contracts and above-market rents for franchisees limit competition, reduce consumer choice, and lead to higher prices in franchised locations compared to company-owned stores.

After 13-year-old Joshua Martin was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve, the Bangor Elim Church started a social media hashtag campaign, #prayforjosh, requesting prayers for him. The hashtag received support globally and a billboard with the hashtag was put up by an anonymous donor. The hashtag brought together people from all over the world to support Josh in his recovery.

The UK Ministry of Defence plans to close Brecon Barracks in 2027.  Brecon and Radnorshire MP Chris Davies is against the closure and plans to fight the decision because of the Barracks' history and the negative impact on the Brecon area.  The Barracks have been in Brecon since 1805 and housed troops who fought in conflicts since the early 19th century, including the Zulus at Rorke's Drift.  Mr. Davies believes the closure will harm the Brecon area, which has high unemployment and a thriving military tourism industry.  Though the Barracks have 85 civilian staff and 90 military personnel, it is not believed that jobs are at risk.  The nearby Sennybridge training ground and infantry school at Dering Lines will not be affected.  The Defence Secretary stated that the closure is part of a larger reorganization that will see a specialist light infantry center created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan.  Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire and a storage depot at Sennybridge will also close in 2024 and 2025, respectively.  Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith agrees with restructuring the estate but is concerned about

The UK fishing industry has been characterized by many as a disaster for Britain due to the EU's Common Fisheries Policy. With Brexit on the horizon, the UK fishing industry has the chance to regain control and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, this is dependent on the UK government prioritizing the industry during Brexit negotiations and making trade-offs with the EU, such as continued access to UK waters for EU boats. According to the House of Lords, while Brexit offers opportunities, it also presents risks that must be addressed to ensure a successful future for the UK fishing industry outside of the EU. The government acknowledges the opportunities Brexit presents for the UK fishing industry and aims to ensure fair access, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA employee, leaked classified information revealing widespread surveillance of personal data by the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA). The NSA reportedly accessed data from major tech companies like Google and Facebook, along with phone records. This sparked a debate about national security versus individual privacy, with government officials defending the practice as necessary to combat terrorism while privacy advocates expressed concerns about potential overreach. The methods used, like the Prism program, remain largely secret, and the extent of involvement by other governments is unclear. The revelations highlighted the challenges of balancing security and privacy in an increasingly interconnected world, raising questions about data protection laws and the implications for internet users globally.

OpenAI, a new research venture, backed by investors including Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, aims to develop artificial intelligence to benefit humanity. The venture will focus on a "positive human impact" and be free from financial obligations, unlike other AI ventures. Some scientists, including Stephen Hawking and Elon Musk, have warned that advances in AI could threaten humanity, while others believe the risk is small. OpenAI's research will be free from financial obligations and will be distributed as widely as possible.

Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, who suffered a severe brain injury in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26th.  His Facebook friend requests exceeded the 5,000 limit as he received immense support.  Despite his injuries, Ben remains positive and dedicates his time to rehabilitation, fundraising, and the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother, Diane, highlighted the overwhelming response, including increased mail, website traffic, and visit requests. Facebook suggested that Ben transition to a public figure page or utilize the subscribe feature to manage the volume of interaction.

In 2011, 46.2 million Americans were in poverty, making the poverty rate 15%. While this rate remained the same as the previous three years, it is still concerning. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021, and the real median household income dropped by 1.5%. There was also a 1.6% increase in income inequality based on the Gini index, which was the first annual rise since 1993. However, the percentage of Americans without health insurance did improve, decreasing from 16.3% to 15.7%. It is important to note that the US poverty rate reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricket specialist, has extended his contract with Lancashire until 2019.  He is known for his impressive ODI centuries, including a record-breaking 46-ball century against Pakistan.  Lancashire's cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praises Buttler's talent and positive influence on the team.  Buttler will rejoin Lancashire for their T20 Blast game on Friday after playing in the Indian Premier League.

Four Type 22 frigates are moored in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting final bids for sale, with a decision expected in spring 2013.  Although no proposals for preservation were submitted, Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt hopes at least one can be saved from scrapping, perhaps as a reef, while the UK government wants at least one to be recycled in the UK to test the capacity of the industry.  The final decision will be based on the best financial return for the taxpayer.

Fiji has experienced racial and political tensions since 1987, leading to instability and international isolation. The tensions stem from coups led by indigenous Fijians against Indian-dominated governments, causing economic damage and emigration of Indo-Fijians. Military coups have occurred in 1987, 2000, and 2006, resulting in Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. Democratic elections in 2014 led to Fiji's reinstatement. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing and informal segregation. The economy relies on sugar, tourism, mining, and services, but trade and budget deficits persist, making Fiji a large recipient of aid.

Syria, despite setbacks, maintains its commitment to eliminating its chemical weapons stockpile, though it missed the initial deadline. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad cited attacks by terrorist groups on shipments to Latakia as a cause for the delay. He defended Syria's use of barrel bombs, stating they target terrorists, not civilians, and accused the US of supporting terrorist elements. Additionally, the Syrian government denied reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, claiming it repelled the attack, despite reports from organizations like the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Aleppo Media Centre suggesting otherwise. The prison reportedly houses at least 3,000 detainees in poor conditions. While only a small percentage of Syria's chemical weapons have been removed, Russia, a Syrian ally, has set a new deadline of March 1st for the transfer of all weapons to the coast for removal, with a final destruction deadline of the end of June. Despite the delays, Syria, through Mr. Mekdad, reaffirmed its commitment to fulfilling its obligations to the OPCW and the UN Security Council.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize shortlist has been announced, with six authors vying for the prestigious award. This year's shortlist includes three British writers (Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, and Richard Flanagan), two Americans (Joshua Ferris and Karen Joy Fowler), and an Indian author (Neel Mukherjee). The winner will be announced at a ceremony in London on Tuesday night.  Neel Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others" is the bookmakers' favorite, while former winner Howard Jacobson's "J" is also considered a strong contender. The shortlist has generated some controversy, with critics noting the omission of certain notable novels. Sales of the shortlisted books have increased since the announcement, with Karen Joy Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves" being the best-selling among the nominees. The judging panel, chaired by AC Grayling, will select the winner, who will receive £50,000 and a specially bound edition of their book. Last year's winner was Eleanor Catton from New Zealand for her novel "The Luminaries". The awards ceremony will be broadcast on the BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

PJS, a celebrity, is appealing against an appeal court ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media regarding alleged extra-marital activities. The Supreme Court will hear arguments and decide if the appeal should be granted. An interim injunction remains preventing the publication of PJS's identity. The injunction was previously lifted by the Court of Appeal as stories were published elsewhere, despite PJS's argument for the right to privacy. The Court of Appeal ruled that it was unlikely a permanent injunction could be granted as confidentiality had been lost due to the widespread nature of the story across the internet and various publications.

Fosse Park, purchased in August for £345.5m, has plans for improvement.  These include addressing parking and traffic congestion, and improving the overall aesthetics of the shopping park. The new owners are working with Blaby District Council to ensure the improvements enhance the gateway into Leicester. The goal is to create a more visually appealing and functional shopping experience for visitors.

Malaysia's Censorship Board (LPF) has approved the release of the live-action remake of Disney's "Beauty and the Beast" after a minor edit concerning a gay moment in the film. The film was initially held for review, sparking controversy and criticism from netizens. The film has been granted a P13 parental guidance classification and is now cleared for screening.  The "gay moment" involves LeFou, Gaston's sidekick, who struggles with his feelings for Gaston.

Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) in the area. Landlords who rent properties to more than three unrelated people need to apply for a license, which can cost ??1,000. Failure to obtain a license can result in a fine of up to ??20,000. Nationally, mandatory licensing for HMOs is aimed at houses of three storeys or more and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licenses affect properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling, Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett.

The leaders of Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil, the two largest parties in Ireland's parliament, are attempting to form a government to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will not be part of a coalition government but may support a minority Fine Gael government.  One of the main obstacles to forming a government is disagreement over water charges.  Currently, no party has enough seats to form a majority government.

The Sorrento ferry, traveling to Valencia, caught fire off the coast of Mallorca, Spain. Passengers were evacuated and rescued; at least three people sustained injuries, with one reported as serious. The cause of the fire, which started on a car deck, is unknown. Rescue efforts involved multiple ships, and passengers were later transported back to Palma de Mallorca. The ferry may sink due to the extent of the damage.

The Electoral Commission reported a record 46.8 million registered voters for the June 8th election, with a 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997.  Concerns remain about duplicate applications due to the lack of a central database linking local registers and the online registration system.  While the online system increased registration, it also led to a 30-70% duplication rate in some areas, causing administrative burdens.  Although claims of double voting surfaced, it's a criminal offense, and the commission recommends better cross-checking between electoral registers to prevent it.  Labour cautioned against measures that could hinder student and young voter registration.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player with a history of legal trouble, was found dead in his prison cell on Wednesday at the age of 40, an apparent suicide.  Phillips had a successful college career at the University of Nebraska but was plagued by off-field issues throughout his time in the NFL with the Rams, Dolphins, and 49ers. After his football career ended, he was convicted of assault in two separate incidents and was serving a 30+ year sentence. At the time of his death, he was awaiting trial for the murder of his cellmate.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to Lance Corporal for good behavior.  He is the 30th ram to serve as mascot since the mid-19th century.  Private Derby XXX has served since 2014, receiving an army number and pay for rations.  He has participated in events such as switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

Liverpool beat Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a thrilling game, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time. The win moved Liverpool closer to a Champions League spot and showcased the team's fighting spirit under Jurgen Klopp.

Klopp inspired his team to overcome a 2-0 deficit, invoking the spirit of their 2005 Champions League final comeback. The win highlighted Liverpool's resilience and never-give-up attitude, instilled by Klopp.

The atmosphere at Anfield was electric, with fans creating a cauldron of noise and color. Both Klopp and Tuchel praised the incredible atmosphere, with Tuchel acknowledging the belief in the stadium after Liverpool's equalizer.

While Liverpool's attacking prowess was on display, defensive vulnerabilities remain. Klopp's impact on the team and fans is undeniable, with his identity imprinted on the club in a short time.

Liverpool's Europa League run has echoes of their 2005 Champions League triumph, with growing confidence and the possibility of a Champions League return. Klopp, however, remains cautious and focused on the task ahead, forbidding his players from touching the "This Is Anfield" sign until they achieve success.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis and Scotland's Brexit Minister Michael Russell offered differing perspectives. Davis stated that the UK government would share Brexit negotiation updates with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, aiming for a "two-way information flow" to understand their views. Russell, while acknowledging the start of the process, criticized the UK government's lack of transparency regarding its strategic intentions, particularly concerning the single market and customs union. He emphasized the importance of single market membership for Scotland's economic prosperity. Additionally, the Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government's appeal to the Supreme Court regarding the triggering of Article 50.

A group of scientists at the University of Nottingham are studying a flock of cloned sheep, including four that are genetically identical to Dolly the sheep, to see if they age normally and how healthy they are. This research is important because it could answer questions about the long-term effects of cloning, such as whether cloned animals are more prone to age-related diseases. The sheep have undergone various tests, including joint X-rays and fMRI scans, to assess their overall health and look for signs of age-related illnesses like osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. The results of the study, which will be published soon, could have a significant impact on the future of cloning.

• Unbeaten Shutter Speed won the Musidora Stakes, ridden by Frankie Dettori.
• Trainer John Gosden will send Shutter Speed to the French Oaks instead of the Epsom Oaks.
• Stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Epsom Oaks.
• Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes.
• John Gosden might not run Cracksman in the Dante Stakes because of concerns over the ground.

Amidst the Brexit campaign, the British pound has fluctuated, dropping against the dollar and euro before recovering slightly and then falling again. The pound’s volatility is attributed to recent polls suggesting a potential “Leave” victory in the upcoming referendum, causing uncertainty in the markets. Investors are reacting to this uncertainty, with some hedge funds betting on the pound’s decline. Asian stock markets have also experienced significant drops due to Brexit concerns. While the FTSE 100 initially showed a muted reaction, it ended the day down. The “Leave” campaign argues that the pound has strengthened since March and that a weaker pound would benefit UK exporters, citing recent trade figures showing a narrowed trade deficit and increased exports.

Braintree Town lost to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten run to nine games. Braintree has lost their last three games. Despite the loss, Braintree manager Cowley remains positive, citing the team's successes as “remarkable". The Iron are currently sixth in the National League.

Starting in April 2015, local councils in Northern Ireland will be responsible for making planning decisions, which were previously handled by the Planning Service. This shift aims to democratize the planning system, offering councils more control over development in their communities. However, concerns exist regarding potential bias and a lack of transparency in the decision-making process, particularly given the history of discrimination in housing allocation and close relationships between developers and political parties. Ensuring fairness and accountability in the new system will require strict codes of conduct and potentially greater transparency regarding political donations.

In Winchburgh, a one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun, resulting in the amputation of her back leg. Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, discovered her injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA. The incident has prompted calls for the licensing of air guns in Scotland, a measure that was opposed by a majority of respondents in a government consultation last year. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward.

Liverpool has signed Christian Benteke, making him their second most expensive signing to date. Benteke comes from Aston Villa, where he scored 49 goals in 101 games. Liverpool has been struggling to score goals, especially after selling players like Luis Suarez, and hopes Benteke will help. They have also added other forwards like Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi. Benteke is a strong player with a proven track record, and experts like Paul Lambert and John Aldridge believe he will do well at Liverpool.

Tablet use in UK schools is rapidly increasing, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools currently utilizing them.  Although there is no definitive evidence that tablets improve academic results, head teachers report a positive impact, particularly in student motivation and family engagement.  However, the study also highlights the pervasiveness of technology in students' lives, with many using tablets and smartphones late into the night for social media and entertainment. One school headmaster, while unable to quantify the academic benefits, believes that providing students with tablets like iPads empowers them and better prepares them for the modern workplace.

The exhibition, Growing Up in the City, at the Museum of Liverpool, showcases 25 photographs spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, depicting the lives of children and social history of Liverpool. The images, curated by Kay Jones, were chosen from hundreds in the National Museums Liverpool's collections to capture the diverse experiences of childhood, including playtime and child labor. The exhibition runs until September 25th.

Myles Anderson and Ruairi Keating are joining Torquay United. Anderson, a 27-year-old center-back, previously played for Barrow. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, was recommended to Torquay's manager by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Torquay United, who are four points above the relegation zone, have won only one of their last six games.

Bolivia's new child labor law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental permission, reflecting the country's economic realities. The law also increases penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. Although the International Labour Organization (ILO) recommends a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries, Bolivia's law aims to balance international standards with the needs of its impoverished population, where many children already work to support their families. The ILO is reviewing the law to determine if it violates international child labor regulations.

Rosie O’Donnell, a 50 year-old actress, recently survived a heart attack after self-diagnosing her symptoms, which included sudden nausea and aches, by searching online. She took aspirin before visiting a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. O’Donnell’s heart attack is known as the “widow maker.” Although she did not call 911 when she experienced symptoms, she urges others to do so.

Che Labastide-Wellington, 17, was stabbed at a party in Kenton on Saturday evening and died an hour later. A 16-year-old boy remains in stable condition after also being stabbed. Police stated that Che was not involved in an earlier altercation at the party, but was targeted in a later scuffle in an alleyway. A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder. Two boys, aged 15 and 16, were arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed. A 14-year-old boy was arrested on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark reorganized its cancer diagnosis system about 15 years ago due to poor survival statistics compared to other European countries. The new system has three routes: 1) Fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with "alarm" symptoms; 2) Diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms GPs cannot diagnose; and 3) "Yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms that are unlikely to be cancer.  The changes have led to better organization and improved survival rates, showing Denmark is catching up to other Scandinavian countries in cancer survival. The Danish system's success may offer lessons for Wales, which has a similar healthcare system.

Powys County Council will take over consumer protection enforcement in the estate agency industry from the now defunct Office of Fair Trading. The local council will receive £170,000 a year to enforce the Estate Agents Act and will work with local authority trading standards departments across the UK, who will still be responsible for prosecuting offenders. Powys hopes this new responsibility will lead to more opportunities to take on work outside of the council.

Nurses could be trained to take on tasks currently done by doctors to address staff shortages. A review by the Nuffield Trust found nurses already filling in for doctors in some areas, but unions cautioned against using this as a quick fix for broader NHS problems. The report suggests reshaping the workforce to improve patient care and offer staff more fulfilling roles, especially given the increasing prevalence of long-term conditions. However, it acknowledges the need for funding to support this training and emphasizes the importance of maintaining high-quality training for doctors. The British Medical Association and Unison also stress the need for adequate doctor training and funding for staff development, respectively, rather than relying on support staff as a substitute for qualified professionals.

At 3:00 AM GMT, there was a crash on the Lower Bristol Road in Bath, which led to the road's closure until 2:00 PM GMT. This caused delays and disruptions for commuters and bus services. Investigations into the cause of the crash are underway, and bus services are expected to fully return to their normal schedule by the evening commute.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disagree on the environmental impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project. 

*   NRW estimates the project will kill 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout yearly. 
*   TLP disputes the figures, claiming they lack scientific basis and that their own modeling shows a 2% loss across all fish species.
*   NRW defends its assessment, citing a thorough review by independent and internal experts. 
*   The Welsh government supports the project but awaits the UK government's decision on its viability.

Northern Ireland's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of a new agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, to provide strategic leadership and direction for the entire sector. This was welcomed by Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill as a positive step for the agri-food industry, a key sector in delivering export-led economic growth, but she noted that the plans could impact other organizations and require further discussion.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a project to plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood in Northern Ireland to commemorate the 40,000 Irish lives lost in WWI.  The public is invited to participate in the tree planting on Saturday afternoon.  The trees will serve as a tribute to the Irish who served in WWI and will create a space for wildlife to thrive and the public to enjoy.  The project is part of a larger UK-wide initiative by the Woodland Trust to plant millions of trees in remembrance of those who died in WWI.

Hilary Mantel's "Someone Else's Skin" won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award. The book, the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome, tackles domestic violence and so-called honor crime. US author Sara Paretsky, creator of detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career. The awards were presented at the start of the Harrogate crime writing festival in North Yorkshire.

Mitchell Santner will return to Worcestershire for the T20 Blast in 2017 after his 2016 season was cut short by a broken finger. Worcestershire director of cricket Steve Rhodes said that Santner's injury was a big loss for the team and that they are excited to have him back. Santner said he is looking forward to returning and making an impact.  Worcestershire previously signed John Hastings as their main overseas player for the entire 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old British millionaire, was killed in a hit-and-run incident in Kiev in 2008. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, who was much younger than him, left him to return to a restaurant moments before the accident. An inquest ruled his death as unlawful killing, with evidence suggesting it was a deliberate act. Ziuzina, who quickly tried to claim her husband's assets after his death, is suspected of involvement in the incident. Although Ukrainian police initially closed the case, they reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011, though it remains inactive.

Charlie, a child from Merseyside, needs to fly back to Seattle for experimental treatment. After a failed T-Cell transplant and no treatment options available in the UK, the family was in need of funding for further treatment in the US. An anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment at Seattle Children's Hospital, and the treatment will begin as soon as possible.

Apple has implemented a security feature to prevent third-party software from stealing photos from iCloud. This feature requires users to enter a four-digit code, sent to a trusted device, when logging into iCloud on a new device. While this makes the system more secure, it is an opt-in feature, and some experts suggest it should be the default. One expert also points out that the 14-character recovery key, while adding security, poses a risk if lost or stolen. Apple plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

- Mark Wright is in talks to purchase 20% of Billericay Town Football Club.
- The deal may include a directorship role for the 30-year-old.
- Billericay are currently 8th in the Isthmian League Premier Division.
- Wright previously played for several non-league clubs.
- Glenn Tamplin, the club's new owner, said he was willing to invest heavily in the team.
- Former England international Paul Konchesky recently joined the club.

- MP Iain Wright has requested Mike Ashley to provide evidence regarding his company's treatment of workers.
- Ashley was asked to attend a meeting at Westminster to discuss the matter but has declined all proposed dates.
- The Business, Innovation and Skills committee will further review the issue of treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of minimum wage.
- If Ashley fails to attend the meeting, the committee will consider further action.
- Sports Direct has not provided a comment regarding the matter.
- Sports Direct had previously committed to reviewing worker rights under Ashley's supervision.

The report, "Putin. War", reveals Russia's involvement in the Ukraine conflict, despite their denial.  Evidence suggests Russian soldiers and equipment played a crucial role in rebel victories, with Russian generals directing battles. The report estimates Russia's spending on the conflict to be 53bn rubles.  The report faces challenges in distribution due to fear and limited public interest, as many Russians either remain unaware of the facts or accept Russia's involvement. The opposition, however, accuses Putin of orchestrating the war to bolster his popularity, potentially rendering the report ineffective like previous works by Boris Nemtsov.
Craig Nelson, 34, was found dead on Monday in Derbyshire. A post-mortem examination showed he died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield.

Carwyn Jones, First Minister of Wales, is unhappy that he was not consulted during the drafting of the Article 50 letter, which outlines the UK's strategy for exiting the European Union. Although the UK government has stated that it intends to increase the decision-making power of each devolved administration following Brexit, it is unclear which powers will be devolved and whether the associated funding will follow. While some in the UK government believe that the powers related to EU funding should be transferred to Westminster, this seems politically unlikely at present. More details about the process may be revealed in a white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

Two police cars were damaged in Newry on Friday night. Police described the incident as a mindless attack on officers and the Newry community. They appealed to parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts.

American Apparel’s board of directors filed a response to Mr. Charney’s defamation lawsuit in a San Francisco court. The board’s filing states that Mr. Charney engaged in conduct that violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy, citing illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts as evidence. They believe no company would hire Mr. Charney as CEO due to the risk to the company and shareholders. Mr. Charney's lawyer called the board’s statements false and accused the company of invading Mr. Charney’s privacy. Earlier, American Apparel was granted a restraining order against Mr. Charney.

Great Britain's men's basketball team will play Greece at the Copper Box Arena in London on August 23, 2017, at 17:30 BST. This is the team's only home game before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017 tournament. Coverage of the game will be available on BBC iPlayer, the BBC Sport website, and the app. The game is a rematch between the two teams after Greece beat Great Britain 92-64 in Patras, Greece, earlier in the month. However, Greece will be missing three players from that game. The game will be the first time some of the Great Britain team have played in London. After the game against Greece, Great Britain will travel to Poland for a four-team tournament as their final warm-up before EuroBasket 2017 which starts in September.

The iPhone's launch in 2007 was a pivotal moment in technological history, revolutionizing mobile technology and impacting various industries, particularly photography.  Initially met with skepticism and complaints about media hype, the iPhone's user-friendly interface and diverse functionalities proved revolutionary. Its significance is comparable to the Model T Ford's impact on transportation. The author, initially hesitant, now acknowledges the iPhone's transformative role and expresses gratitude for witnessing its launch, a moment that marked the beginning of the mobile connected era. While other companies like Amazon and Google have advanced AI-driven innovations, the iPhone's launch in San Francisco was a seminal event that shaped the modern technological landscape.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, at least 5 cats have died in the past two weeks due to antifreeze poisoning near Victor Avenue. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and urges residents to store all chemicals safely, especially antifreeze. The most recent victim, 7-month-old Meereen, died on Monday after consuming antifreeze, leaving her owner devastated.

- Greece's tourism industry is booming despite the Syriza government's implementation of austerity measures.
- The Greek people are not protesting the new measures, possibly waiting to see the full extent of concessions made by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras.
- Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and causing monetary austerity through bank closures.
- Greek businesses are struggling to obtain credit, which could negatively impact the economy.
- The new bailout will only be successful if creditors ease Greece's debt burden and offer hope for recovery.
- Brussels and Berlin should avoid triumphalism and forgive debt to help Greece recover.

After a 9-year absence, Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell in the BBC soap opera EastEnders for a short stint to coincide with the departure of Dame Barbara Windsor, who plays his mother Peggy Mitchell. Peggy Mitchell's character is set to pass away from cancer in the spring of 2016, and Grant will return to Albert Square to be with his family during this time. The Mitchell brothers, Grant and Phil, will reunite on screen for the first time since 2006, in what is being touted as a classic and emotional storyline for the show.

Alice Ruggles was stalked by Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, suspected Dhillon even before police arrived to inform them of Alice's murder. Alice's mother, Sue Hills, feels guilt over her attempts to reassure Alice that the police would handle the situation. Alice's parents have started the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking dangers. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power station, but the UK government has delayed a final decision. The project has been criticized due to environmental concerns, escalating costs, and foreign involvement, as one-third of the cost is covered by Chinese investors. EDF, the French company financing the project, has faced financial challenges and internal disagreements regarding the project's viability. While proponents argue the plant is necessary for the UK's energy needs and will create jobs, opponents like Greenpeace advocate for renewable energy alternatives. The government's delay raises questions about the project's future and the UK's post-Brexit energy policy.

A newly designed divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person with whom adultery was committed, which family lawyers advise against as it often escalates conflict. Although the form says it's not mandatory, it's feared that people will still fill it in. Naming the third party makes them part of the legal proceedings, potentially causing delays and extra costs. Statistics show that adultery was the reason for about 12% of divorces in 2015, with "unreasonable behavior" being the most common reason. While some petitioners want to involve the third party, lawyers and judges generally discourage it. The Ministry of Justice clarifies that naming the third party has always been an option, but not a requirement, in divorce applications.

- The forestry industry in Wales faces challenges from environmental policies that prioritize native broadleaf trees and recreational access over commercial timber production.
- Confor, a forestry advocacy group, reports a loss of 16,000 hectares of commercial forest since 2001 and highlights the need for replanting to meet timber demands.
- The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social considerations in forestry management through initiatives like the Glastir scheme, which encourages woodland planting.
- Confor argues that the current emphasis on environmental aspects hinders commercial forestry and that bureaucratic processes impede new woodland creation.
- The industry faces challenges in harvesting timber from remote locations and transporting it through communities, leading to potential conflicts with residents.
- Despite these obstacles, there's a strong market for Welsh timber, with sawmills expressing a desire for increased production if sufficient timber were available.
A boy was seriously injured after being struck by a vehicle in Coatbridge around 4:40 pm near Langloan Primary School. He was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow.

The passage describes Arctic Convoy veterans finally receiving the Ushakov medal from Russia for their service in WWII. Initially, the Foreign Office blocked the award as it broke the rules on foreign medals being given for acts that occurred more than five years prior. However, an exception was made, and the veterans received their medals. The convoys were incredibly dangerous, facing German attacks and harsh weather, and were vital in supplying Russia, allowing them to defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. The veterans see the medal as recognition for their service and a symbol of the wartime alliance between Britain and Russia.

## Concise Summary of the Probation Report:

**Unpaid work, or "community payback," is frequently not enforced effectively.** Offenders often complete minimal hours, and many are not penalized for non-attendance. While some high-quality work and positive offender experiences exist, the system suffers from poor organization and a lack of focus on rehabilitation. 

**Key issues identified:**

* Delays in starting work and lack of consequences for non-attendance.
* Inconsistent quality of work and management.
* Failure to tailor work to individual offender needs.
* "Community payback" seen as mere punishment, missing rehabilitation opportunities.

**Recommendations include:**

* Reducing instances of turning away offenders who report on time.
* Matching work to offender circumstances.
* Ensuring offenders face consequences for non-attendance.

**The Ministry of Justice has accepted the report's recommendations and is taking action to improve the system.**

Comedian Russell Brand has been accused of hypocrisy for advocating for economic equality while living in a luxury home. He has responded to this criticism in the past by acknowledging his wealth and fame but emphasizing his belief in personal and systemic change. He argues that his wealth doesn't invalidate his concerns about economic inequality and ecological disaster. He also admits to past mistakes and frivolous behavior but maintains that these don't detract from the importance of addressing inequality.

Dr. Craig Venter, a prominent figure in genomics, has significantly accelerated the field through his work on the Human Genome Project and the creation of the first synthetic life form, Synthia.  Initially driven by his experiences in the Vietnam War, Venter pursued medical research and focused on gene decoding.  His innovative approach, utilizing automated sequencing and focusing on active gene parts, led to breakthroughs, including the complete genome of Haemophilus influenzae.  Despite facing criticism for his methods, Venter continued to push boundaries, establishing Celera Genomics to compete with the public Human Genome Project and ultimately publishing his results in 2001.  His entrepreneurial ventures and scientific achievements have provided him with resources to pursue ambitious projects, including creating synthetic life forms and exploring marine microbial genomes through his "Sorcerer II" expeditions.  Venter envisions synthetic microbes revolutionizing industries and offering solutions to environmental challenges.

A survey of about 1,000 parents in England found that 80% of children who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school, and 50% of those children requested those foods at home. The research, commissioned by the School Food Trust, aimed to explore the impact of school meals on children's diets. Popular vegetables included carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while less favored options were aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach. School meals are seen as a way to introduce children to new foods and increase dietary variety, potentially overcoming the challenges parents face at home. Notably, school meals in England must adhere to nutritional guidelines, with around 40% of primary school children and slightly fewer secondary school children opting for them. In Scotland, the rate is higher, at approximately 46%. The survey was conducted online in February and March 2023 among parents with children aged 4-17.

Álvaro Morata transferred from Real Madrid to Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid.  Juventus included a buy-back option for Real Madrid for a fee of 30 million euros. Morata scored 27 goals in 2 years with Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias.  He also played in two consecutive Champions League finals.  The first appearance was as a substitute when Real Madrid won in 2014 and the second in 2015 when Juventus lost to Barcelona 3-1.  Morata debuted with Real Madrid's first team at age 18 and scored 10 goals for the La Liga team.

Kelvin Wilson is a 30-year-old football player who rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013. He was released in May and is currently without a team.  He made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground, having spent four seasons at the club prior to signing for Celtic. He has also previously had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is selling most of its Fresh & Easy stores to Yucaipa, which will keep about 4,000 of the 5,000 Fresh & Easy employees. Tesco will loan the new business around £80m. The remaining 50 stores will be closed. Tesco will take a £150m loss, some of which may be recouped depending on the success of the new business. In the event that Yucaipa is successful, Tesco has the option to buy back into the business. Yucaipa, run by billionaire Ron Burkle, specializes in supermarket and restaurant businesses. In April, Tesco reported its first loss in 20 years.

Lutalo Muhammad, a British Taekwondo athlete, encountered racial discrimination early in his career. He briefly thought about representing France but ultimately chose to compete for Great Britain. His current objective is to win a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Glaciers in the French Alps have decreased by about 26% in the last 40 years, accelerating since the mid-1980s. A new inventory shows glacier coverage fell from 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s. The retreat is more pronounced in the southern Alps due to lower elevation and different climatic conditions, with the Belledonne Massif seeing almost complete disappearance of glaciers. The northern Alps, including the largest French glacier La Mer de Glace on Mont Blanc, show less retreat due to higher precipitation and cloud cover.

Scotland's women's football team, currently undefeated in their Euro 2017 qualifiers, are on the verge of securing a spot in the finals. A win against Iceland at Falkirk Stadium would solidify their position.  Forward Lisa Evans highlights the team's determination to qualify after experiencing play-off disappointments in the past.  Iceland, ranked 20th globally, poses a strong challenge, making the upcoming matches crucial for both teams.  Scotland's squad boasts players competing in top leagues worldwide, including Evans herself, who recently won the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich.  Evans emphasizes the positive impact of playing in competitive leagues, like the German Bundesliga, on individual players and the national team's overall performance.  She believes that the experience gained abroad enhances the team's quality and contributes to their progress towards a historic qualification for a major tournament.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger, was arrested in England following harassment allegations by a woman. Campbell claims the allegations relate to some of his tweets, which he states were not threatening.  He was released on bail and is due back for further inquiries in mid-September.

Peta has suggested that Skegness’s mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, should be replaced by a fish with the slogan “Skegness- A Happy Plaice”. Peta believes the Jolly Fisherman promotes animal cruelty, while the mayor of Skegness believes the Jolly Fisherman promotes happiness and is a positive symbol for the town.  The mayor said that Peta’s suggestion would be considered but that he doesn’t see a need to change the mascot.

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match with a final score of 53-26. Though Georgia scored first, Scotland quickly took the lead with a try by Tommy Seymour.  Scotland dominated possession in the first half, leading 38-11 at halftime with tries from Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg.  Georgia's scrum caused problems for Scotland in the second half, resulting in a try for Vasil Lobzhanidze and a yellow card for Moray Low. However, Scotland finished strong with Hogg scoring his second try and Ali Price contributing a penalty.  Scotland's head coach Vern Cotter praised his team's performance, particularly their first-half dominance and ability to counter-attack effectively. He also acknowledged Georgia's strength in the scrum and their ability to compete for the ball.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38-28. Tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge gave Widnes a 14-6 halftime lead.  Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor scored tries in the second half to extend Widnes’ lead to 38-12. Castleford then scored three tries to close the gap, but Widnes held on for the victory. Widnes moved ahead of Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti man, was released from Guantanamo Bay after 12 years of detention. He was suspected of having links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, but a US review panel concluded he was not a threat. He will be sent to a rehabilitation center in Kuwait. His release follows a prisoner swap in May and brings the total number of Guantanamo Bay detainees down to 148.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, was observed with a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, a parade of 400 people, and a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. The service at Westminster Abbey concluded with the national anthems of Australia and New Zealand. The Gallipoli campaign, a significant event in the war, is remembered for the sacrifices made by Australian and New Zealand troops.

David Clarkson, who rejoined Premiership Well for his second spell in July, could make his debut for St Mirren against Alloa on Saturday. Clarkson has been playing with the U20s to keep his match fitness up and says he is ready to play. He has two caps for Scotland and has made almost 400 senior appearances at the club level. St Mirren are currently eighth in the Championship.

Bernard Matthews, the turkey firm, was sold to Ranjit Boparan.  There were concerns that the new owners would not honor the pension scheme agreements in place, but after discussions with the union, it was confirmed that the pension scheme agreements will be honored.  The new owners plan to invest in the business, implement cost savings, and utilize spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkey, with the goal of restoring the firm to a highly profitable business.

The new Cowes Floating Bridge has had a problematic start with breakdowns, groundings, and suspensions, causing disruptions and frustration for local businesses. The council has initiated a project review and offered free ferry crossings until July 2nd to gather feedback. Compensation for local businesses impacted by the ferry's issues is being considered, while the council has addressed some technical problems and is working to resolve the remaining issues.

Following Brexit, the UK fishing industry, which currently makes up a small percentage of the UK’s GDP, has the opportunity to become a leading fish exporter. However, this depends on the UK government prioritizing the industry during Brexit negotiations to maintain tariff-free access to the EU market, which may come at the price of allowing EU boats access to UK waters. The UK fishing industry also needs to ensure that fishing quotas are based on scientific advice and that there is a unified fisheries management approach across England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. Despite the challenges, the industry remains optimistic about the future of UK fishing post-Brexit.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, admitted to taking and possessing indecent images of children over a 10-year period. He was sentenced to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and has now been removed from the teaching register by the General Teaching Council Scotland. The GTC panel deemed his actions incompatible with the teaching profession and found a high likelihood of recurrence due to the volume of images, duration of the offense, and lack of remedial action. Geaney is prohibited from reapplying for registration for two years.

A large fire occurred at a waste recycling facility in Duncan Street on March 2nd, causing travel disruptions. Following the incident, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended the facility's operator, Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, from receiving further waste. While the fire service found the operator generally compliant with fire safety laws, the EA decided to revoke the site's environmental permit due to concerns about potential risks to the surrounding area. The operator has until August 7th to appeal the revocation, after which they must cease operations and remove all waste from the site. The cause of the fire is still unknown.

Syria, despite delays, maintains its commitment to eliminating its chemical weapons stockpile, citing attacks by terrorist groups as a hindrance.  They deny accusations of using barrel bombs against civilians in Aleppo, framing it as defense against terrorists.  Furthermore, the Syrian government refutes claims of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, stating it remains under government control, despite reports from organizations like the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Aleppo Media Centre suggesting otherwise.  The US expresses concern over delays in the chemical weapons removal process, originally slated for completion by June.  Russia, a Syrian ally, has set a new deadline of March 1st for the transfer of weapons to the coast for removal.  The OPCW acknowledges security concerns have hampered the process, but Syria insists it will fulfill its obligations.

England decisively won the second Test against Pakistan by an innings and 120 runs to level the series 1-1. Joe Root's exceptional performance, scoring 254 in the first innings, earned him the man of the match award. Pakistan's batting struggles continued, highlighting a lack of confidence and poor shot selection, while England's strong performance suggests they are well-placed to win the series, despite predictions it will be closely contested.

- The Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of residential care of older people in Wales.
- The review aims to gather evidence from older people and their families to understand their experiences (both positive and negative) with residential care.
- The goal is to develop recommendations for improving the quality of life and care for older people in residential homes.
- The review will investigate various factors impacting quality of life, including physical and mental health, social interactions, and the care environment.
- While supporting the review's aims, Care Forum Wales expresses concern about the lack of care provider representation on the advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, former Dons midfielder and Arbroath's player-manager, will be Aberdeen's new manager after Neil Cooper. Aberdeen's chief executive said that despite wanting to keep Sheerin at Arbroath, the chairman understood his desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin played for several Scottish clubs, Östersunds in Sweden, and was capped for the Scotland Under-21 team. He also led Arbroath to win their first national trophy and a promotion in 2011.

Following Bob Bradley's dismissal, Curtis and Paul Williams will temporarily lead Swansea against Bournemouth. The club aims to swiftly appoint a new manager, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the top candidate. Curtis believes Swansea have deviated from their successful approach since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 due to frequent managerial changes. He emphasizes the importance of remaining in the Premier League, acknowledging the difficulty of immediate promotion if relegated, citing Norwich, Burnley, and Newcastle as examples. Despite believing the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation, Curtis highlights the significance of the club's history and the need for players to understand its value.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his work on the human genome project and the creation of synthetic life. His contributions to genomics significantly sped up the process of decoding the human genome, despite criticism from some in the scientific community. After the human genome project, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, Synthia, which was a decade-long endeavor. His career also includes work at the NIH, where he developed innovative gene decoding methods, and founding Celera Genomics, a company focused on cracking the human genetic code. Beyond genomics, Dr. Venter has explored marine life and collected genetic data through his project, Sorcerer II. His work has been controversial at times, but he remains a significant figure in genomics and synthetic biology, with his creations potentially leading to a new industrial revolution.

England's apprenticeship system is failing young people with a majority of apprenticeships being low quality and too short. In comparison to other European countries like Germany, who have a strong vocational education system, England has too many qualifications and too few employers offering apprenticeships. The report suggests that England needs to create more apprenticeships that are at least 3 years in length and at a level 3 standing. The report also suggests that no more than 10% of apprenticeships should be 2-year courses at level 2. The goal of increasing the number of quality apprenticeships is to boost the economy, improve youngsters' job prospects, and provide a path to good skilled jobs that rivals that of a university degree.

Sarah Storey, a British Paralympian, won the UCI Para-cycling Road World Cup time trial in Switzerland. With this win, Storey is now on track to possibly win her 17th title at the UCI Para-cycling Road World Cup. In addition to her cycling achievements, Storey was previously a swimmer and has won a total of 22 Paralympic medals across both sports. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference because the club failed to provide assurances that they could resolve their financial issues, despite being given several extensions. As a result, Chester has been reinstated, and Hayes & Yeading will remain in Conference South. The club's financial woes stem from debts owed to football creditors, including former players and staff. Hereford United had been given multiple deadlines to pay their debts but ultimately failed to do so, leading to their expulsion. Their expulsion follows a dramatic end to the previous season where a last-minute goal kept them in the Conference Premier, but those efforts are now void. The club's financial troubles have been ongoing since their relegation from the Football League in 2012, worsened by declining attendance. An offer from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club and resolve the debts was not accepted, and despite talks with other potential buyers, a resolution was not reached before the final deadline.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England since his 2009 debut. Although he was part of the England squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, his only playing time in those tournaments was a brief three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46, and scored his sole international goal during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers against Moldova.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a period of illness.  He was the founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), where he served as director for three decades, leading them across six continents and producing over 200 CDs.  Hogwood's legacy includes his work with leading orchestras globally, his significant contributions to historically informed music, and his role in nurturing the talents of numerous musicians who now hold prominent positions in orchestras worldwide.  His colleagues and peers remember him for his generosity, intellect, and ability to bring music to life through historically accurate performances.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream school in June because he was not coping. His family requested a place for him at a special school, but all the schools were full. The boy's mother is worried that other families will face the same situation as the special needs school system is at capacity. The Education Authority said they are reviewing the need for special school places and are trying to ensure that places are available close to where children live.

The Welsh Rugby Union has put in a bid to take over the Newport Gwent Dragons and stated that they view Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. Newport County has a lease with Rodney Parade until 2023 and expects the contract to be honored. The WRU's takeover will be put to a vote on May 9th, 2017. In 2013, Newport County agreed to a 10-year lease after gaining promotion to the Football League. The WRU had been made aware of the fact that Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. The WRU wants to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County can clinch survival this weekend if they win and their rivals Hartlepool lose. Relegation to the National League would be devastating for fans and the city of Newport.

Mohamed Sillah, a former Sierra Leonean rebel during the civil war, found solace and purpose through the Lifeline Nehemiah project after escaping the horrors of war and imprisonment. During the 2014 Ebola crisis, Mohamed and his team played a crucial role in educating communities, providing support, and establishing treatment centers, ultimately saving numerous lives. Now reformed, Mohamed focuses on investing in young people, believing they hold the key to a brighter future for Sierra Leone and the world. The Ebola outbreak in West Africa resulted in over 11,000 deaths, with Sierra Leone being one of the most severely affected countries.

The Wedgwood Museum's collection of 80,000 works will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire after a public fundraising campaign raised enough money to save it from being auctioned off. The collection will be gifted to the V&A Museum and loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The fundraising campaign was successful due to the goodwill and determination of those involved in the negotiations. The collection is important for Staffordshire and charts a significant part of Britain's cultural development.

Mark Wright is in talks to purchase 20% of Billericay Town Football Club. Currently, the club is owned by Glenn Tamplin.  Billericay is three points out of a playoff position.  Wright previously played in a series of non-league football clubs. In early March, the club signed Paul Konchesky, a former England International.

Blackpool and Colchester United tied 1-1. Blackpool's Jamille Matt scored the first goal of the match, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester tied the game with a goal by Kurtis Guthrie.  Colchester's Sean Murray was given a red card for a foul on Jim McAlister. The match ended with a score of 1-1.

The Fawley Power Station chimney, decommissioned in 2013 after over 40 years of operation, will become the focal point of a £1bn "merchant city" development.  The project will include a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry connections to Southampton and Portsmouth, with construction potentially starting in 2018. The chimney, standing at 198 meters, will be the tallest structure south of London's Shard. It was built in 1971 and supplied power to one million homes. The 300-acre site was acquired by Fawley Waterside developers in 2016, who plan to transform the chimney into a petal-shaped glass structure as the centerpiece of the development.

At the Hong Kong World Championships, Great Britain's Mark Latham secured a bronze medal in the men's scratch race, while the men's team pursuit squad finished fourth. In the women's team pursuit, the British quartet, featuring Olympic gold medalist Elinor Barker, placed fifth. Katy Marchant, an Olympic bronze medalist, was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint.

After a 10-year absence, Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell in the spring of 2016. He will reunite with his brother, Phil, to see their mother Peggy, who is being killed off after her cancer returned. Peggy's sons will be reunited with her one last time before her death. The Mitchell brothers, two of EastEnders' most memorable characters, will be played by Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden.

Tottenham Hotspur lost to Liverpool after a poor performance, especially in the first half, that manager Mauricio Pochettino said showed a lack of desire to win. As a result, they are now at risk of falling further behind in the Premier League title race, with Chelsea having the chance to go 12 points clear at the top. Spurs have struggled away from home against their fellow top-six sides, with only one win in their past 17 such matches. Their defensive record, which was among the best last season, has also suffered in these games.
